Enter to them the rest of the Travetors, with Selindra very weak, who when they see Pollider dead, do let Selindra fall, who lies on the ground while they take up Pollider, and dress his wounds.

sp.speaker: Tene.
sp.p: Curs'd be that Woman, accurs'd our •… ate to loose our Prince thus.
sp.stage: They dress him as they talk.

sp.speaker: Teck.
sp.p: Now the blood issues at the wound, it may prove not mortal.

sp.speaker: Titi.
sp.p: The blood only choak'd him as he lay, you see his eyes look chearfully.

sp.speaker: Tene.
sp.p: Ye Gods, if any do take care of Hungary, [Kneels. look down on Pollinesso, and restore him to us.

sp.speaker: Selin.
sp.p: What's that he said?—was it Pollinesso that he named?

sp.speaker: Titius.
sp.p: The King will live, thanks to heaven for his deliverance.

sp.speaker: Selin.
sp.p: They call him King too; Pollinesso's name Selindra creeps to look on the hurt man, as they dress him. gives me Strength;—but that face is none of mine, and yet that name makes that face Lovely to me;—How I fool my self with vain hopes of what cannot be.

sp.speaker: Tene.
sp.p: How is it Sir, your looks are lively, and your wound though it did at first seem desparate, is not very dangerous.

sp.speaker: Polli.
sp.p: My tongue moves heavily and painfully, loss of blood makes me faint too;—how shall I travel with these wounds?—my stay here will be very dangerous, and my Journey to Belgrade, too long for one so weak as I am.

sp.speaker: Tene.
sp.p: The same gods that have preserv'd you to this day, will not let you fall thus.

sp.speaker: Selin.
sp.p:
They talk of Belgrade too; who can this
be?—give me way that I may gaze on this wonder.
sp.stage: She rises, crowds in amongst them, and stares on Pollider.

sp.speaker: Tene.
sp.p: Away wild Woman, thou Author of this mischief.

sp.speaker: Selin.
sp.p: He looks up again, those eyes are mine, I know 'um now.

sp.speaker: Tene.
sp.p: Throw her off, tear her away, she disturbs him, sure she is mad.

sp.speaker: Selin.
sp.p: Tis you are mad, tis you that love him not; why do you haile me thus? whither will you dragg me? did you not call him Pollinesso?

sp.speaker: Titi.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Selid
sp.p: King Pollinesso.

sp.speaker: Titi
sp.p: I think we did.

sp.speaker: Selin.
sp.p: That name is mine, those wounds are mine then.
sp.stage: She offers to go to him, but they hold her off.

sp.speaker: Titi.
sp.p: I wish they were.

sp.speaker: Selin.
sp.p: And so do I with all my heart, pray let me go to him, I can heal him with my tears;—I'le suck his wounds well, for I have heard wounds have been cur'd so.

sp.speaker: Tene.
sp.p: How comes his name in her mouth?

sp.speaker: Teck
sp.p: Twas not well done of us to name him as we did, best to stangle her, least she discover us.

sp.speaker: Titi.
sp.p: Shall I shoot her in the head? though the Act be horrid, tis better she perish, then all we.

sp.speaker: Teck.
sp.p:
Let us first hear what she will say to him,
we shall have time enough to kill her after.

sp.speaker: Selin.
sp.p: I pray who are all you?

sp.speaker: Titi.
sp.p: Tis very fit indeed that we should tell you.

sp.speaker: Tene.
sp.p: We are the hurt mans servants Lady, pray who are you? by whom we have receiv'd such dammage.

sp.speaker: Selin.
sp.p: If my eyes deceive me not, I may be happy; but am yet the most miserable, accurs'd Woman living.

sp.speaker: Titi
sp.p: I think so too:—

sp.speaker: Polli.
sp.p: What Woman is that weeps so?

sp.speaker: Tene.
sp.p: Tis she you rescued Sir.

sp.speaker: Polli.
sp.p: Did I rescue her?—loss of blood makes my eyes dazzle, and my fancy work even to a lightness; that face brings to my memory somthing that I have known:—why does she weep? and why do you hold her so rudely Tenedor?
sp.stage: Pollidor and Selindra both look earnestly at each •… ther.

sp.speaker: Selin.
sp.p: In charity to me Sir, though they know it not, for had they sooner let me know that Pollinesso liv'd, my suddain joy had slain me.

sp.speaker: Polli.
sp.p: What is this she sayes?

sp.speaker: Titi
sp.p: She is a Witch Sir I think.

sp.speaker: Selin.
sp.p: Does not my Brother know me yet? has my sorrows wrought such a change, that Pollinesso should not know me?

sp.speaker: Polli.
sp.p: Oh! my Astella, pardon my dull sight;—for I am very weak.

sp.speaker: Selin.
sp.p: Would I had dyed, rather then be rescued at this rate, so joyful, and so sad a day I have not seen before.

sp.speaker: Teck.
sp.p: He does but slumber Madam, and tis good he should do so.

sp.speaker: Selin.
sp.p: But slumber say you, it looks so like death, that I would dye to see it.

sp.speaker: Tene.
sp.p: Madam, the Joy will out-live the sorrow of this day, the Prince's hurt is without danger;—can your goodness pardon the rudeness which my self, and these Lords in our distraction, used you with?

sp.speaker: Selin.
sp.p: Alas my Lord, I was not sensible of what you did, my mind was so o're-loaden with my griefs, and so intent on Pollinesso, that I heard you not; Now while my Brother takes this rest, pray make me know how he escaped, when my Father and Barzanes fell, and why he has been thus long conceal'd.

sp.speaker: Tene.
sp.p: Madam, in that sad day, Pollinesso in vain attempting to save his Father, was with my self, and these you see here, cast on a sandy bank, from whence by good swimming we got to shoar, and have been since disguised for fear of Lascares, in several Princes Courts soliciting for aid, to force the Grecians to quit their stollen possession of Hungary; when in the midst of Pollinesso's preparation, he hears that Phillocles had resign'd the Crown to be preserv'd for you; This made us lay aside all further preparation for War, and thus disguis'd to pass this way to Belgrade: It seems by destiny directed to your rescue.

sp.speaker: Selin.
sp.p: I shall find some fitter time for my own story, twere good that we removed my Brother—he walks—how are you Sir, has this repose refresht you?

sp.speaker: Polli.
sp.p: I am something better then I was Astella, and shall soon be well, now I may look on thee.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: And I most happy! my brother you must give us leave to remove you to some place of rest, and safety, and you must be still conceal'd; which these new wounds, with your Perriwig will be disguise enough.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I shall be directed by you.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: You must also a little counterfeit your voice, least you be remember'd by it; for should Lascares know who were in his power, all his hopes of Hungarie would vanish untill he saw you dead; I am call'd Selindra here.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Who were those Robbers? and how came you amongst them?

sp.speaker: Selin.
sp.p: 'Twas Cleonell, who did beguile me, after he had sworn to carry me to Belgrade, was conveying me to his own Castle.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Was not Cleonell Cecropiu's son? and will not his death, be our ruine if we stay here?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: My interest in the Princess Ordella, will secure you, and his guilt was such a crime, as can expect no justice from the law to touch you; besides the rescue you brought the Prince, will merrit a reward,—but where is Phillocles? where is the Prince! we are all lost indeed, if he be falln; I have been so much distracted, that I mist him not till now!

sp.speaker: Tecknor,
sp.p: What Prince mean you Madam?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p:
Prince Phillocles! 'twas he my brother rescued; run, look, search about the Wood, for heaven sake search;—unfortunate Astella, and unworthy, that could thus long forget him; now
Pollinesso lives, I have no hate to Phillocles; methinks his vertues now look gloriously upon him—but how shall I look on Ordella? if her beloved brother have lost his life, to save my honour!

sp.speaker: Pol
sp.p: Was it Phillocles that I found fighting with Cleonell and his two men?

sp.speaker: Selin.
sp.p: 'Twas he.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: 'Tis strange I knew him not, but I now remember as I came in, he did persue the man that fled into the wood,—(let some look that way,) Selindra I must glory in my wounds, that have sav'd thee from false Cleonell, and relieved Phillocles, who my soul thirsts to see, next thy self most dear to me.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: And mine trembles at his absence.
sp.stage: Enter Phillocles bloody, and weary, leaning on his sword; he calls beforé he is seen to Enter.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Selindra, Selindra, is Selindra safe?—has she any mercy yet for Phillocles?

sp.speaker: Selin.
sp.p: She is safe and happy too, now she sees you alive sir; my heart is so much disturb'd by She goes kindly to him. my fears and joyes, that I know not how to express my gratitude: good sir, let these strangers dress your Wounds, they have shewed much skill on this hurt man.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p:
My Wounds are but slight scratches when
Selindra smiles; my joyes are much more dangerous then my Wounds.

sp.speaker: Selin.
sp.p: My life sir, and my honour you have saved, I must look on you with devotion! pray be pleas'd to own these our Redeemers, and give them some assurance of your Protection, they fear Cleonel's death may by Cecropiu's power with the Emperour, prove their destruction.

sp.speaker: Phillo.
sp.p: I will be their security, Selindras Redeemers shall command my Life; of what Country are they?

sp.speaker: Tene.
sp.p: Hungarians Sir, Men that since the late War have sought Fortunes in Forraign Lands, and now on private Affairs were returning home.

sp.speaker: Phillo.
sp.p: Unto you Sir, I have a great Obligation, such as my whole Life shall express my Zeale to serve you, for by you Selindra lives.

sp.speaker: Polli.
sp.p: Sir, I am rewarded much above my merrit, and shall bless the occasion that gave me power to serve you.

sp.speaker: Antilla.
sp.p: Sir, the Emperours much inraged at Cecropiu's hurt you gave him, and at your departure, staid us till now;—Is this Cleonels, or your own blood Sir?

sp.speaker: Phillo.
sp.p:
Tis neither, Cleonel fell by that Noble hand, whose timely ayd deliver'd Selindra from a
Rape, and me from death; My Arme Antilla •…
is grown weak of late, and thy good Sword so du •… it will do nothing in my hand.

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.p: But Sir, how comes it that you thus neglect your wounds?

sp.speaker: Phillo.
sp.p:
I have business of more weight to thi •… on, now Selindra smiles:—Antenor pray h •… you back unto Ordella, and desire her to be 〈◊〉 first relater of Cleonels death; bid her tell my F •…
ther of his horrid Treachery, and let her magni •… these strangers sent by the gods to saye the innocent, and to chastise the perjur'd Ravisher; ma •… hast Antenor, and tell Ordella that I am in Paradice.

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.p: She will be glad to hear that you are 〈◊〉 Sir.

sp.speaker: Phillo.
sp.p:
Well Antenor, why thou art well, and 〈◊〉 is he, and he, we are all well; But I am blest 〈◊〉 all my heart can wish for; tell my Sister the ge •…
tle and the fair Selindra smiles, and let her thi •… the rest;—I am all Ayre, Antillacus pray th •…
Exit Antenor.
help me to rub my wounds, a little smart may 〈◊〉 me know that I am mortal.

sp.speaker: Antil.
sp.p:
If I mistake not Sir, you'l finde sma •… enough in your Fathers rage, when he hears 〈◊〉
Cleonels death.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Some anger will do well Antillacus, to all •… this joy within me.

sp.speaker: Selin.
sp.p:
I have some fears too, least Cecropiu's m •…
lice may ruine us, you know his power Sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p:
Let not my Divinest Mistris have so me •…
a thought of my power to serve her, let not a sad look appear on this day, that you have dain'd to smile on Phillocles: Madam, tis time that we were moving towards the Town with our wounded friend; how must I call him?

sp.speaker: Selin.
sp.p: I think they call him Pollidor; Sir, though my confidence in you be equal to the value you are pleas'd to set on me, I cannot chuse but fear Lascare's anger, when I think on Cleonel.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Believe me Selindra, I will rather dye, then let them suffer.
sp.stage: He leads off Selindra, the rest take up Pollidor.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Thus let us march in Triumph to the Town,
Aloud proclaiming Pollidor's Renown;
While the Arched Heaven does Eccho its content,
To see Selindra freed from Ravishment.

div.head: THE FOURTH ACT.
div.stage: Enter Lascares, Ordella, Cecropius, Antenor, and Servants

sp.speaker: Cecro.
sp.p: SIr, I beg the due Execution of our Laws on Murderers.

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.p: And I Sir, beg mercy for those that have sav'd my Brothers life.

sp.speaker: Lascares.
sp.p: I may not hearken to thy suit Ordella, the Lawes must be inviolable, to pardon such a Murther, would pull down Vengeance on my own head, on thine too, on all our Family.

sp.speaker: Cecro.
sp.p: When you remember Cleonells faith, and his many services, I hope Sir you will not deny me Justice.

sp.speaker: Las.
sp.p: Cecropius you shall have Justice;—go you Antenor, and command the Provost of the City that he seize Selindra, and her fellow-Murtherers, let them be all close Prisoners in the black Tower; by to morrow this time, shall their bloods be shed, as they shed Cleonells.

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.p: Did you say Selindra should be Prisoner Sir.

sp.speaker: Las.
sp.p: I did.

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.p: Good Sir, call back Antenor till you have heard me speak.

sp.speaker: Las.
sp.p: I may not Ordella.

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.p: Who can forbid you to be Merciful, and Just? you break the Laws of Hospitality in this; Selindra is a stranger, she is innocent, and cannot suffer justly; Cleonel was full of horrid guilt, and was cut off by a just hand;—the Travellers too have saved Phillocles his life; good Sir, let not Cecropius malice perswade you to do, what you will blush to think on after.

sp.speaker: Las.
sp.p: They shall have Justice, and a Legal Tryall.

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.p: Oh Sir! where is your wonted mercy? whither is that goodness fled? how have I lost your favour, that cannot with my Tears, nor Prayers prevail on your mistaken anger.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Is it your Majesties Command that Selindra should be a Prisoner?

sp.speaker: Las.
sp.p: Must I aske your leave?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Though not my leave Sir, I cannot chuse but wonder at such rigour!

sp.speaker: Las.
sp.p: You have leave to wonder on.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Thus low Sir, I do humbly beg Selindra's He kneeles. Inlargement; and an equal Tryal for those that rescued us;—

sp.speaker: Las.
sp.p:
Selindra as chief accessary, must abide the
Sentence of the Law, in this case of Cleonel:—Phillocles thy mean Love has drown'd all my Favours, and Eclip'st all thy former actions; from this time I shall study to forget thee, unless thou wilt forget Selindra, and Lead the Army to relieve Astella.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I shall obey you Sir in this, and all things else, so you will be pleas'd to send Selindra safe to Ciprus, and set those innocent men free that saved my life.

sp.speaker: Las.
sp.p: Degenerate fool, I shall cure this disease in thee; Cecropius send presently for the Judges, Command them by virtue of this my Signet, to put the Lawes in present Execution, upon thy Sons Murtherers; let the rigour of the Law pass on them all.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Ye Gods, to what purpose are men innocent? why is virtue prays'd, and taught us?—Good Sir, consider how you do murther these innocents with a shew of Law, and a pretence of Justice.

sp.speaker: Las.
sp.p: How dare you talk thus?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: You make me desperate Sir.

sp.speaker: Las.
sp.p: Do not raise my temper higher, least I cu •… thee off, as if thou wer't no part of me;—they shall dye.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p:
Had the Gods so pleas'd, I wish my self the meanest of your Subjects, for I am now a slave unto your passions, and must inherit the cur •… that's due to all your guilts, such as I shake 〈◊〉 think on; 'Tis you Sir, that have murthered Cleonel, 'twas your poyson that Selindra fled from by your confining me, you gave Cecropius first, and
Cleonel next the power to become Ravishers; pray let the Law take notice of this;—It may free innocent persons.

sp.speaker: Las.
sp.p: Who am I tro? Is this Gallant my Son, or my Soveraigne?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Sir I do see fire, and fury in your eyes, and am prepar'd to meet it, 'tis better to dye with those are Noble, then to live thus neglected; by my hand two of Cleonells men fell, 'tis I am guilty of that sin of rescuing Selindra from a Rape: let your Justice and your Lawes grow famous by my blood, 'twill please Cecropius well; by all our Gods I'le not out-live those innocents.

sp.speaker: Las.
sp.p: Tis fit to take thee at thy word.
sp.stage: Lascares Draws and Runs at Phillocles to kill him, Ordella steps between.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: It will become your own hand best.

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.p: Have you another Son Sir, when you have slain my Brother?

sp.speaker: Las.
sp.p: Antenor call in my Guard, and carry Phillocles to the New Castle; see that he be safe, and close there, as you will answer it with your life;—I shall not trust you in the Army now Sir.

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.p: Pray Sir re-call this severe command, my Brother has no danger in him, you saw he did not avoid death, when your hand offer'd it.

sp.speaker: Las.
sp.p:
Antenor, I will be obeyed;—by Heaven Here all Intercede.
he dyes that dares dispute my Will.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: If I go to Prison Selindra dyes, there is [Speaks aside. none can help her, and then I shall have time hereafter to lament her sad fate; Sir, I aske your [He Kneeles. pardon for the harsh words I utter'd, I did believe those truths might touch you, and move compassion towards those you threaten so much rigour too: but I now see your anger has decreed them dead, and that you have the same thought for me; my last sute is, that since we may not live, we may dye together: I shall submit to any kind of Death Sir; But I have vowed to be no more confin'd.

sp.speaker: Las.
sp.p: You of the Guard seize on him.
sp.stage: As the Guard comes toward him he draws.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Against Imprisonment I shall endeavour what I can; command my death Sir, and I will welcome it.

sp.speaker: Las.
sp.p: Kill him;—Kill the Traytor;—dares none stir to do it? Is my breath grown so weak? I'le try my own strength then.
sp.stage: Lascares snatches a Partizan from one of the Guard, and wounds Phillocles in the breast slightly, Phillocles holding down his Sword opens his arms and receives the wound; they search his wound set him in a Chair, while Lascares stands amaz'd at what he had done.

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.p: Oh, my Brother's slain! how cruel, and unnatural a deed is this?

sp.speaker: Cecro.
sp.p: The Surgeons say the Chief Prisoner will not Live till Morning; I beg Sir, that the Sentence may pass on the rest.
sp.stage: Lascares gives Cecropius no answer, only points to Phillocles, lets fall the Partizan till then in his hand, and exit with Cecropius.

sp.speaker: Antil.
sp.p: 'Twas well the Emperours age did not permit his force to act his will, the wound has not past the bone Madam, 'tis but a slight cut in the flesh.

sp.speaker: Arman.
sp.p: 'Tis time that you hasten to the Army, for while Cecropius holds his power, you can not be safe here.

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.p: He advises well Brother, untill my Father be dispossest of this evil spirit that reignes in him, I wish you away too.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I think it must be so; the Souldiers I hope have not forgot their love to me;—My Dear Sister, pray will you o're-take my Father least in this fit he slay all our Friends; say that Selindra did fly willingly with Cleonel, and that she regards not my Love, say any thing to gain alittle time, untill I may do something to relieve them.

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.p: I shall do my best:—
sp.stage: Ordella at the door meets Lascares with Selindra in his hand, and Pollidor led in, he delivers Selindra to Ordella, and points to them to set Pollidor by Phillocles, then goes out with Cecropius and Servants.

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.p: What means my Father, by this dumb shew.

sp.speaker: Polli.
sp.p: Where are we now Tenedor?

sp.speaker: Tene.
sp.p: Truly Sir, I know not, but I see Friends here.

sp.speaker: Polli.
sp.p: Who are they?

sp.speaker: Tene.
sp.p: Those that brought you in were the Emperour, and Cecropius; you know Prince Phillocles that whispers with Selindra, that other sure is the Princess Ordella.

sp.speaker: Polli
sp.p: Is that the Princess Ordella?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p:
Your presence Madam gives me strength,
and your kind looks give life unto my drooping spirits.

sp.speaker: Selin.
sp.p: How miserable am I Sir, that am the occasion of all these evils.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Your own sufferings are the onely evils to be lamented, I could curse my self, that brings such troubles on you;—but Madam we forget to comfort this Gallant man, by whose sword we enjoy our lives:—Sir can you pardon me that undertook so much, and can so little serve you?

sp.speaker: Polli.
sp.p: It was an injury Sir, to think I would receive my life, ransom'd by your death.

sp.speaker: Phillo.
sp.p: By my wound Pollidor, I have appeas'd my Fathers Rage; by thy Wounds Selindra Lives, and through all these Clouds I see the Tempest ceasing;—cannot Selindra speak to him?

sp.speaker: Selin.
sp.p: I have a heart as full of Gratitude as yours Sir, but not yet any means to shew it; I shall make it my business to serve him.

sp.speaker: Phillo.
sp.p: Has my Dear Sister no complement for Pollidor? by whose valour she enjoyes Selindra and me.

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.p: Yes Phillocles, I am studying how to expresse it, for you two have left nothing for me to say: Sir I can only thank you o're again for my Brothers, and my Friends preservation, by which you have obliged me, and the whole Empire, and do deserve some publique Honour, and High Recompence.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p:
What honour, or what recompence can outweigh this you now heap on me? Madam, if what I have done, be a service that you will own, I have
no wish beyond it; I shall ever on this day keep a solemn Feast unto the Gods, that did direct my course that way, and gave me power to become as happy here, as in Elizium

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Let those Lodgings next to mine be made ready for Pollidor, I will not trust him farther from me;—Antillacus, go you with as little noyse as may be to the Army, and let the Souldiers know that I will suddainly be with them;—some take up Pollidor.

sp.speaker: Cecro.
sp.p: 'Twas not revenge, for Cleonel made me press your Majesty to do Justice on his Murtherers, but to cut off Selindra, by which Phillocles might have no hindrance to gain Astella;——But Sir, since you have freed the Prisoner, and are content the Prince shall marry Selindra, I have done; if you Sir, can lay by all thoughts of Astella; and that Crown, I shall soon forget a private losse.

sp.speaker: Las.
sp.p: I must laugh Cecropius to see how thou art abus'd by my feigned shew of kindness, which I only did to heal the wound I gave; had I another Son, by whom I might gain Hungary, Phillocles had found my Force answerable to my Anger; but 〈◊〉 confesse I did relent upon a suddain thought, which made me strike so feebly at him, for now to loose Phillocle, were to throw Hungary away, and to destroy Selindra, were by another kind of stroak to destroy Phillocles.

sp.speaker: Cecro.
sp.p: What other way have you Sir, that I cannot yet fancy.

sp.speaker: Las
sp.p: A sure one Cecropius, a way that cannot fayle, I will give loose reines to my Sons Love, let him run on, and Joy in his Beloved Selindra, whose sweets once had, and his young Appetite allayed (as most violent passions soonest are) then 'twill be best to take away Selindra by a poyson; then it may be done without suspition, while I urge on the Marriage, joyne in all the Nuptial Jollities, and put on such pleasing looks, as shall make thee doubt my purpose, though thou knowest my heart.

sp.speaker: Cecro
sp.p: I see not yet how this can get Astella, or that Crown.

sp.speaker: Las.
sp.p: Thou art grown so dull of late, that thou seest nothing; while this joy lasts, Astella may be found, and then Selindra dying, what can hinder Phillocles from getting Astella?

sp.speaker: Cecro.
sp.p: I do submit Sir, and must applaud your purpose, tis a design I do confess much above my reach, and the first mischief I have come short in.
sp.stage: Pollidor seen as in his Chamber, Enter to him Phillocles and Ordella and Selindra, the servants go off.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: You look chearfully to day Pollidor, we may hope to see you abroad shortly.

sp.speaker: Polli.
sp.p:
I believe I might venture now Sir, though
my Surgeons be not of my mind; but Sir, how do you find the good old Emperour dispos'd?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I like not my Fathers smiles Pollidor, his suddain starts into such extreams, makes me apprehend more danger in his kindness, then his rage; so that to prevent all further evils, I have a purpose to repair unto the Army; and tis Ordella's wish as well as mine, that Selindra would trust her self with me there.

sp.speaker: Polli.
sp.p: That may secure you both, but will not Selindra's Honour suffer?

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.p: Now that Selindra's interest, and his are become one, I see no reason she should fear to go, nor indeed any scruple why their Marriage may not be privatly, and presently dispatch'd, for while the business lingers thus, they give hopes to such Endeavours as would divert it, and do run daily hazzards, by staying here.

sp.speaker: Phillo.
sp.p: Ordella argues what my soul wishes, but Selindra's looks, do not consent to make me so soon happy.

sp.speaker: Selin.
sp.p: Sir, my looks do be-lye my heart, if they shew ought that would delay a happiness to you, for I have none beyond yours:—But Sir, above all other reasons, Pollidor (not being yet able to attend you) if he be left behind, will hardly escape Cecropius's fury?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Most true Selindra, he will be in danger, I shall therefore attend his recovery; without him I will not move; nor will I put a thought in act without thy Councel.

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.p:
You have both said well, but in my Judgement this is no fit time for such Complements,
when your lives are daily sought.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: If you be resolv'd to attend my recovery, I shall propose a sudden fancy of mine, to that purpose, which may secure us.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Speak it Pollidor.

sp.speaker: Pollidor.
sp.p: Suppose Selindra do ask the Princess leave to return to Cyprus, and give out that she onely expects her Fathers coming to convey her thither.—Sir, you may court Selindra publickly while she stays, and she seem to neglect your love, and put on a shew of kindness unto me, as in gratitude for my hazzards in her redemption, I will also counterfeit affection to Selindra, and give out that I am of better quality then I seem: This Sir, if well manag'd, will be ground enough to deceive their best Spies, and for some time secure us all.

sp.speaker: Phillocles.
sp.p: I approve your thought Pollidor, and if Selindra can undertake her part, doubt not me, I'le put on such a seeming jealousie, as shall puzzle the old Fox Cecropius himself.

sp.speaker: Selindra
sp.p: I shall easily observe my directions, and soon learn to be civil to a man I owe so much to!

sp.speaker: Phillocles.
sp.p: Come Ordella, while they practise love, we will reconcile us to the Emperour, and try to bring him on a present visit to Pollidor, before this fit of his good nature leave him.

sp.speaker: Ordella.
sp.p: Selindra we must find you sitting in a more familiar way with Pollidor then ordinary conversation does allow.

sp.speaker: Selindra.
sp.p:
I shall obey you Madam:—Now they
are gone, we may enjoy our selves, this happy design of yours, will afford us many hours of freedome.

sp.speaker: Pollidor.
sp.p: My soul is joyed to look on thee Astella!

sp.speaker: Selindra.
sp.p: And my happiness too great to be exprest by words! that you live, makes this Earth a Paradice to me; my heart can scarce make room for Phillocles, it is so full of Pollinesso!

sp.speaker: Pollidor.
sp.p: I am all thine Astella▪
sp.stage: Enter to them Tenedor, Tecknor, and others.

sp.speaker: Tenedor
sp.p: It is time Sir, that you retir'd to rest▪ you spend your spirits by so much discourse, which does retard your cure.

sp.speaker: Tecknor▪
sp.p: You should neglect no means Sir, for your recovery, least by a long stay here, some accident unlook'd for, may make you known.

sp.speaker: Tenedor.
sp.p: I wonder Phillocles does not call to mind that he has seen you.

sp.speaker: Pollidor.
sp.p: He believes me dead, as all others do; but I shall observe the best Rules for my recovery however:—Now Astella we have time to hear how •… ou were conveyed from Belgrade, pray make me know how you •… ame hither!

sp.speaker: Selindra.
sp.p:
That same night that you departed to the Army, and our first Embassadors went towards Greece, to implore Lascares's aid against the Germanes, I was by my Fathers own hand deliver'd
unto Periander, whom I was to call Father; and by him was brought to Ciprus, where the Plague then raging, he transports me with his family to this Town.

sp.speaker: Pollidor.
sp.p: How came you into the Court then?

sp.speaker: Selindra.
sp.p: On the first Feast-day, I went with Periander to the Temple, that I might see the Emperour, and the Princess Ordella, where the Princess casting her eyes on me, found mine so fixed on her, that I could not remove them, but blush'd, and still look'd on her: by what power led I know not, but she took a fancie to have me live with her, which Periander durst shew no dislike to: thus was I to my great joy call'd to Court, where I became a Companion to the Princess: within a short time Cleonel had affection for me, which did not free me from old Cecropius dotage: of which, with Prince Phillocles his worthy love, you shall know hereafter, for I have now held you too long from your repose.

sp.speaker: Pollidor.
sp.p: Dearest Astella thy words are balsome to my wounds;
sp.stage: Enter Lascares, Phillocles, Ordella, Cecropius, and train, and see them embracing.

sp.speaker: Phillocles.
sp.p:
Your Majesty will not think this honour too much for Pollidor, when you shall know
he is of better quality then he seems;—ha! what do I see?

sp.speaker: Lascares.
sp.p: That which should teach thee to have nobler thoughts Phillocles.

sp.speaker: Phillocles.
sp.p: How they are disturb'd!

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.p: They do it rarely well.

sp.speaker: Lascares.
sp.p: Sir, I am now come to excuse the imprisonment you had, and to give you thanks for my sons life; I shall rather endeavour to recompence your merit, then trouble you with words.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: Great Sir, this honour, with the many other favours I receiv'd, do shame me to think that you allow me a merit I cannot own; but if the Gods do give me life, my only business shall be to seek occasions to serve you and yours.

sp.speaker: Lascar.
sp.p: I shall contribute what I can to your health, and will please my self with the expectation of great things from you.
sp.stage: While they talk, Lascares observes Phillocles courting Selindra, and she neglecting him; Lascares observes Pollidor to be troubled at their Courtship, and is pleased at it.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: Sir, you oblige me beyond words to utt •… my sense of your favours.

sp.speaker: Lascar.
sp.p:
My purpose is to give you a kind welcome,
and a respect suitable to He goes to Selindra. your worth, and quality:—fair Maid, I know not well how to frame my discourse to you, whom I have so ill treated: but I shall no more disturb your joys, I do now make it my suit, that you will defer your return to Ciprus, I shall lay my Commands on Ordella, to deny you her consent to go.

sp.speaker: Selind.
sp.p: Sir, the favours and honours I have received here, are far beyond the ills you mention; and my happiness such in the Princess Ordella's love, that I lament the thoughts of my departure; but when I consider the mischiefs past, and foresee worse like to follow, 'twere madness not to fly them; when my father is return'd, I shall renew my suit to have the Princess leave to leave this place, and until then make it my care to tend this hurt man, my redeemer! to whom I owe my life and honour!

sp.speaker: Lascar.
sp.p: Selindra if I can add any thing unto thy happiness, I shall do it gladly, for thou art something more then I have ever found in woman.

sp.speaker: Philloc.
sp.p: What thanks do we owe Pollidor for this disguise! it takes Ordella beyond our hopes; did you observe how my father eyed us, while he talked to Pollidor?

sp.speaker: Ordella.
sp.p: Yes, and do believe Cecropius and he are gone to compare their notes, for that Fox was very vigilant.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Selindra let us enjoy this blest minute.
sp.stage: Phillocles leads Selindra to the Couch, and Ordella sits by Pollidor.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Sir, While the two Lovers whisper, pray oblige me with the knowledge of the occasion of your coming into these parts, by which we have received so great an obligation; and if you please to pass this time with the relation of your own story, unless with your self you would conceal it.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: Madam, My story is not worthy your eares, nor my self this honour:—yet I have a story,—such as will make me blush to utter, though no crime do belong to it:—nor am I what I seem, and yet not fit to appear other,—but, Madam, your commands are too high honours to be neglected, my own resolutions shall give way, and my nearest Concerns submit to your will.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: I perceive you are disturb'd at my curiosity, to know what I believe you would conceal; it may be you have vowed not to discover; truly Sir, for want of what to say, I onely said it.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: Madam, I was surpriz'd by your approach, which made my tongue appear less ready then my heart to obey you; your commands, Madam, are sufficient to dissolve any vows of mine, and since you will vouchsafe to hear, I shall relate.
sp.stage: Phillocles and Selindra come to them.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: How are you Sir, Methinks your eyes do shew some anguish in your wounds, do we not trouble you?
sp.stage: Here Phillocles and Selindra interrupt Pollidor, which puts him into some passion, for he now began to love Ordella.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: We have done ill to stay thus long, Selindra 'tis your fault, you should have directed better.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: No, Madam, my hour to rest is not so precisely to be kept, nor have I any pains upon me, as the Prince thinks; my wounds heal the faster for your company.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: You are civil Sir.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: Madam, the Prince's kindness, and his care is not at this time necessary:—pray Sir, if your occasions call you not, do not take your self away thus hastily.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Pollidor we know your civillity is great, our discretion must not be the less, I see you are disturb'd, and know your pains are great upon you; make no reply, we'l visit you again suddenly; come Ordella, let us leave Selindra to her charge; good rest unto my friend, all joys unto my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: Beshrew your kindness at this time—how like Tantalus was I?

sp.speaker: Selind.
sp.p: What mean you by this passion brother? shall I call the Surgeons?

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: No Selindra, they have no skill in my disease.

sp.speaker: Selind.
sp.p: You talk, and look, as if you wanted sleep, pray retire to rest.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: Rest Selindra! where can I find rest? Phillocles has taken all rest from me! did you not observe how the Princess sat down by me? and how she threw her favours on me! when in the height of all my joy, your approach destroyed me.

sp.speaker: Selind.
sp.p: If this be all, I must smile to hear you sigh brother.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: All Selindra! doest thou mock me? are thy own flames so weak? thou smilest at mine!

sp.speaker: Selind.
sp.p: I cannot chuse but smile when I rejoyce to see my wishes fall so fast upon me: you love the Princess, and she will love you, she must, she shall, nay, I doubt she does already! and have some fear the work will be too easie, if I undertake it.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: Now thou mockest me more then thou didst before! prithee Selindra be serious, and do not play with what torments me.

sp.speaker: Selind.
sp.p: What can be more serious? then to make a marriage between so great a Princess, and the King of Hungary? pray where can she make a better choice? or who can better plead your suit then I? Look to your wounds brother, leave this affair to me.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: My best wishes do attend thee, she ha •… rais'd in me such doubtful hopes, that they begin to vanish with her, and such fears to lose what •… never had, do throng so fast upon me, that on th •… sudden I am orewhelm'd,
sp.l: With doubts, with joys, with fears, so strangely mixt▪
My heart is Hell, until my hopes be fixt.

div.head: THE FIFTH ACT.
div.stage: Enter Selindra, pensive Cecropius meets her.

sp.speaker: Cecro.
sp.p: GOod day unto the bright Selindra! Selind. May your Lordship find many such.

sp.speaker: Cecro.
sp.p: Why do you fly me, Madam? I come in dilligence to make known to you, what concerns you more then any other business can, towards which you make such haste from me.

sp.speaker: Selind.
sp.p: I fled not from your Lordship, nor did I perceive that you had ought to say to me; what is your pleasure now?

sp.speaker: Cecro.
sp.p: My business is to preserve you from a certain ruine, and to set you above the reach of mischief, as high in honour, as you are in beauty, and in vertue.

sp.speaker: Selind.
sp.p: I were much unworthy such a favour, and not Mistress of any virtue, if I should not return a befitting gratitude;

sp.speaker: Cecro.
sp.p:
Know then Selindra, you are design'd unto your grave; your wedding robe will prove your winding sheet, if I prevent it not; the Emperour
puts on this shew of kindness, onely to destroy you with less noise; he does consent that Phillocles by a present marriage, should satisfie his appetite; after which you shall be poysoned, that the Prince may have no object between him and Astella: This by all our Grecian Gods is true, and this I have consented to.

sp.speaker: Selind.
sp.p: Can there be such a wickedness 'mongst men!

sp.speaker: Cecro.
sp.p: Can you doubt it, that have seen so much? or can you think Lascares will consider such a life as yours, when it does interpose between the Crown of Hungary and him?

sp.speaker: Selind.
sp.p: If this be so, how can I avoid it? shall I think you will betray the Emperours trust, to oblige me!

sp.speaker: Cecro.
sp.p: Madam, if you would please to look on your faithful servant with equal eys, and on your dangers with judicious thoughts, you'l see that Phillocles his love brings death;—and Pollid •… r methinks should not have gain'd an interest where Phillocles pretends.

sp.speaker: Selind.
sp.p: My Lord, I must confess what you have said, is worthy my most serious thoughts,—but my Lord, 'tis not fit that I treat farther in this affair, until my Father doth return; if you please to move him in it, my obedience shall follow h •… will.

sp.speaker: Cecro.
sp.p: Of his consent I make no doubt, my best Mistress.
sp.stage: She suffers him 〈◊〉 kiss her hand.

sp.speaker: Selind.
sp.p: But how can you secure your self, and me from Phillocles? will not his rage raise a revenge as ruinous, as this you would have me fly from?

sp.speaker: Cecro.
sp.p: Good Madam, let not so mean a thought remain with you; I have Lascares Scepter in my hand, and all the Frontier Towns in my Command; the Souldiers too, since Phillocles forsook them, are become mine; if my fair Mistress would by one kind look confirm my joys, it would encourage me to let her see at what a rate I value her.

sp.speaker: Selind.
sp.p: Truly my Lord, I blush to think that I have smil'd so much, upon so short acquaintance, Pray Heaven you have not a design to destroy me this way!

sp.speaker: Cecro.
sp.p: Can you think I will destroy my souls onely joy? to remove all such fears, I will now put my life into your hands.

sp.speaker: Selind
sp.p: How my Lord! your life?

sp.speaker: Cecro.
sp.p: You have heard, Madam, how the Hungarian Army marches towards Greece, it does so: drawn in by me, to my aid they came, to assist me to get Selindra, and to set Lascares Crown upon her head, if she will deserve it:—we are interrupted now,—think on me, and thou shalt wear this Imperial Crown, Selindra.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: What has caus'd thy clouded brow Selindra? has that viper vext thee?

sp.speaker: Selind.
sp.p: He has frighted me, and will anger us all, if he be not prevented, such horrid mischiefs he has in love to me reveal'd, as I shake to think on.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: To what tune run they?

sp.speaker: Selind.
sp.p: To several tunes, some to Love, some to private blood-shed, others to publick War, and in summ to ruine all that's good;—The Emperour will permit our marriage Sir, and after poyson me, that you may have leisure to gain Astella; but above all, Cecropius treachery must be lookt to; He has call'd in the Hungarian Army to make me his by force: he talked of a Crown too, that I should wear, if I would comply with him, and at that word you interrupted us: good Sir, make it a little more your business to prevent these Devils, and their designs.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: There is danger in this worthy our best care, Selindra, I see our stay here will still occasion new designs on us.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: And you too late, I fear, will find my counsel good, why may not I have credit to protect Pollidor in your absence?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: I think you may, but yet 'tis not fit to hazzard such a friend to the fury of that Monster Cecropius; besides Selindra is now engaged in honour to stay for him.

sp.speaker: Selind.
sp.p: Truly Sir, I think I am in honour bound not rashly to throw away a man that has preserv'd us both;—but Sir, when you shall consider that his wounds do now permit him to walk abroad, a few days more will get him strength to ride with us: during which time I can secure all, by dissembling a little kindness to Cecropius, by which I shall also discover his treaty with the Hungarians

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Pollidor is much oblig'd to you Selindra, I like well this noble humour in you.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: It does become her, my dear sister, it shall be my care to look after Cecropius now, and if necessity require, I will remove him speedily; I must leave you for some hours, Ordella to attend my Father; Farewel, my bright Mistress, pray, let your care continue unto Pollidor, and let▪ not fall your kindness to Cecropius, he may confess to you what no tortures can draw from him.

sp.speaker: Selind.
sp.p: It does concern me Sir.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: It does indeed, Selindra, thy gratitude to Pollidor looks hansomely; methinks as he recovers health, he grows comely, he shews to me as if he were above the ordinary rank of men, I dare say he has a Noble soul.

sp.speaker: Selind.
sp.p: Madam, you judge right, did you converse as I do daily with him, you should wonder at such worth; methinks I see greatness in his looks, and do observe that he holds in that lustre, with more advantage, then others shew it forth.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p:
He is sure some great Prince disguis'd,
Selindra! and a happy man he is, that has found one that can discover his conceal'd perfections so fully.

sp.speaker: Tened.
sp.p: Madam, my Master is now awake, and begs the favour of a visit.

sp.speaker: Selind.
sp.p: I shall follow your Lordship when I have brought the Princess to her Chamber.

sp.speaker: Ord
sp.p: Is he a Lord too, Selindra?

sp.speaker: Selind.
sp.p: Did I call him Lord, Madam?

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: Ask when you see him next, go Selindra; this Ceremony to me is needless, I shall find the way alone; 'tis fitter that you attend your charge, Pollidors wounds will not heal out of thy sight, Selindra;—I cannot chuse but wonder what kind of entertainment you can find for so many hours, with so great a stranger as Pollidor!

sp.speaker: Selind.
sp.p: Sure she is jealous, and I speaks aside. have been too free in praising him;—Pollidor and I do spend more hours discoursing of Ordella's beauties, then of all other matters; he admires your perfections, Madam; his other wounds are slight, compar'd with those he received from your eyes: for—

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p:
Hold, Selindra, I delight not in such saucy thoughts from Pollidor, nor does it become you to hear, much less to relate them unto me: I do •… ear, Selindra, you hope by this invention to dazle my eys, that I may not discover your own affection •… o this Pollidor; take heed you fall not from that
vertue you are valued for, if you do deceive my trust, or Phillocles his love, you will be neither worthy his anger, nor my pitty.

sp.speaker: Selin.
sp.p: Let me fall under the weight of both your angers, when I deserve ill from either of you, your jealousie afflicts me Madam.

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.p: I hear my Brother coming, retire that he may not see thy tears, and meet me in the Garden after supper, then I will hear more of this, and till then suspend my Judgement of thee.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Why went Selindra weeping out? and what troubles you my Dear Sister?

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.p: I am not troubl'd now Sir: pray how did you find my Father? in what temper is he?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Well Ordella, all is safe yet; but I cannot be satisfied until you tell me why Selindra weep •… ;—your silence will beget doubts more troublesome, then the knowledge can be.

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.p: 'Twas nothing but an Argument that fell between us.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: That Argument Ordella, if thou lov'st my peace, that Argument.

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.p: I may wrong Selindra by it, and trouble you without a cause, when I am certainly informed you shall be so, till then pray do not urge me farther.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p:
I am so weak a man in thy Esteem, thou darest not trust me with my self; Ordella, thy discourse
will disturb me much, unless thou lettest me know the whole matter.

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.p: My unwillingness to tell you, is now become the onely cause I fear to do it, for I was questioning Selindra onely about her frequent visits to Pollidor, which it seems I put into such Language, as made her weep; this on my credit is the truth, are you now satisfied?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I am satisfied that we have the same thoughts, your judgement on this matter, confirms my observations, which till now took no hold on me;—If she prove false, thus I can blow her off;—But Pollidor, shall pay deare for his Treachery.
sp.stage: Enter to them Pollidor, very weak in Rich Cloaths; a staff in his hand.

sp.speaker: Polli.
sp.p: Madam, 'tis fit that I visit you before the Temple, and pay my first vowes at your shrine, offering up a Life devoted to your service.

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.p: You owe your health Sir, next to the Gods, unto Selindra's care, such a Gratitude I have not seen before, nor such a zeal as hers to serve you.

sp.speaker: Polli.
sp.p: My Obligations to Selindra, I must rank after the Honours I have received from you [He turns to Phillocles Madam:—Pray Sir, how does the Emperour, and Cecropius, take this fained love between Selindra and me? how does it work with them?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Since Selindra dwelt with you, the whole Court believes it is a mutual Love; onely my Sister and my self, have other thoughts.

sp.speaker: Polli.
sp.p: (Those last words came coldly out, I must remove this jealousie;) I am glad Sir that you are secur'd by it, and I am joy'd to have a hand in any thing, that shall conduce to serve you, I do profess my Medicines have not so much wrought my cure, as the joy I have to see such unparalleld Virtues, and Affections meet, as is yours, and the good Selindra's; day by day she tires her tongue in praising Phillocles, and still grows fresh by talking of you Sir; I cannot wish you greater happiness on Earth, then you will have with her, may it last while you last, and my Eternal Curses light on those that wish it less.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I thank you Sir, and will hope to prosper, as you pray for me, and next to Selindra, and my Sister, place you by my heart.

sp.speaker: Polli.
sp.p: You Honour me too much, and will make me proud, I must take my leave Sir, my strength is not yet enough confirm'd to stay long abroad.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: The Gods go with thee, thou Man of Honour.

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.p: What think you Brother of this Complement?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I think him really what he seems.

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.p:
I wish I could do so too, but when I call to mind that Selindra unto me did talk just thus of
Pollidor, as he now discours'd to you of her, methinks it looks like a design.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Does Pollidor presume to pretend to you?

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.p: So Selindra would have me think, which indeed was the main cause of my anger, and her tears.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I am not willing to be jealous, nor yet so fond, as not to be sensible, when there is just cause; Ordella let us smooth our brows, and observe them farther, such a guilt cannot be long hid, and untill we be confirm'd by some better proof, tis unworthy in us to suspect them on our surmises only, since what they do, is by our direction.

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.p: 'Tis not my nature to judge ill of any, and I hope Selindra will deserve better; I am converted, and now we are thus secure, why may not you go to the Army, and leave Selindra with me▪ Pollidor in your absence, may Court her in Publick, which will confirm my Father in his mistake, when he sees me dislike it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I like it well Ordella: what will you do this Evening?

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.p: I have some business for a while; Selindra after supper will meet me in the Garden, pray come to us there.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Bid your Boy attend us with his Lute then, it may so happen that I must take leave this night, for I hear that the Hungarian Army comes on apace.

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.p:
The Emperour sends you word Sir, that
Cecropius has deliver'd all the Frontier Towns unto the Hungarians, and himself advances in the head of that Army towards us.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Dispatch a Post unto Antillacus, bid him advance towards the Traitor, I will this night set forth, and by day-break shall reach him.

sp.speaker: Ante.
sp.p: Sir, Antillacus retreats before the Enemy, his men fewer in Number, are so disheartned by Cecropius's revolt, they dare not look on the Hungarians.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Let the Page call Pollidor to my Sisters Chamber presently, we will take leave there, and depart immediately; Come Ordella, this is somewhat quicker work then I expected; bid my servants make what hast they can to meet me here at my return.
sp.stage: Enter Periander with a Lady, as in Ordella's Chamber.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: My Lord, since you went hence, the Court has been in daily Tumults about Phillocles his Love unto your Daughter.

sp.speaker: Perian.
sp.p: Is Selindra so much in favour with the Gods, as to be look'd on by Prince Phillocles?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: The Prince seeks no other Heaven but her, and as the World thinks she neglects him, and Loves one Pollidor.

sp.speaker: Perian.
sp.p: Madam, I cannot raise my Faith to what you say, nor can I joy in such a blessing, until I know the Emperour does approve it; pray Madam, where may I find Selindra?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: She is now with the Princess in the Garden, I shall let her know your Lordship is return'd.

sp.speaker: Perian.
sp.p: You obliege me Madam;—though [Exit Lady. I have been long absent, I have not been idle, nor could I well have made more hast hither, confidering how many great Affairs I have dispatch'd, since I went hence.

sp.speaker: Selin.
sp.p: Oh Sir! You are welcome, I have with some trouble, and some fear expected your Return.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.p: Madam, I stay'd the longer by reason of those Tumults I found at Belgrade, a false Astella was set up by Euticus and his faction, but so soon as I made known that you Liv'd, both sides laid down their Arguments though not their Armes, which I advis'd as the best means to bring you home in safety.

sp.speaker: Selin.
sp.p: But why does our Army enter Greece?

sp.speaker: Perian.
sp.p: That's the riddle Madam, the old Fox Cecropius gave notice to the Hungarians, that Lascares purpos'd in his own person to invade them, since Phillocles had refus'd it, and would by a conquest joyn that Crown to his Empire; he insinuates also, that if the Hungarians would assist him in his design, he would make Lascares unable to harm them, by delivering up all the Frontier Towns into their hands.

sp.speaker: Selin.
sp.p: And what is his design?

sp.speaker: Perian.
sp.p: Onely by their power to force Lascares to deliver you, and one Pollidor up to him: This I perswaded Orsanes, and the rest to harken too, and my long stay was to see the Towns deliver'd to Orsanes, which is done, and Cecropius fooll'd by his vaine hopes, Marches in the head of your Army, which comes on apace, only to receive your Commands Madam.

sp.speaker: Selin.
sp.p:
The Gods reward you, for I never can;—but here is Newes Seriander beyond what you tell; Pollinesso Lives, Lives here under the name of Pollidor;
[Enter Pollidor. and see where he comes;—Oh! my Brother we are happy above our wish; this is Periander, who has so much obliged me.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I hope I shall live to thank you Sir.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.p: Sir, I am rewarded in the good I have done, if my services do prove such in your Esteem.

sp.speaker: Selin.
sp.p: My Brother, you must dispatch Periander back unto the Army to give Orsanes and the rest notice that you live;—Cecropius has rendred the Towns, and comes on demanding to have me deliver'd to his lust.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p:
We shall order him at leisure, our care to inform Orsanes must indeed be speedy;—Periander, though I cannot command, I may intreat you that know our Affairs to return unto Orsanes, and give him notice that I intend this night to set forth with Phillocles, and will come over to him, with my first opportunity; bid him march fairly through the Country, and take heed that Antillacus
ingage him not to fight till I Arrive; if you ride hard, you may be back with us, before we part from hence, for I hear Cecropius is not far off.

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.p: By my speed Sir, judge my Zeal to serve you.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p:
As you passe by my Lodgings, pray send all my servants to attend me in the next Room, from hence we shall take Horse this Evening;—Now
[Exit Periander. Astella, methinks the Gods do smile on Hungary▪ and on us; if Ordella would be gracious Pollinesso were most happy; How does my love prosper, Astella?

sp.speaker: Selin.
sp.p: I can make no certain Judgement on it yet.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: Canst thou not procure me one smile before we part?

sp.speaker: Selin.
sp.p: 'T will not be possible, if you depart this night; I could wish we had more time, because I now propose some pleasure in my woing for you; methinks the stormes that I have rais'd, look merrily now the calm is certain, and so nigh, I have so light a heart, that I could play with dangers, if any were within my reach.
sp.stage: To them Enters Phillocles, and Ordella, who stand unseen behind them, siting on the Couch.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p:
Let me Embrace and Kisse thee, my Dear, Dear Selindra; thou art so great a Joy unto my
soul, that I lament to part one minute from thee; when we meet next, we shall Embrace more freely.

sp.speaker: Selin.
sp.p: That you must go from me, grieves me;—must you needs go with Phillocles? may you not stay one day longer with me?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I dare not, do not weep thus, thy tears will prove ill Omens, and I become a superstitious fool, to fear I know not why.

sp.speaker: Selin.
sp.p: How can I chuse but lament to part with what is dearer to me then my life; pray do not go this night, bestow this night on me.

sp.speaker: Polli.
sp.p: I swear thou makest me sad, prethee speak more chearfully, and dry thy eyes, least Phillocles perceive thy tears, and Ordella do discover us, and so unmask us both before we be prepar'd.

sp.speaker: Selin.
sp.p: No matter for their jealousie, are not we above the reach of malice now?
sp.stage: Phillocles draws and offering to strike, is held by Ordella.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Not yet Selindra, we may be ere long, till then, 'tis not good to provoke any, it is by your advice to, that we should be still disguis'd.

sp.speaker: Selin.
sp.p: Yes, and tis my opinion still; but when Phillocles is gone who can discover us?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p:
The Gods, who will not suffer such impiety to be longer hid? let me loose Ordella, and I will out these twisted Monsters into Atomes,
that their united souls, may so expire together.
sp.stage: The Women part, and hold them.

sp.speaker: Polli.
sp.p: Why thus inraged Sir?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Canst thou aske false man? we have heard and seen, all that has past between ye.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: It may be so, and yet be mistaken in all you have heard and seen too;—Sir, if you will have alittle patience, your shall see your mistake, and be sorry for this injurious Language, when you know to whom you speak.
sp.stage: Phillocles offers to run at him, but is held by Ordella.

sp.speaker: Selin.
sp.p: Good Madam, perswade the Prince to hear us, and there will be no cause to fight.

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.p: Thou worst of Women, how dares thy lips move towards me?

sp.speaker: Selin.
sp.p: For Heavens sake Madam hear us, you will too late repent this rashness else; we are both Innocent.

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.p: Brother you may do well to hear them and revenge at leasure; pray lay by this anger for a while, and take it up again when you see cause they are in your power to punish as you please.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I thank thee Ordella, they are so;—am tame, and now you may say on.

sp.speaker: Polli.
sp.p:
Sir, if you have heard, and seen what pa •… between us, I do confess you have reason for yo •… anger, and our fondness doth deserve blame, b •…
not death; tis true, that we have negligently shew'd, what we might better have conceal'd; necessity therefore now compells us to discover what we yet meant not to do, that our Innocency may no longer suffer.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Your Innocence.

sp.speaker: Polli.
sp.p: Madam, the Prince his absence gives me opportunity to beg your pardon for Selindra and my self, who have too long hid our affections from you, and our selves also; for she is my Sister, and will ere long appear worthy Phillocles his best thoughts, and I do hope my self, when I shall dare to be my self, may have leave to say, my life is vowed to serve you.

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.p: Sir, you are mistaken, I am not to be deceived by this slight trick;—you would gain time to escape my Brothers vengeance.

sp.speaker: Polli.
sp.p: No Madam, you will shortly see I am above it; and if—

sp.speaker: Phillo.
sp.p: Seize on that Traytor.
sp.stage: Pollidor steps to the other door, and calls alone.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p:
Tenedor, Periander, Tecknor, They Enter, & both parties stand ranged on either side. Treason;—what means this madness Phillocles? a reasonable man should hear another speak; If I do not satisfie all your doubts,
you shall find that I dare meet your fury, and can raise storms as high, as you can wish to see.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Pray unfold this mistery, I do attend you.
sp.stage: Pollidor leads Selindra to Phillocles who steps back from her;—

sp.speaker: Polli.
sp.p: Let this pledge speak for u •… both, for I can have no other interest, then to give her up into your Armes Sir, send your Guards off, and this riddle shall be as easie, and as pleasant, as it now looks hard;—Phillocles will blush when he shall know from whom he flyes, and by whose hand offer'd to him.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I understand you not, nor do I care;—hark, what noyse is this?
sp.stage: Enter the Emperour with his Train, and his Guard, swords drawn, crying Arme, Arme, as they enter.

sp.speaker: Las.
sp.p: What's this? a War within his our own Walls; Phillocles is this a time for private brawls? when the Hungarians are at your Gates?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I am ready to depart Sir; and shall send them back much faster then they now come on. I beg your pardon Sir, for my neglect.

sp.speaker: Las
sp.p: What Newes brings Gillon?

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.p:
Antillacus sends you word Sir, that you must prepare to receive him with the Army under
the Town Walls, his Souldiers have so many pannick fears, he dares not lead them out to •… ace the Enemy; he also wishes that Prince Phillocles would draw out the Court Regimens, to hear •… en his dejected men.

sp.speaker: Las.
sp.p: I think 'twere better to receive them within the Walls, until their shame do out-face their fears; Tell Antillacus my old Armes are on, and that I will my self, strike the Traytor in the face.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Hast back good Gillon, and tell Antillacus; If he can defend his Camp till I Arrive, I wish him not to move this way; my looks will send those ungratefull people •… ome, if not, I have a flame within me, which will consume them all.—I beg your pardon Sir, for my neglect.

sp.speaker: Las.
sp.p: Repair it by your speedy succour, I shall take present order for what the Town can afford us.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Ordella I have a War within, that will consume me.

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.p: I hope this great Affair will divert your thoughts, and remove your trouble.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: For some few dayes it may;—farewel my Dear Sister;—and when I return, you shall hear from me Sir.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p:
I shall not stay behind you Sir, my wound Phillocles is going out. is not so ill, as to keep me from waiting on you;
when this hurry and your anger is over, I hope you will be at leasure to hear me out, and be pleas'd rather to finde you can be mistaken, then me guil •… y.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I will by no means suffer it, 'twill be no charity, to permit you to hazzard Selindra's interest by new dangers.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Sir, your scornes shall have no more power to stay me, then your anger has, I will along.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: But you shall not; I do suspect you will betray me to your Country-Men, and dare not trust you with me.

sp.speaker: Polli.
sp.p: All this will not do, I know you do not doubt me that way? and I do swear, unlesse you break the bonds of Hospitality (and do imprison me) I will along.

sp.speaker: P •… il.
sp.p: And I will rather do it, then have your company, if you desist not.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Phillocles will not so much blemish his great Name! imprison me that sav'd your life;—me, that am vowed to stand or fall with you;—Sir, I must chide you now, you do too long hold up a causelesse anger, you know not why; too long neglect the great Affair that calls you hence;—I will stay no longer for you, but go do the work before you come.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p:
Stay Pollidor, thou hast confounded all my reason, such a mixture of Noblenesse, ne're met with •… uch a Treachery till now; though I do know thee false, and do resolve with my own hand to Kill thee; I will trust thee this way, and
do now intreat thee to stay till to morrow that my Father comes.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I Obey.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Oh! my Dear Sister, once more farewell,
I am now fall'n from Paradice to Hell.

sp.speaker: Ordel.
sp.l: The Gods go with you, and your action bless,
While I retire, and pray for your success:
sp.stage: Exeunt all but Pollidor and Selindra.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: We will be gone Selindra, and face Phillocles in the head of our own Army;—what news Periander?

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.p: Sir, I am come to fetch you to your Army, I can convey you thither, before you are mist here.

sp.speaker: Selindra.
sp.p: We are ready now, how far off is the Army?

sp.speaker: Peri.
sp.p: You may hear their Drums Madam, at the City Gates.

sp.speaker: Pol▪
sp.l: Come, let us hasten to our Troupes;—
When Instruments of War, from War release,
'Tis a good Omen, to a happy peace.
sp.stage: Enter at one Door Lascares, Phillocles, Antillacus, Armanthus, Gillon, and the Grecian Army.
Enter at the other door Cecropi us, Orsanes, and other Lords with the Hungarian Army.

sp.speaker: Lasca.
sp.p:
Thou art a bold ill man Cecropius, thou
art ungrateful to thy Country, and my trust.

sp.speaker: Cecro.
sp.p: Sir, I have but hid my gratitude under this old Armour, which is onely now put on to obtain what my prayers could not,—I demand justice Sir, for Cleonels bloud, which you have hitherto denied me, in favour to his Murtherers:

sp.speaker: Lasc.
sp.p: This fained modesty is more impudent then thy Arms are, thou knowest I was more eager then thy self to do justice on those that slew thy son, and thou seest clearly our Laws cannot touch them for his fall.

sp.speaker: Cecro.
sp.p: Was not Cleonel slain by Pollidor? and was not Selindra accessary? and does not our Laws condemn such murtherers to die?

sp.speaker: Lasc
sp.p: No; thou knowest they do not, thou knowest thy son was by a just hand punish'd, and that Pollidor deserves,—

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Good Sir, spend no more breath on this vile man, the slave is not worthy your anger:——Foolish Hungarians, ingrateful perjur'd people:—Orsanes I did not look for this from you;—but my sword shall speak my vengeance.

sp.speaker: Orsan.
sp.p: Prince Phillocles has not in Greece a more faithful servant then Orsanes; Pray Sir lay by this passion but a few minutes, and you shall see that I have labour'd hard to bring your own desires to their wish'd ends:—and Cecropius the main Agent in it all!

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Why do your actions and your words so disagree? Orsanes knows our Grecian hearts cannot be compell'd, when we have time to draw our swords.

sp.speaker: Orsan.
sp.p: Great Sir, your actions have enough declar'd your worth unto the World, and to our Nation most; which we shall ever own, though now by some necessity compell'd, we do appear as enemies, in the behalf of this good man, who has ingag'd us to deliver up a Lady call'd Selindra, and one Pollidor to his hands, which he by strong arguments assur'd us, would be for your, and for our future happiness: this done, we are all at Phillocles command.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Those two you mention are of late become unworthy of my thoughts; yet your engagement was barbarous, to undertake you know not what:—sound the charge.

sp.speaker: Orsan.
sp.p: Hold Phillocles, I have entertain'd you with discourse thus long, only till I might hear that shout behind [a shout within▪ us:—hark, hark, Sir! Now the time is come for us to keep our oaths to Cecropius, and to manifest our love to Phillocles,—make way there for the King.
sp.stage: The Hungarian Army opens, and through them enters Pollinesso crown'd, leading in Astella; Orsanes | delivers them both unto Cecropius.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: What Riddle's this? what wonders do I see?

sp.speaker: Cecro.
sp.p:
Take away that shadow of a King to present death, Orsanes; and now Selindra you are once more at my dispose: and you Sir, that think
you can command the World, shall find this weak old arm can justifie my title here.

sp.speaker: Orsan.
sp.p: Have I now perform'd my oath unto the great Cecropius?

sp.speaker: Cecro.
sp.p: You have.

sp.speaker: Orsan.
sp.p: I must then set this Lady free from the danger of our swords,—

sp.speaker: Orsan.
sp.p: Long live the King of Hungary.

sp.speaker: Cecro.
sp.p: I am betrayed.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Pollidor! and Selindra! why is he crown'd! how come they there?

sp.speaker: Lasc.
sp.p: They are confederates with Cecropius, on which design they have thus long liv'd amongst us.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: Orsanes, lay that Monster at his Masters feet.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Pollidor, what mean these misteries?

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: All respects to Phillocles.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p:
How comes Selindra then with thee? and that Crown upon thy head? I tell thee Pollidor, if Selindra can neglect me, I can contemn her; and not envy thee that mis-becoming Crown thou wearest, which I will tear from off thy swelling
brows, and trample on it, when 'tis mine by a second conquest.
sp.stage: Pollidor leads Selindra to Phillocles, and he retires.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: —Will Phillocles forsake the List? fly from such a foe! send for the Princess Ordella then, that we may meet on equall terms.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: You are merry Sir, my gentle temper I see, begets contempt from your great courage.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: No, Sir, you are mistaken still, I am your servant, and do value Phillocles, more then he can contemn me:—Orsanes, bring my Standard hither:—carry this and my Crown unto the Princess Ordella; lay them at her feet, and if she dains to take them up, tell her your King with his whole people do wait on her Commands.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: I understand not what these Riddles mean.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: If Phillocles be yet at leasure to hear me speak, I shall soon remove this wonder?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: If Pollidor prove worthy, I shall not trust my eyes nor ears for ever.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: But when Prince Phillocles shall know that Pollinesso speaks, he will believe no hand has more right to deliver up Astella into his arms, then I: Do you not know me yet Sir?
sp.stage: He pulls off his Perriwig, and his patch from his eye.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Nor yet know my self:—Antillacus, do I wake? or is this a Phantosm that I think I see?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis as strange to me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lasc.
sp.p: While my sons wonder lasts, let me embrace you, Sir, and obtain both yours and Astellas pardon, and chide you both in the same breath; why did you suffer us to walk so long in this unhappy darkness? and run so many hazards, which this light would have avoided.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: There was no other way to obtain this light, while Cecropius eclips'd your glory Sir.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: Does Pollinesso live? can he forget my crimes? and forgive my blindness!

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: Can Phillocles pardon my concealment •… by which he was so blinded?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: There is but one happiness on earth beyond holding Pollinesso thus!

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: To me too there can be only one above it!—and that is Ordellas leave to love her:—but Sir▪ have you no room for Selindra in your heart?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: I dare not look that way: I dare not have a hope so high as pardon from her.—I am so full of guilt, that I dare not live longer to think of my unworthiness.

sp.speaker: Selind.
sp.p: What have I done Sir, that you should be thus cruel to me! will you not look on me?

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: I shall blush to death, if you speak thus again.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: Will Phillocles turn from me ever?

sp.speaker: Phill
sp.p: Yes, Madam, as asham'd to look on you; I have a guilt within, that takes my manhood from me!—shall I dare to think you can forgive my unworthy jealousie?

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: If you can forgive me that provok'd you to it? I can meet you thus.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p: And I fall as low as earth will let me, to receive your pardon.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: I am so much amaz'd at what I see, that I know not which way to turn me!

sp.speaker: Lasc.
sp.p: This way, Ordella, if you will by me be guided to felicity?—this is Pollinesso's wish too, if I mistake not.

sp.speaker: Pollin.
sp.p: 'Tis my ambition Sir, my highest hope on this side Heaven.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: And my honour, that Pollinesso has such thoughts for me; but Sir, 'twill ask some time for me to raise my wishes to such a value of your worth, that we may meet on equal terms.

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.p:
Pollinesso's merit, and his worth is such,
that when he says he loves, 'tis argument enough to gain the greatest Queen:—Ordella, the Gods smile upon us now:—and you, Sir, I hope concur with Heaven in our felicities.

sp.speaker: Lasc.
sp.p: My prayers and my blessings shall not be wanting: let Pollinesso give sentence on Cecropius before we go unto the Temple.

sp.speaker: Pollin.
sp.p: Let him live for ever banish'd from this happy Climate, which he has so long polluted with his venomous breath.

sp.speaker: Lasc.
sp.p: Antillacus see it done.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: Madam, can you pardon my disguise?

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.p: I cannot well tell what to answer! to find Selindra worthy, is a Concern greater then Astella can be to me; and that you now are Astella, does not more raise my wonder, then that you were Selindra does confirm my love, and my respects to you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: I have a heart too full of joy to keep this distance any longer!

sp.speaker: Phill.
sp.l: We now lose time that might be better spent,
In sacrificing for this blest event!

sp.speaker: Lasc.
sp.l: Lead on then to the Temple, and proclaim
A publick feast, in bright Astella's name;
While we do march in a triumphant state,
That all the City may participate
Our joys, now Phillocles captivity
Is chang'd into a triple Victory.

div.p: LONDON, Printed by T. Mabb; for John Playfere at the VVhite Lion, in the Upper Walk of the New Exchange; And Thomas Horsman, at the three Kings in the Strand, 1665.

list.item: Ormasdes, Her General, a Prince of Greece.
Embassadour, From Valeriana King of Treconia.

div.head: ORMASDES.
THE FIRST ACT.
THE SCENE In the Island of Citherea.
div.stage: Enter Menetius, and Nearcus; A Messenger meets them.

sp.speaker: MESSENGER.
sp.l: MY Lords, the Queen sends me to let you know.
That she is safe, and her whole Fleet secure.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: The Queens safety, is welcome News to all,
Though from the Castle top, we saw the fight;
None could so clearly the success discern;
As to rejoyce for her security!
Till you are arriv'd.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: Twas bold, & bravely done, with less numbers
To Assault so great a Fleet, so near home!
I wonder how they got Intelligence?
So just, to know the Queens return from Greece.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: To Assault us, was far from their design;
They fell by chance amongst our Ships ith' night,
As they were passing by; found us secure,
And unprepar'd for such an accident:
So we together sail'd, till Day appear'd;
Then our great Admirall, and his brave Son,
With their two Squadrons, did begin the Fight:
—The Queens Ship was attacqued on every side,
In which, Ormasdes by the Gods was plac'd,
That by his hand, Cleandra might be freed,
As by a Miracle! her dangers such!
And his Achievements so beyond them all!
That my Relation, 'would Romance appear,
To tell you, how he acted every where.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: I hope this accident, will now perswade
The Queen, that she no more such journies make:
Great Princes to such visits and not bound,
Where Complements do so great danger bring.

sp.speaker: Near.
sp.l: Though Cleandras visit, may not admit
Of a State Argument to justifie
A danger;—She had reason to return
Some high respect, unto the Grecian Court,
Where she so long, in so great splendor liv'd;
Before she had this Citherean Crown:
Nor was it now amiss to shew the Power,
And Glory, of so great a Fleet, as Greece
Ne're saw before! by which, our renew'd League
Will be more valu'd, and our Nation fear'd.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: I have no Argument for a dispute;
—This visit past, she needs no other make;
But Sir, how comes Ormasdes here again?
What great Affair, occasions his return?

sp.speaker: Near.
sp.l: How can the Grecian Empire so long spare,
So great a Captain? and so much belov'd.

sp.speaker: Messen.
sp.l: That happy Emperour; who has no War,
Did give Ormasdes liberty once more,
To grant Cleandras sute for his return,
That he may now confirm, what he has won,
Least his late Trophies in the Zelnian War,
Be tumbled down! for we may doubt! those Kings
Who border Zelnia, will not long indure
Such loss; as will Cleandras Crown secure.
Though her great Ancestor that Kingdom won,
And left it to his most unhappy Son;
Who all those Princes Tributaries made,
That in Affection call'd him to their Aide.

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: Heark Nearcus, heark how the People shout!
As if the Queen were now, come near the shore;
Pray Sr. cōmand the Guards advance with speed,
Unto the Port; Nearcus I do fear,
The Queen may land, while we are trifling here.
sp.stage: Enter Cleandra Queen of Citherea, Ormasdes a Prince of Greece. Her General with his Arme in a Scarfe Old Titus Admiral, Young Titus, Lords, Ladies, and Train.

sp.speaker: Admi.
sp.l: The Gods have given you a full Victory,
And all your Fleet will be in Port, by Noon.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: I have thank'd the Gods Titus, and do fee
Yours, and your Sons mirits, in this great work:
But have not words that can express my thanks
To brave Ormasdes, for preserving me;
Had you seen my danger, when the bold Turks
With assured Victory, my Labin forc't!
And how by his hand from that Ruine freed!
You would with me admire, if not adore
The force which Rescued, with so great a Power!
My fear, my wonder, and my joy, so mixt,
I had no time for any thought betwixt
My danger, and my safe deliverance,
Which did the Price of that great work inhance!
The bloody Trophies of Ormasdes sword;
Surpas'd what Mars to Hector did afford.
sp.stage: Ormasdes faints, and leans on Young Titus.

sp.speaker: Adm.
sp.l: He faints, this remove to Land, makes him
—How do you Sir?

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: My soul Titus, shrunk away, much asham'd,
To hear my service by Cleandra fam'd,
To much for any modest man to own,
That my weak Arm, should rescue her alone!

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: I am amaz'd, thus suddainly to find
The Gods so cruel, who have been so kind!
Thus to Eclips the joyes they freely gave,
Shews they repent the mercy which did save;
Ormasdes death will now so dismall be,
I cannot sacrifice for Victory.
Unless the Fates this mischief do divert!
It will our Triumphs, into Tears convert.

sp.speaker: Y. Tit.
sp.l: -His wounds shew not the danger you con
Madam, you Prophesie so great an ill, (ceive;
The Fates themselves will tremble to fulfill.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: I am well Madam, only blush to hear,
That my slight wounds, should be so much your
If great (leandra, do mean Acts admire, (care
Brave men will not to high Attemps aspire.
sp.stage: Enter to them, Nearcus, Cleobulus, and Cithareans, they Kiss Cleandras hand, a noyse of joy within from the People.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Madam, the Publick joy for your return,
Does shew how much we did your absence mourn.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: My Peoples joy brings me great happiness,
And your love my Lords, my true value has:
But still I must your gratitudes, direct
Unto Ormasdes, by whose powerfull hand,
Cleandra was preserv'd, and now restor'd. (don,

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Madam, you reward my small endeavors
With praise above, the merrit of a man!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: I can afford Ormasdes as much Worth,
And Honour, as the Antient Heroes had,
So he will me such gratitude allow,
As s •… tes with my great benefits receiv'd;—
—What Fleet Nearcus, lies within our Port?

sp.speaker: Near.
sp.l: 'Tis from Treconia Madam, here's Arriv'd
A brave Embassadour, from that great King,
Who here has long expected your return;
His Equipage is Rich, and with him shines,
A Lady he calls Sister; hither come,
To wonder at the Glories of your Court,
While we do all admire, their Princely Port!
