sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: He shall have present Audience, to excuse
His •… ong attendance; give him a respect:
Beyond the reach, or thought of a neglect;
—Do you Nearcus, bring him to us now;—
—Cleobulus, what news from Zelnia?

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.l: The frontiers have been frequently attaqu'd,
Since you went hence, but no great damage done.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.p: I beg the Honour Madam to chastise those haughty Rebells, for their Insolence.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: The whole world knows, Ormasdes can cōmand
The fortune of a war; why then should you?
As if your Name were yet obscure! desire
New dangers? But you covet a Renown,
Beyond the value of the Zelnian Crown;
Else, you'd secure my People from their fear,
By your consent to be my Vice-Roy there.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Such proffer'd gifts from Princes are not us'd
To be molested, and much less refus'd!

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: But I must not your Majesty permit,
To load me with an honour so unfit!
As will Eclips the merrit you allow,
When gifts shine brighter, then my Actions do.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Is there no way Ormasdes to remove
These niceties? must I for ever own
Your benefits? and make you no return!
How little do I seem to your great Eye?
Who scorn I should your service gratifie.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: I have in Greece, all my relations left,
To serve you Madam, and am hither come,
With a fixt zeal to wish, and to obey,
What ever you command! and only fear
My inclinations may my tongue direct,
To beg what you'l deny: though I affect.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Though I your sute dislike, I will consent,
And from your happiness, raise my content.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: With your permission Madam, I would beg
Leave to retire unto the little Lodge,
Within the Forrest, half a League from hence,
Where after all my Travells, I may find,
Ease for my body, and refresh my mind,
With the soft solace of a private life,
Free from Affairs, and Courts Eternal strife.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: This is far beyond my fears Ormasdes!
Tis no wonder you my favours slight!
When you do our society dislike.
But I will not your purpose now oppose,
Though I your councils, & your frindship lose;
Who in debates can speak; in fight command,
And order all, that in disorder stand;—
—Can nothing alter your desire from this?

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Not unless, troubles be prefer'd to bliss.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Ormasdes it shall be as you desire,
And freely, when you please, you may retire.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Though I a while absent my self from Court,
I shall be ready to lay by my Books,
When you do call me to put Armour on,
Stories tell that great men the like have don.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Though I know no example, I believe
What e're Ormasdes shall make choice to do,
May be a president, that will ingage
Brave men to follow, in the future age. (content

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Your Majesty in this, has given me more
Then all the favours proffer'd me before.

sp.speaker: Y. Tit.
sp.l: Is this his humour? or some fancy grown
From passion for some Love, to us unknown;

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: No Titus, he has ever been observ'd,
A great contemner of Amores, and does
True friendship more esteem, then idle Love.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: The more like now to be so much concern'd
When touch'd; our mortal bodies are so frail,
That we may love, and know not what we ail!
Why, does your Majesty think friendship can
With as much force as love, transport a man?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Not to such frensies, as wild brains Create,
When fancy cannot change the course of Fate—
—When love to faces, with the face decay,
A virtuous friendship will for ever sway.—
—I wish you Titus, when he first retires,
To try how far your friendship can prevail,
To get the secret from Ormasdes soul;
Tis for his good, that he his griefs impart;
True friendship will allow a little Art,
When the design does nothing more import,
But bringing of Ormasdes back to Court.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: I shall be joy'd, and happy if I can
Bring back to Court! so Excellent a Man.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: The Embassadour attends your Majesty.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Admit Him.

sp.speaker: Embas.
sp.l: Madam, my Master, the Treconian King,
Salutes you in these Letters, and by me,
Congratulates your Zelnian Victory;
But does lament, that he no share acquir'd,
In that great Conquest, he so much desir'd:
He was ambitious Madam, to command
In that near War, and not as neuter stand.
When strangers merits do such Triumphs claim,
While he to you unknown, sat still with shame.
But since Ormasdes conduct, and his skill,
With such high Valour, has fulfill'd your will.
He envies not so great a Souldiers praise,
But would have shar'd in his Triumphant rayes.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: If I had known Valerianus mind,
He might my thanks have shar'd, and not repin'd.

sp.speaker: Emb.
sp.l: I have commission also, to propose
A League between your Kingdoms, & your selves,
Such, as new Conquer'd Zelnia will secure,
That Cithereas peace may long endure.—
—Your beauty Madam, more then Crowns invite,
Valerians wishes to unite
Your hearts; and then, your Scepters may
Be doubly fixt, when both do love obey.
He begs, that he in person may appear,
To plead his love, and treat this great affair.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Valerianus friendship I approve,
But never shall consent to treat of love;
'Twould raise my dead Lords Ashes in his Urn,
If I should to a second Lover turn?
Your great Kings proffer'd League, I do imbrace,
With fit Affection, and a chearful face:—
Declairing to the World, how I respect,
His person, though I must his sute reject.

sp.speaker: Emb.
sp.l: I shall acquaint my Master,—and beg leave
I may your Majesties commands receive,
Without the Ceremonies that belong,
To a State audience, in a formal throng.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: You shall have free access, as you desire,
And now my Lord, I must a Sutor be,
That fair Mariana will appear,
Who I am told is come to visit me. (quest,

sp.speaker: Emb.
sp.l: That Madam, should have been my next re
That you my dearest Sister would permit,
To kiss your hand, who does attend without.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Will you Ormasdes please to bring her in?—
—If I had known that she had been so near,
She had been better treated for your sake.

sp.speaker: Emb.
sp.l: You oblige me Madam.
sp.stage: Enter Ormasdes, with Mariana and her Ladies; the Queen Salutes Her.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: You do me, and my Country, honour more,
Then any Lady ever did before.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: I have done my self a favour Madam,
And tis your Majesty that honours me;
The fame of Citherea I confess,
May Princes hither bring, but my address,
Is •… o Cleandras self, that I might see,
The virtue fam'd for such Divinitie.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Madam, if you such flatteries throw out,
You will your welcome spoil, and make me doubt
You rather come to mock, then to admire!
On such another word? I shall retire.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: I can be silent Madam, while I live,
But m •… st speak truth, when you this freedom give.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: We then will change our argument, & place,
Least I do chide, whom I intend to grace.
sp.stage: Exeunt all but Nearcus and Cleobulus.

sp.speaker: Cleob.
sp.l: Did you observe, with what forc'd modesty
The Embassadour supprest his anger?
When his Masters sute, so briskly was denied.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: Yes, and how suddain his sad looks change,
When bright Cleandra did so soon admit
His private visits; as if himself were struck!
And did no further press his Masters Sute.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I have other thoughts, that made me believe,
The Lady he calls Sister, is his Love.

sp.speaker: Near.
sp.l: Such things have been, and Mariana may
His Mistris be; whose beauty in my Eye,
Does far surpass Cleandras Majesty.
And now you put these thoughts into my head,
I did observe Marianus eyes and his,
Did a long practiz'd silent language shew,
While they by turns did entertain the Queen.

sp.speaker: Cleob.
sp.l: But I had second thoughts, led me to think,
I did sometimes perceive Marianas eyes,
On brave Ormasdes fixt; and seem'd to take
Such a survey, as Purchasers do make.

sp.speaker: Near.
sp.l: I doubt Mariana has not an estate,
To purchas •… him, at great Cleandras rate.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Let us observe them better next, and see
If it be Art; or their simplicitie.

sp.speaker: Emb.
sp.l: I have undone my self, Mariana!
For now beyond resistance I do love;
And find Cleandra will by her neglects,
Dash all my hopes, and turn from my respects,

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: There does not a just cause to me appear,
For such a doubt; much less to raise dispair:
Because Cleandra runs not at first sight,
Into the arms, of such a wandring Knight.
Though your State Arguments cannot procure
To Treat; she may but a short Siege indure,
When as your self, a King you do appear,
The Castle may be won, by love, or fear.

sp.speaker: Emb.
sp.l: No Mariana, I have heard, and seen
Too much, the brave Ormasdes stands between
Me, and my happiness, his retirement
Is to cloak their close love, and to prevent
Pretenders; or such scandal, as would rise,
If openly in Court, without disguise!
Such unproportion'd love should ere be known,
Which shews they dare not their affections own.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: What nee •… such dissēbling? to hide that love,
Which all the Cithereans do approve;
And publickly do pray, his great Renown,
Might be rewarded with Cleandras Crown.
To publick fame, I therefore credit give,
They not in love, but in true friendship live.

sp.speaker: Em
sp.l: Such friendship between man, & woman, may
'Mongst silly people make a holy day.
No Callenders of mine, shall ere admit
Of a red Letter, for a counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: The Gods defend Brother.

sp.speaker: Emb.
sp.l: Why Mariana? what is your concern?
To blush, because we do their crimes discern!
Can you believe, that a Platonick flame,
Has power to Cannonize Cleandras Name?

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: I blush for you, who now so boldly dare,
Against the person that you love! declar •… .

sp.speaker: Emb.
sp.l: Your words, and looks, do not at all agree,
But shame for your Ormasdes infamie.
He is the man in Marianas eye,
Whose blushes, would his vices justifie.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Though I his virtues honour, and admire
The glorious Actions of his life, my heart,
Is not in any danger to be lost.

sp.speaker: Emb.
sp.l: When a heart is so well lost Mariana!
'Twill soon be found, I did believe my own,
As fast fixt as yours, and yet at first sight,
Of the fair Queen, 'twas from its center forc'd.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: I Brother, your business was to lose it.

sp.speaker: Emb.
sp.l: But the blind Deity considers not
Our purposes he wounds at randome still;—
—I wish thou wouldst ingeniously confess,
If in thy thoughts; Ormasdes be not grown
The handsomest and gallantest of Men;
Whose famous actions, in our western World,
May well excuse thy wonder, and thy Love;—
—I wish thy beauties could his heart ingage,
That I might have no Rival for the Queen.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: To oblige my dear brother, I will try,
What may be done, for your security.

sp.speaker: Emb.
sp.l: Thy whole life, never can oblige me more;
—Ormasdes is a great Prince in Greece,
And I for thee, will make him greater yet,
By my additions in Treconia;
If you can think him worthy of your Love?
—Our forces joyn'd, may double conquest gain,
When seve'rd; both indeavours may prove vain.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: While you talk thus, I had as good confess:
What you so much believe, and do allow,
I gladly would obtain, if I knew how.

sp.speaker: Emb.
sp.l: That was well said, let us to Councel then—
Suppose I Court the Queen in my own shape?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I think tis best that you do first inquire,
How far the subtle Queen does stand ingaged
Unto Ormasdes, that you may not kneele
To her, if she unto another bow?

sp.speaker: Emb.
sp.l: It will not be amiss, that I inquire,
Of some great man in power, who I may bribe:—
Such as Cleandras trust does most admit,
To plead my Masters cause, and argue it:—
—What if I first Ormasdes self do try?
Twill search his love, and his fidelity.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: I am not fit to judge, nor can advise;
But will with prayers, assist your enterprize.

sp.speaker: Emb.
sp.l: I'le visit him, and if he guilty be,
I shall confound his great securitie.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: I fear you sooner will your self destroy,
Then by your furious passions him anoy.

sp.speaker: Emb.
sp.l: Will you go with me to Ormasdes Lodge?
Least I disturb his solitary Soul,
And with my rude breath, harm the man you love.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: I'de rather be the subject of your mirth,
Then gr •… at Ormasdes should such rage discern,
As from your Arguments will soon arise.

sp.speaker: Emb▪
sp.l: No, I'le approach him with my gentle looks,
As calm, and smoath, as Virgins when they smile,
Such as our tender yielding hearts beguile;

Bu •…
•… f Ormasdes do a lover prove!
He will my hopes and fears to anger move;—
—Do you attend the Queen, till my return.
sp.stage: Enter Ormasdes, a Book in his hand, as talking to Young Titus.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: I never liv'd, till now you think me dead—
Does my dear friend believe, what I have said?

sp.speaker: Y. Tit.
sp.l: Sir, if the friendship you allow, be more
Then an Airie name? you will now permit
That I as freely speak, as I do love.

sp.speaker: Orm
sp.l: Titus friendship would have honored Cato,
And now my self am prouder of advise
From Titus, then for all my victories.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: Thus then Cleandra thinks, and so do I,
This loneness will your sorrows multiply;
Passions conceal'd, do nourish discontent,
But if reveal'd, much mischief may prevent:
Tis my ambition to obtain this trust,
If great Ormasdes thinks I dare be just.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: By all our—I know no discontent,
Nor has my quiet brest a passion in't.—

sp.speaker: Titus
sp.l: Hold Ormasdes, hear me out; who now come
To let you know, that I, and many more
Who love you, do believe that you repine,
Because Cleandra is so much reserv'd;
And dare not own the passion that you have.
—If this be your trouble, trust it to me;
And you shall soon perceive, what I can do,
In satisfaction to your highest wish:
—I do so far incourage, and assure,
What I have mentioned; Is the Nations hope;

Who pray that grea •…
Cleandra may comp'y
In all, that will Ormasdes satisfie
Thus my affection, has my heart exprest,
And I expect an answer I may trust.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: What you have uttered Titus; I believe,
And scorn to think such friendship, can deceive.
By the same sacred tye, I you conjure,
To credit me, who seriously do vow.
I only chose this solitary life,
To ease my body, and repose my mind;
I have no passion, nor do grief sustain,
Nor have a wish beyond Cleandras smile,
And Titus friendship; which I'le near beguile.

sp.speaker: Titus.
sp.l: Sir, I am bound to credit what you say,
And shall no more endeavour by discourse,
To alter such well grounded purposes:
But must we never hope •… or your return?
To Court? where you with the same freedom may
Enjoy what private hours you can desire,
And not thus put the World so wholly off;
Which surely was, with all its glories made,
For use of man, and its felicities
To be by us injoyed; without a crime.

sp.speaker: Ormas
sp.l: Yes Titus, but we vain men mistake,
And from our fickle Infancy propose,
Glittering felicities we never find,
For as we grow up to the injoyments
Of what riper years bring with them, we see
That our desires do daily higher grow
And our fruitions but foundations lay,
T' entertain our busie brains, a new way.
So that we seldome contentation have,
In what we do possess; but forward look,
And only find some pleasure in the way,
Towards the end we aime at; which obtain'd,
Brings not those real joyes, we did expect;
Only affords some relish which invites
Our idle fancies, to seek new delights;
—How unhappy then, is our best happiness?
When no fruitions, can our fond hearts bless.
Still subject to unsatisfied desires,
That from quench'd Ashes, does beget new Fires.
Thus all our Appetites, do make us slaves,
And from our cradles lead us to our graves.

sp.speaker: Young Titus.
sp.l: Has the Gods only given us active souls?
And no objects, fit for them to fix on?

sp.speaker: Orma.
sp.l: To think on those Gods, will afford our hearts,
A full variety, of lasting joyes;
VVith which our earthly fancies cannot mix,
VVhen on Coelestial happiness, we fix.

sp.speaker: Titus.
sp.l: I shall e're long, this argument revive,
And shew, how you are buried alive!
Where is that valor, and that virtue gon?
Whither that courage fled? I doated on.
Though you can passion, and desire sustain,
You must not quit the Court, as if disdain
Of all the glories that a Court can give,
Could not perswade you there again to live.
—I must now leave you to attend the Queen;—

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: A clearer virtue I have never seen.
sp.stage: Enter the Queen, Embassador, Mariana, Old Titus, and Train.

sp.speaker: Embassador.
sp.l: Madam, shall I return without a hope?
No gratious answer to my Masters sute!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: My Lord, I fully have declar'd, that way.

sp.speaker: Embassador.
sp.l: Never to marry Madam!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Tis my opinion now.

sp.speaker: Embassador.
sp.l: Will you permit my Master to appear?
Whose person may bring Arguments to prove,
It necessary to allow his Love.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: By no means my Lord, I shall not admit
His visit, if he come on that affair!
But must against his coming now declare.

sp.speaker: Embass.
sp.l: How can you Madam, thus declare against
A person, and a passion you see not?
Or prejudge, what you will think hereafter!
His presence, may change this severity.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: I have consider'd all that can be said,
Urge it no more.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Brother,-Sir,-what do you ail? what strange looks
Do you put on? you will be discovered!

sp.speaker: Emba.
sp.l: I Mariana, tis now my business,
To try if this Scene changing, may not change
Cleandras stubborn heart; when she shall see
This borrow'd habit, thrown away; if then,
She scorn my Love! I will break off the League
And in my own Right will a VVar declare,
For her so lately conquer'd Zelnian Crown,
And there will try, if her conceal'd Gallant!
The great Ormasdes may once more be drawn
From Sanctuary, to defend her Right,
From my just rage;—I will now visit him.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: This humour is not fit for complement,

sp.speaker: Emb.
sp.l: Fear not Mariana, I'le not wrangle now,
My business is to bribe that mighty man,
And make him plead my cause to the fair Queen,
—But if I find him rotten at the heart!
I shall unmask him, spite of all his Art.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: That is what I fear.

div.head: THE SECOND ACT.
div.stage: Enter the Embassadour, with Ormasdes, who holds a Book in his hand, they sit on Chairs by a Table.

sp.speaker: ORMASDES.
sp.l: YOur Lordship by this visit, honours me;
Emb My visit brings you business of the State,
You must not take it for a Complement.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: What is your business then?

sp.speaker: Emb.
sp.l: I have observed Ormasdes, the Queens sence,
Is yours, in her Affairs of Consequence,
She moves by you; this brings me to consult
My Masters Marriage, for a full result!
For I conceive Valerianus Name
Of so great Credit! and so high a Fame!
That our two Nations, by our Princes joyn'd;
Though our surrounding neighbors were cōbind,
Our Territories would be safe, and we
Should thank the Gods for such Tranquilitie.
But when a Lady Rules, they may presume,
And their Rebellious Principles assume;
If great Ormasdes shall be call'd away,
And fair Cleandra left alone to sway.

sp.speaker: Ormasdes
sp.l: I know Sir, that Cleandra does esteem
The stout Treconians friendship, as she ought;
And I know she honours your brave young King,
Whose martial acts, have gain'd him through the
A character so noble, and so great! (world,
That she with joy this proffer'd League, does treat.
Onely dislikes the Marriage you propose
On good State Arguments, as I suppose,
In judgement, and affection to her Son,
She will not raise a Rival to his Crown.
And for her angry Neighbours, she believes
The late Zelnian war, has such wisdome taught,
They will not suddainly, unurg'd, provoke,
A Queen, so powerfull, and so fortunate.

sp.speaker: Embassador.
sp.l: Suppose Valerianus take offence?
And look on this neglect as an affront!
Because he only did propose this League,
To introduce his sute, which he conceives,
VVill both our Nations equally advance;
But if laid by with scorn! suppose he then,
Do joyn with your old Enemies? and claim
His Fathers Title to the Zelnian Crown;
VVhat may the hazzards? and the issue be?
If a new war, dispute your Victory?

sp.speaker: Ormasdes.
sp.l: I will not Prophecy the sad event,
That so unjust a war, may justly bring
Upon so Gallant, and so wise a King!

sp.speaker: Embass.
sp.l: Suppose then, that I have his Commission?
To •… ay by the Treaty of this new League,
Untill the Marriage be agreed unto;
And if deni'd! I must Proclaim his Right
To Zelnia; and your late Conquest bring,
To a new question, with a Powerfull King.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: If Valerianus be so fixt, we must
No h •… zzards fear, in wars that are so just.

sp.speaker: Embass.
sp.l: Your great success have high thoughts begot,
Above your Conquest, which I value not?
But wish such evils as we now foresee,
May be avoided by our industry;
For 'twill become your Wisdom, and your Trust,
T'advise Cleandra to this happy Match,
Wherein if you prevail! I have full power,
Now to confer on you, the first, and best
Of our Treconian Principalities.

sp.speaker: Ormas
sp.l: You do me wrong, and are in this unjust,
To think that I will break Cleandras trust,
Which I do value 'bove your Masters Crown!
And therefore boldly will advise the Queen
Not to admit his sute, on Arguments
Which must an evil consequence produce
To her Sons Right, if she Comply,
And by it lessen her own Dignity.

sp.speaker: Embass.
sp.l: If my imployment, anger did allow,
And my own Honour would permit, to strike
A-Book-man! this rude language, I'de correct.

sp.speaker: Orm.
sp.l: If the Queens honour were not more concern'd!
In a respect to your imployment due;
You soon should find, how little I do value you!
The Book-man would not from your Master take
This Insolence; but for Cleandras sake
I do forbear; pray visit me no more.

sp.speaker: Embassador.
sp.l: Fear it not; when Valerianus knows
How little worth, Cleandras honour is!
He will this League, and her Alliance scorn;
Who puts Ormasdes into this Disguise,
To hide her Lover from her Peoples Eyes?

sp.speaker: Ormasdes.
sp.l: This is beyond sufferance.
sp.stage: Enter The Queen, Young Titus, and Train, who part them.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Hold Ormasdes, I heard his Insolence—
—Sir, you have leave to go aboard your Fleet,
Where you only can be safe; begon then,
Without reply be gone; for if't be known!
What you have said! my People may revenge
My wrong, before your Master do me right.—
—Ormasdes you must in this, my will obey,
Your wonted Judgement, must your passion sway:
While I by a quick war, with Fire and Sword,
Require such Justice as he must afford.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Madam, the Conduct of that war I beg;

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: If you this passion will lay by till then!
You shall: But no more of this anger now;
I came to take the Ayre this After-noon,
But will defer it, till another day.
—Pray be pacifi'd, you shall not stir out▪
I do intreat, and do command you stay.
Titus stay you, till this heat be over.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Titus, my friend; I have a flame within,
That will consume my heart, if you help not!

sp.speaker: Yo. Tit.
sp.l: Do you doubt my assistance, to serve you,
In any way you can prescribe a friend?

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: I'le rather thank thee for't, then doubt thy love,
Th' Embassador can this night hardly▪ reach
Coriola! where we, in a swift Boat▪
By break of day, to morrow may Arrive;
I •… some hours since! we in the dark, Imbarke!

sp.speaker: Yo. Titus
sp.l: I guess your purpose, and I will obey;
Yet I would gladly have an Argument,
To justifie what we intend to do;
Lest Forreign Princes should condemn our State,
That Laws of Nations rashly violate;
And so Cleandras honour, suffer more▪
Then by his Insolence, she did before.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: How can he justifie, those words he spoke?
His rude language, the Law of Nations broke.
For when a Publick Minister puts off
That sacred shadow, which should him protect;
And dares in such vil'd language give affronts,
To a much greater Monarch then his own!
That minute, his Commission did expire;
And like a Ruffen, talk'd so lavishly.

sp.speaker: Yo. Titus.
sp.l: This I confess, is reason for revenge,
But if the World our action not approve?
Pray think, what we shall urge for our excuse,
In case we can no president produce?

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: A president Titus! where will he show,
That Nations do Embassadors allow
To be so barbarously base, as he?
When he dares make his Act, a president!
I will another shew, and kill him for't.
In the first Age, no presidents, were known,
And in ours, this shall be my Creation:
Tis not Cleandras work, nor is it thine;
The glory, or the shame is only mine▪
Titus my heart would break, if I permit
That man to brag, as he will do at home;
How he has brav'd Ormasdes to his face!
And on Cleandra thrown so foul disgrace.

sp.speaker: Y. Tit.
sp.l: Since I your resolution cannot change,
Pray name the place, and hour, and I'le not faile.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Some 3▪ hours hence, we'l at the Ferry meet,
Where a swift well-man'd Boat, you must provide,
My motion may some jealousie beget,
Of what we do intend; and must perform;
If our best speed, can but this Mad-Man reach,
I shall his fury, better manners teach.
sp.stage: Enter Cleandra, Mariana, Old Titus, Cleobulus, and Ladies.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Madam, you are now got so near my heart,
That I am sad to think that we must part.

sp.speaker: Mariana.
sp.l: And I too soon do find, that I too late,
Am now involved in my Brothers Fate.
We leave our hearts behind, though we now fly,
This place by our impulsive Destiny.
My soul has not a wish can send me hence,
If I could stay on any just pretence.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Why may you not stay here Mariana?
And let him go, we will a friendship make,
Such as thy virtue justly may expect,
And my affection give, if here you'l live?

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: I am unhappy Madam, who must be
At his dispose, has done you injurie
So great! that I must suffer while I live.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Rather then you shall suffer, I'le forgive

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Your pardon is, beyond your power, I fear,
Unless you will admit his Master here?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: His pardon then, is far beyond my reach,
If for his King, his own concern be such!
And yours, so much for him; I must consent
To part with both; yet I could be content,
To see him for your sake, I and forget,
What he so rashly has against me said,
Thy tears for him, have satisfaction made.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: My Brother is already on his way▪
And has ordered Boats for me to follow,
Where I expect to find his rage to high,
To hearken to such mercy, as I bring,
Unless Cleandra will admit his King!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: I have not seen such useless rage before,
Whom but himself? can his mad fury harm?

sp.speaker: Mari
sp.l: It is a Riddle I dare not expound.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Dare not Mariana? am I so low
In your Esteem? you da •… e not let me know
What you dare do? this secret I confess,
Has only power to make me love thee less.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: I cannot, I have sworn not yet to say▪
What 'tis, to him I'me doubly tied t' obey:
But since your goodness, can so soon forgive,
So great a Crime, I'le try to bring him back,
And if I can prevail, for his consent,
I'le shew the cause of his distemperment.—

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: You have his pardon, and may now persue
Your own design, to bring him back with you;
But if he chuse to go, and set you free,
Your self shall be much welcomer to me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Your words incourage me to take no leave,
But cherish hopes which may my heart deceive
With present thoughts rather to smile then mourn
As a good Omen to my quick return.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: You Nearcus, shall conduct Mariana
To Coriola, and at your own house,
As you pass by; pray treat her as my friend.

sp.speaker: Nearcus.
sp.l: I shall be carefull in it Madam.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: I love her, and am somewhat more concern'd
To part with her; then I can make you see!

sp.speaker: Admiral.
sp.l: She has by her behaviour, gain'd esteem
From all the Court, and from the Nation to.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: I wonder Titus none of you lament,
When so great Beauty from the Court is sent!

sp.speaker: Admi.
sp.l: Your Majesty has shew'd enough for all.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: I do mean Love Titus, and did expect,
Her beauty should have fir'd a hundred hearts!
And by the powerfull charms of her bright Eyes,
O're-ruled, our Citherean Destinies.

sp.speaker: Admi.
sp.l: My heart Madam, has been so often burnt,
There is no substance left, that can take fire;
Indeed I wonder how the rest have scap'd!

sp.speaker: Cleob.
sp.l: Nearcus, and my self, had other thoughts!
Of this great beauty, which did secure us;
We do Mariana for his Mistris take,
Few Sisters Travel for a Brothers sake!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: How Cleobulus! have you any ground
For this? to justifie so vile a thought;

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Only the freedom, which they daily us'd,
With this new way, for Men who have no Wives,
To carry Sisters, into Foreign Courts!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Though not in use, it does not sure deserve
A censure so severe! such Innocence,
In Mariana, did to me appear,
That I should sooner judge her good, if bad!
Then blemish such perfections by a thought
It cannot be! so Insolent a Guilt!
He durst not own! nor such a scandal raise,
On his own Name! and on his Country too!
I do command you to suppress this thing,
I am asham'd a Cithereans heart,
Should entertain a thought of such a crime!
We bring our own Worth in question then,
When we asperse the Worth of other men.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: They were but thoughts, as rashly then tain up,
As now thrown out; with no design to wrong
The Innocent; I wish her virtue may
Our thoughts convince, and she be justified.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Keep firm there my Lord, for all those who live
Near Princes Eares, should weigh how they let fall
A word, that may a Womans Honour blast;
If I were apt to credit your report?
And on your groundless jealousie affront
Such virtue! what a sin were it in you?
To make me guilty of so great a Crime!

sp.speaker: Cleobulus.
sp.l: I am sorry for my rash opinion,
Since it offends your Majesty so much!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: It is the baine of Courts, when we permit
Those near us, to asperse the Innocent;
If our strict Laws for petty theft, gives Death?
How much a greater punishment is due
For Robbing a good name? a sin so vil'd,
And so unknown! no punishment was made
By way of Prophesie, for crimes to come!
If I did think this malice from your heart,
I would for ever banish you my Court.

sp.speaker: Cleobulus.
sp.l: Your Majesty does raise your anger now
Above my guilt; which had no mischief in't.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: I am no farther angry with you now,
But take occasion to declare my sence,
Against all such as defame Innocence.
'Tis a Prince his chief business to be Just,
The Gods impose on us no higher Trust!
We have no petty faults, to answer for,
Universal Justice, is our great work,
And those who shall divert it, to destroy
The Fame, or Fortune of an Enemy,
Deserves to be thrown off with Infamy.

sp.speaker: Admiral.
sp.l: I have not seen the Queen in such a heat!
You have offended her some other way?

sp.speaker: Cleobulus.
sp.l: Not that I know of, in this kind ever!

sp.speaker: Admi.
sp.l: What Devil, made you talk thus to her now?
You knowing that she is so good herself,
She makes a doubt, that any of her Sex
Can do amiss! and tis great Nobleness!

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: There is a kind of pi •… e Devil, dwells
In many Courts, that haunts our idle heads;
And prompts us, when we know not what to say;
To Entertain great Princes with reports
Of others so to please and pass the time;
This foolish spirit, I think, entred me.

sp.speaker: Admiral.
sp.l: You gave Cleandra cause, for your reproof,
For how can Princes judge Malice, for Mirth?
When cunningly thrown out, with specious shews,
Of probabilities; when those aspers'd,
The Queen did Excellently well, to chide
You, whom she loves; that none may ere presume
The like hereafter! for if Princes be
Born Credulous? Malitious persons may
Defame a Nation, if they please! this way.

sp.speaker: Cleobulus.
sp.l: I know I was to blame, but from this day,
I'le hold my peace, till I know what to say.
sp.stage: Enter Nearcus, with Mariana and Servants at his House.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: (well.
Where are we now my Lord? this house stands

sp.speaker: Nearcus.
sp.l: It is my poor habitation Madam;
Here I must treat you by the Queens command,
'Tis the mid-way unto Coriola.

sp.speaker: Mariana.
sp.l: 'Tis a Noble, and a most pleasant Seat;
Has it no Mistris Sir? Are you fingle?

sp.speaker: Nearcus.
sp.l: I am only that way, happy Madam;

sp.speaker: Mariana.
sp.l: You have a Mistris then? or do you call
It happiness? that you as yet, have none?

sp.speaker: Nearcus.
sp.l: Will you please Madam, to view the garden?
sp.stage: The rest of the Train stay looking on the Pictures, and see them not go out.

sp.speaker: 1. Lady.
sp.l: That piece methinks, does look as if it liv'd.

sp.speaker: 2. Lady
sp.l: I do prefer that smiling Figure first;
Whose hand is it my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: I have not skill enough to know the hands,
Though I love Pictures:—pray observe the next;
Is •… ot this sleeping •… us, rarely done?

See how that Cupid
〈◊〉 the Tree stands off!

sp.speaker: 2. Lady.
sp.l: Tis rare indeed, that Satyr, and the rest,
Of the whole piece, is excellently good!

sp.speaker: 1. Lady.
sp.l: Let us look into the next room my Lord;

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: This way they went, & this way must return.
sp.stage: They go out, and return hastily.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: The doors are lock'd, and we can pass no way.

sp.speaker: 1. Lady.
sp.l: Is this by accident? or on command?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Let us attend a while, and we shall see;
From the next Chamber window, where they be.
sp.stage: Enter Nearcus with Mariana in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Mariana.
sp.l: I have no Argument for further talk,
And now am weary grown, with this long walk;
Where is the beauty? you so much admire!
Your praises, have in me rais'd some desire
To see this wonder of our Sex! that I,
May judge your skill, and with your choice cōply.
sp.stage: Nearcus locks the door, and kneeles.

sp.speaker: Nearcus.
sp.l: She is here already, oh she is here!
A brighter beauty, never can appear!

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Why d'ye lock the door my Lord? why kneele
To me? you make my heart some tremblings feele,
By this surprise; and I do doubtfull stand,
What of kind Treachery you have in hand!
It looks!—yet, like a Lio •… ness betray'd
Into the Toyles; I scorn to be afraid.

sp.speaker: Nearcus.
sp.l: I have no Argument for either now,
But a distracted heart; that knows not how
T'excuse, what I have done! - tis love has brought
Me to this Precipis, and too late taught,
That I from hence, shall head-long tumble down,
If you disdain to save; oh do not frown!
Rather take this, and while you may, prevent
Your own near ruine, and my rash intent.—
—That angry look, and those enraged Eyes,
Pierce like quick Lightning, from the stormy skies;
They melt my heart, & make me •… mbling stand,
To beg what Love, and Nature may Command.

sp.speaker: Mariana.
sp.l: Love! do the Cithereans by such Arts!
Such force! and treachery! win Ladies hearts?
Fie, •… e Nearcus, this does not agree
With Love! nor with Cleandras trust to thee;
I shame to find such ills! and blush to chide:
—Repent, and I thy Infamy will hide;
Oh! tis the basest of all crimes to be
Justly condemn'd, for infidelity;
And with a treachery, my trust beguile,
Beyond the story of the Crocadile.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: What dares not love attempt? when it goes high
Like mine? your ships are ready, oh to nigh!
The wind is fair; and I, no time but this,
To woe; no other means to reach my bliss!
The Queens command, and my desires here meet,
To throw my life, and fortune, at your feet
That by this desperate course, you now may see,
Your love, or scorn, I make my destenie.

sp.speaker: Mari
sp.l: Nearcus, how would you prevail my dreams!
Instruct me not, to answer such extreams!

sp.speaker: Nearcus.
sp.l: I would have you Mistris of me, and mine,
Before we part, made so, by vowes Divine:

sp.speaker: Mariana
sp.l: Tis a short warning, to a work so great!
Is this Cleandras Love? and this your Treat
To strangers? do you think my lips, my heart
Does hold so loose? as at first sight, to part
With it to you? what do you find in me
So slight? that looks like so much levitie.

sp.speaker: Nearcus.
sp.l: If you'l afford more time? I will proceed
With caution, and respect! and shall take heed
How I offen •… ; if you'l resolve to stay,
Or to comply, my passion will obey.
—If not! I must this desperate course persue,
And trust my ruine, or success, to you
—Who does in desperate attempts ingage,
Can seldome at first sight, th'event presage:
—Love led me on, and reason comes to late,
Now to retreat; this Fortune, is my Fate.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Your language, & your looks, do rather threat,
Then woe; which does in me such scorn beget,
As to an Enemy, that does invade
—That Innocence you have berest of aid;
And boldly dare impose on a free heart,
What should be won by Love, not such base art!

sp.speaker: Nearcus.
sp.l: Give me but time to woe! and I will fear▪
And tremble in your sight; with zeal appear,
And the same duty, I approach the Gods,
When my offences, make me fear their Rods!
It is not I, (as y •… affairs do stand)
But high necessity, makes me command;
That all the remnant of my life, you may
Triumph! for my ambition's to obey.

sp.speaker: Mariana.
sp.l: Think you by force, that I shall ere think fit,
To yield my self to such a counterfiet?
I am not born unto so mean a Fate,
As to submit unto the man, I hate:
Nor will I be thus frighted, to comply,
With so contemptable a destiny.

sp.speaker: Nearcus.
sp.l: I must confess, I can by no disguise
Lessen, or hide, the guilt, of this surprize;
But by some greater crime, more amply shew,
That a distracted passion may soon know,
To act such evills, as I fear to think;
But do not set me in despair thus sink.
Speak so, as that I may, some hope retain,
And you'l restore me to my self again.

sp.speaker: Mari
sp.l: Stand by vil'd Man, and let me pass; who waits?

sp.speaker: Near.
sp.l: None within call; that now can help! the fates
Themselves have not the power to set you free,
Nor can you hope for safety, but from me!
No storm at Sea, nor in it, ships on fire,
Creates more terrours, then my wild desire,
Brings me! here is a Tempest in this brest,
Above all them; since raging Love possest
My heart, I am become a walking storm;
Reason, and Virtue, are both wrack'd, no form
Observ'd, while this confusion bears the sway,
None knows to govern; but must all obey,
If we cannot resist; then to cry no,
Is madness, when we must to ruine go!

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l:
I have no power, but 〈◊〉
•… st my Brothers will
Obey; I must his mind, not yours fullfill;
Lest his great pride, and anger may destroy,
What you'd preserve, and frustrate all your joy.

sp.speaker: Nearcus.
sp.l: If my high birth, and quality do prove
But hazzard all my hopes, on his consent,
Let his denial, sign my punishment.

sp.speaker: Mariana.
sp.l: If your birth equal mine, and he consent
To joyn our hands! I have no argument
Against your hopes; but must be Mistris still,
Of my own heart▪ not part with my free-will;
Yet now Nearcus, I do promise you,
What truth and honour dictates, I will do.

sp.speaker: Nearcus.
sp.l: Unless you both do ere you go, comply,
You shall soon see, that I know how to dye.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Pray call my servants down, that I may see
Your truth; and find my self at Liberty.

sp.speaker: Nearcus.
sp.l: Now Madam, that my life's at your dispose,
Your self secure▪ I humbly do propose,
You will before the Gods, confirm by vow,
What you have freely promis'd, to me now.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: By all those powers, I'le keep my promise made▪
Andnever fail to own, what I have said.

sp.speaker: Nearcus.
sp.l: It is enough, a kiss of your fair hand,
Must satisfie the man, you may command;
Nearcus has no soul, cannot be blest,
Untill his love, with love you do invest.
sp.stage: Enter Servants, and all go off together.

div.head: THE THIRD ACT.
div.stage: Enter The Embassador, as at Coriola, with Cleon, Erillos, and Train.

sp.speaker: EMBASSADOR.
sp.l: THis Piazzo Cleon, is Magnificent;
I have not seen any so Beautifull!

sp.speaker: Cleon.
sp.l: It shews the Princes Treasure, and their minds,
Are alike great, who can so soon Erect
So vast a City, which in every part
Deserves to be as much admir'd, as this!

sp.speaker: Emba.
sp.l: We may walk through it, ere my Sister comes!

sp.speaker: Erillos.
sp.l: You may, the River side is your best view;

sp.speaker: Cleon.
sp.l: There is a Boat now coming to the shore;

sp.speaker: Erillos.
sp.l: Those who land, seem to be of Quality!

sp.speaker: Embassador.
sp.l: I see no Woman yet with them appear!
They are very brave, and come towards us!
Do any of you know who these may be?

sp.speaker: Cleon.
sp.l: Young Titus landed first, but as I think
It is Ormasdes who now leads the Troop:

sp.speaker: Embassa.
sp.l: If so! I must expect some angry words,
From the Offended Queen.
sp.stage: Enter Ormasdes, and Young Titus, with Servants, who come up close to the Embassador without any respect.

sp.speaker: Emb.
sp.l: What means this kind of rudeness Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Ormasdes.
sp.l: It speaks my business, who am hither come,
To scourge that pride, you so much glory in.
And with this hand that insolence chastise,
Which boldly durst indeavor to defame,
By base surmises, great Cleandras Name.—
—Titus, I beg as you love my Honour,
If I do fall! let none come in to help!
—Sir, you shall have fair play, that we may see,
How Insolence, and Courage do agree!

sp.speaker: Embass.
sp.l: I shall soon satisfie the doubt you make;
—Stand off; he dyes that stirs to my relief;
Or by a word let fall, does make me known!
sp.stage: They fight, Ormasdes burts and disarms him.
Enter Mariana, and servants, who run in and part them.

sp.speaker: Mariana.
sp.l: Ormasdes hold; it is a King you wound!
It is Valerianus you fight with.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: My self a Prince of Greece of the same blood
With our great Emperour, will justifie
What I have done; and to the World declare,
If any man do wrong me in disguise!
I do his Titles, and himself despise.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Oh Gods! my prophetick soul, did long since
Fore-see this Evil! oh let not—

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Hold Valeriana; there are no Gods!
Nor shall one Altar in my Kingdome stand,
To honour those we foolishly call Gods!
I will Erect new Temples unto Chance,
Which guiddely, thus governs us below.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Take heed Sir, lest you do provoke those powers!
(You now despise!) to punish your contempt!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I will not own those Gods, those empty names,
Who cannot shelter us from publick shames!

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: The Gods be just, and you are much to blame,
'Twas not Ormasdes, who the King ore-came!
It was his Virtue conquer'd your offence,
Your Guilt gave Victory to Innosence.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Will you, become my Judge? will you, cōdemn
My Life, and Honour? A fit Sacrifice
To your belov'd Ormasdes fatal Sword;
Fool, from this hour, I do thy blood disclaim,
And will forget, I ever knew thy Name;—
—Erillos, let my goods be sent aboard,
I will not stay a minute longer here,
Then my necessity compells me to.

sp.speaker: Vale
sp.l: I have prevail'd with the much injur'd Queen,
To lay her anger by, and to forgive
Those rash words you spoke, and have her leave
To bring you to her sight again with hopes
She may her inclinations change, when known!
Your fury did proceed from Love alone.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My Love is vanish'd, and my heart too full
Of my revenge, to think of my return;
Till I can pull Cleandra from her Throne!
I hope Ormasdes will take care of you,
Who plead his cause, and are to love, so true!

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Sir, though yr wounds be slight, if you remove!
So soon? we cannot answer for your life.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I'le rather dye at Sea, then live on shore,
Make hast good Cleon; lead me to my Boat.

sp.speaker: Cleon.
sp.l: Will you leave the Princess, in a strange land?
Thus unkindly cast her off; for ever?
Because her Love did argue for your good!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And thee that dares so boldly her excuse,
Who does my honour, and her own abuse.

sp.speaker: Cleon.
sp.l: Look Sir, she dyes! your unkindness kills her,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: She cannot do her self, and me more right,
Then to dye now! but she cannot depart,
While great Ormasdes Triumphs in her heart!—
—See how his Name, her fainting soul Revives!
Lead on, or I shall laugh to see her dye!
That can raise Trophies for my infamy.

sp.speaker: Valeriana.
sp.l: What cruelty is this? to leave me here!
Who love him better, then he loves himself;
—You'l be all ruin'd, if you stay with me!

sp.speaker: Cleon.
sp.l: What we have said, has ruin'd us enough,
If his unruly rage, can reach so far?

sp.speaker: Mene.
sp.l: I think 'twere best, that you return to Court,
And do Cleandras proffer'd friendship try,
I have all your Brothers Jewells here,
Which will defray your charges while you stay.

sp.speaker: Valeriana.
sp.l: Tis a plentifull provision for us;
But where is young Nearcus, all this while?

sp.speaker: Cleon.
sp.l: He has not yet appear'd, since we Arriv'd.
sp.stage: Enter to them Ormasdes, young Titus, Nearcus, and Servants, Ormasdes stands off.

sp.speaker: Nearcus.
sp.l: Madam, can you forgive, what I have done?
And own the Author of so great a crime?
Who saw not then a Princess in disguise,
But was captiv'd by Marianas eyes!

sp.speaker: Valeriana.
sp.l: My Lord, I do forgive, and shall forget,
So you repent! and I will serve you to,
With all my power, and interest in the Queen.

sp.speaker: Nearcus.
sp.l: If that be all, would I had guilty been
Of greater crimes, then my good natur'd sin.

sp.speaker: Young Titus.
sp.l: Madam, we hear your Brother is unkind,
But by Cleandras favours you may find
Some means to reconcile you unto him

sp.speaker: Valeriana.
sp.l: I am most happy in Cleandras love.

sp.speaker: Yo. Tit.
sp.l: Will you permit Ormasdes in your Boat?
Or shall he seek some other passage home?

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: I could have wish'd Ormasdes less concern'd,
Or that his courage had not been so great;
But cannot quarrel him on this account;
He was oblig'd to right Cleandras wrongs;
And must in Justice be applauded for't.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Madam, I thank the Gods for my success,
And now with the same breath, can humbly beg,
That you'l forgive, what they so late approv'd?

sp.speaker: Valeriana.
sp.l: Sir, it will not become me, his Sister,
—Now to congratulate your Victory,
Who have just cause to mourn my Brothers Fate;
From whence my own misfortunes have their date

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Madam, shall we attend you to your Boat?

sp.speaker: Valeri.
sp.l: Let Titus order all, as he thinks fit!
I am ready now for my remove.
sp.stage: Titus leads off Valeriana, the rest follow.

sp.speaker: Chy.
sp.l: The Queen is troubled, and her Guards are sent
With speed, Ormasdes Quarrel to prevent:

sp.speaker: Cleob.
sp.l: She must secure th' Embassadors return,
Lest all our Neighbour-Nations do complain,
And say, we give occasion for a War;
Which the Treconians claim cannot pretend,
Nor the rejected Marriage, Justifie.

sp.speaker: Chyron.
sp.l: Valerianus has an antient claim
To Zelnia, which may beget a War!
If the Treconians do a quarrel seek?
There wants no Title to a Prince provok'd

sp.speaker: Cleob
sp.l: Ormasdes will rejoyce, to see that day!

sp.speaker: Chy
sp.l: He is our Nations Darling, and deserves,
Cleandras favour; but methinks, he 〈◊〉
As if his heart, were higher, then his head!

sp.speaker: Cleo
sp.l: I have been lately chid for juggling looks,
And dare not say, what I believe, I see.
sp.stage: Enter to them Cleandra. Old Titus, and Ladies.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: You tell such wonders from Coriola,
That I want faith for it! how comes this Newes?

sp.speaker: Admiral.
sp.l: Madam, a Messenger but now Arriv'd,
Saw the Combate done, and heard Nearcus say,
They would attend Valeriana back
Unto your Majesty; (whereas the wonder?)
Princes have been in forreign Courts disguis'd!

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.l: But have you ever such strange humors found?
A Prince where Vice, and Virtue, is so mixt!

sp.speaker: Admi.
sp.l: No, I have not, nor such a president!
As now Ormasdes gives us to correct
Such impudence, as near before was known.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: If I were not concern'd, I should approve.
What he has done, though now I must not own?

sp.speaker: Admi.
sp.l: For publique thanks on his behalf, I move.—
—Why should we thus, our honest thoughts disguise?
When Virtuous Actions, Virtue Justifies.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Had not Ormasdes stird! by Armes I might
Compell his Master to have done me right.

sp.speaker: Admi.
sp.l: By war, thousands of guiltless persons might
Have suffer'd, for one mans over-sight.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: You have reason Titus, and I shall Judge
Ormasdes Act, as he deserves from me;
Who with my Nation, am so much oblig'd,
I must approve, whatever he will own!
—Let the young Princess lodgings be prepar'd,
Fit for my Friend, and Sister to a King.
sp.stage: Enter to them, Valeriana, Young Titus, Nearcus, and Servants.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: You are welcome Madam, and I am glad
To have you on these terms; do not weep
To part with, what your virtue could not keep!

sp.speaker: Valerian.
sp.l: I am happy, by my unhappiness,
For by your favour Madam, I may find
Some remedy for my afflicted mind.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Be sure, what Citherea can afford,
Is yours; and all Cleandra does command
With me rejoyce, to see you safe return'd;
—But where is Ormasdes? I must chide him.

sp.speaker: Nearc.
sp.l: He is retir'd Madam, to avoid your sight.

sp.speaker: Titus.
sp.l: Ormasdes thinks it duty, and respect,
Not to appear at Court, till you direct!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Pray fetch him hither now; I hope you can
With me, forgive so Excellent a man!
Whose passion never does his reason sway,
But follows on, when virtue leads the way.

sp.speaker: Valeriana.
sp.l: I have no anger to Ormasdes, since
Young Titus did my Brothers crime relate,
I hope this letting blood, will do him good,
When this affront, at home, is understood!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Your Justice, and your Charity is great,
And I do see no reason but you may
Admit Ormasdes, in my company;
I am inform'd, he has a slght hurt to!

sp.speaker: Valeriana.
sp.l: My furious Brother will be glad indeed!
That brave Ormasdes, by his hand does bleed.
This accident, if you'l be pleas'd, to call
My Brother back? may reconcile us all.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: I never shall consent to his desires,
Though I my anger, and revenge remove,
In complement to you, whom I do love.
sp.stage: Enter to them Ormasdes, and Young Titus.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Madam, if doing Justice, have displeas'd!
I do repent, and now your pardon beg.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Since his great insolence, and your revenge,
No Age can parallel! both must submit
To such a censure as the World thinks fit.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Your pardon Madam, is not all my sute,
I beg your interest to obtain like grace
From this sad Lady! my whole Soul is vext,
To see such innocence, so much perplext.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: I can now secure you there Ormasdes,
She does discreetly Judge, what you have done,
Was, what a man of honour could not shun.
—Is not this truth Valeriana? speak?

sp.speaker: Valeri.
sp.l: Yes Madam, I do think, I did say so!

sp.speaker: Q
sp.l: What suddain change is this? can your soft heart,
Conceal a thought of ill? towards the man
You have excus'd? and seem'd to smile upon!

sp.speaker: Nearcus.
sp.l: She does love Ormasdes, and I am lost!

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Pray leave us, all with-draw! to the next room:
—What have I said? that can disturb you thus?
Impart your griefs, and I will share in them.

sp.speaker: Valeriana.
sp.l: I dare not shew 'um with an open face!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: And why, you cannot have a guilt so great
That I cannot forgive; speak it freely.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: Has not my face, my guilty heart betray'd?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: I understand you not!

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: —I am safe then, and may my sorrow hide.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Madam, what means this talking to your self?
While I stand by neglected! is your trust
So great? that you can doubt I will be just?

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: I doubt my self great Queen, and fears not you;
She's jealous of me, and my thoughts too true!
She loves Ormasdes, and most unhappy I,
Am forc'd to smile on my own Tragedy;
I know no way to hide my broken heart,
Unless I do immediately depart!—
—Madam, I beg your Pardon, and your Pass,
I must begon, least I too late alass!
By my distempers here, deserve your blame,
And raise my memory, eternal shame

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: You are not well sure, this distracted talk,
Requires Physitians to consult; I'le send;—

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: Oh no! there needs no more consult for this,
You only can restore me unto bliss!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: And can you doubt, that I will not?

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: I fear so!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: What I can do, be you assur'd, I will.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: What I desire, may be more priz'd by you,
Then is the Citherean Diadem!
—Will you know now? and if not grant! forgive?
For I am desperate on the suddain grown,
And am resolv'd to make my weakness known.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Speak it aloud, or in my bosome breath,
The troubles of thy soul, let not a thought
Be hid, but freely shew, how much you trust
My love, and you shall find me kind, and just.

sp.speaker: Vale
sp.l: Do not you Madam, value Ormasdes
Person? and his service above all mens?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: Valeri.
sp.l: You are Just, and Worthy;—and I am—

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Help, help, some help there!

sp.stage: Enter Ormasdes, Titus, Nearcus, and Ladies, who take up Valeriana.

sp.speaker: Nearcus.
sp.l: Tis love, upon my life!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Leave us again, the dangers over now;

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: I beg your permission to retyre.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: My best wishes still attend Ormasdes.

sp.speaker: Valeria.
sp.l: What can I say, t'excuse what I have done?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Speak plainly your full thoughts, & I'm yr friend;
But if you longer dally with my love!
You will my friendship, unto anger move.

sp.speaker: Valeri.
sp.l: I know you have discover'd by my words,
That your Esteem of him, you boldly own,
Becomes the ground of my distraction;

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.l: You love him then! that look declares it now!
And so do I, or I would ne're consent
To give him unto you; if this cure grow
Within my reach! Ormasdes shall be yours.

sp.speaker: Valeri.
sp.l: Is not your Majesty ingag'd to him?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Indeed, I am not so in love with him,
But I can second your desires; and will
With all my power endeavor to perswade
Ormasdes that he meet with open armes,
So great a blessing by the Gods defign'd;
Though I must part with what I value most,
Your passion, never shall by me be crost.

sp.speaker: Valeri.
sp.l: Madam, your kindness to me flows so fast,
That I am now in danger to be lost,
By my abundant joy for this success
You give, of unexpected happiness.

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.l: Remove these sullen clouds from thy fair Eyes,
And be thy self again, for I will shew
Ormasdes suddainly how great a bliss,
The Heav'ns prepare to Crown his Virtue with.

sp.speaker: Valer.
sp.l: The Gods reward you with your highest wish!
That you may never want what you desire,
My spirits fail so fast! I must retire.
sp.stage: Her Maids lead her off, leaning on them, and shewing much weakness.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Do so; what's this, I have so rashly done!
Thrown off Ormasdes I depend on!
Must I perswade him quit that Interest here,
Which for my sake, he purchased so deare!
—How ill shall I repay his service past?
If I advise, this banishment at last;
What a rash promise, has my pitty made?
By thus proposing my improper Ay'd!
Though by the secret charms of sympathy,
Her passion won my reason to comply,
I must on this imployment Titus use,
My Honour will my active part excuse.
—But if his Arguments should not prevail?
And by my nicety, the business fail?
—If she should perish so? and I repent
To late, that ill! which I may yet prevent;
—I must about it then, and loose no time,
Lest my nice complements do prove a crime!
—My faith is past, and I will now proceed,
Though b •… e Ormasdes do condemn the Deed▪
sp.stage: Enter Nearcus, with Valeriana, in her Chamber, her Ladies stand off, but go not out.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: Madam, my desperate State, and high transport,
You may complain of, though not blame me for't;
Your eyes, like bright misguiding fires, betray
My wandring soul, and make me lose my way.
Tis now too late, to see that I am lost,
•… ed by those guides, to this obdurate coast,
Where neither Rocks appear, nor crossing▪ Tides;
Yet this expected safety, ruine hides!
—But I must claim you by a solemn vow,
Made in the sight of Heav'n; and am come now,
To prove my Birth, which you will not deny,
Is with your own, of equall Quality;
These are such Arguments for your consent,
I cannot think, you dare your vowes repent.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: It cannot well be thought, and much less said,
That I repent a promise, never made;
How could such hasty words, strict vowes appear?
Which my surprise, then made me speak in fear!
When you to seize me, stretch'd those Lions paws,
And threatn'd 'gainst all Hospitable Laws!
Worse then Death to me; what might I not do?
To get from such a Monstrous Beast as you!

sp.speaker: Near.
sp.l: Did my humility such danger threat?
Or my submission, with such horror treat!
Were it even so, as you your self have said!
I might my own conditions, then have made.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: Did you not all my Servants first exclude?
And me into a loneness so delude,
As that no rescue could be had! to free
Me from your Trayterous Captivity.
When you with humble looks, strong fetters laid,
And words let fall, which made my soul afraid;
And caus'd me use some little Art, to gain
Your trust, that I my freedom might obtain.

sp.speaker: Near.
sp.l: Tis true indeed, and you reproach me well,
Or else you might another story tell!
For I confess, I did too much! to prove
The humble passion of a gentle Love;
And much too little, now to justifie
My high affections, or my fact denie.
Had I with vigour my first step persu'd, (new'd.
You might have wish'd my vows, with yours re

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: You talk, as now, I at your mercy were;
As if you still might threat; and I must fear!
But I shall make you know your self, and me,
If you proceed not with more modesty!
And shall soon let Cleandra understand,
How well you Treated me! on her command.

sp.speaker: Near.
sp.l: Though I do shake, and tremble at your frown,
Cleandras anger, cannot bow me down.
For if my suffering no compassion move,
Nor your past vowes, make you regard my Love!
You shall then see, how little I esteem
This Life, you will not with a smile redeem!

sp.speaker: Valeriana.
sp.l: I am not thus ingratefull as you say,
So I may be secur'd another way;
—I did not threat, till you aspers'd my Name,
By this false promise, you unjustly claim.
For though your Birth flow from a Noble Spring,
Tis something less, then Daughter to a King.
And more, I must the secret now impart,
That brave Ormasdes long since, had my heart.

sp.speaker: Near.
sp.l: Madam, I have no Plea beyond my Love,
If that, do of too mean a value prove!
Think how your honour stands ingag'd by vow,
And that my all depends upon it now!
Yet here I do before the Gods profess,
To quit my Title, if my birth be less!

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: From Nearcus, the Gods will me protect,
Who boldly must a subjects claim, reject.

sp.speaker: Near.
sp.l: Which I am not; but a Prince Nobly born,
As is Cleandra! though you now do scorn
The Man, who lay'd his greatness at your feet,
Without a thought, of Royalty to meet!
Your Virtue, and your Beauty did engage
My heart to Love; and did create that rage,
You now so much condemn; and makes me sha •…
I did no more, who was so much to blame!

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: You do amaze me! knows Cleandra this?

sp.speaker: Near.
sp.l: She yet does not, but must do, when I plead
My Title to Valerianas Bed.
For Madam, you can onely now be mine,
Made so by humane Lawes, and by Divine.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: What ere you are! I do much scorn to think
Of being compell'd and will strong poyson dri •…
Rather then be by such a trick betray'd,
Or of your scandalous reports, afraid;
Your first attempt was base; and now as vain
Your hopes are; you are a Prince! I do disdain
To have a thought for him, who poorly can,
Demand, what's given to another man.
I must this Injury at last reveal,
And to the Queen, for Justice now appeal.

sp.speaker: Near.
sp.l: I am content, then let Cleandra Judge,

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: I'le hear no more.

sp.speaker: Near.
sp.l: What a strange heat I feel, that alwayes burn,
Yet do not wast, cannot to Ashes turn!
But like a fire-flaming Statue stand,
To warn the World, not to approach this Land;
Ye Gods! how cruel is your doom? that she
Melts not; but should an Icie Mountain be,
Of power to kindle such tormenting fires,
Where her own frozen heart has no desires.

div.head: THE FOURTH ACT.
div.stage: Enter Cleandra, with Ormasde •… , the Lords, and Ladies stand off.

sp.speaker: QUEEN.
sp.l: I shall allow your Argument for War,
If the Treconian do provoke so far!
But how shall I, Valeriana free?
From her fierce Brothers great barbaritie;
And how Estate her in her Mothers Land!
If her mad Brother, should that right withstand!
Though she do now desire but what's her own,
If he should dye; She must Ascend that Throne.

sp.speaker: Ormas
sp.l: I have heard so, and that, by my rash Act,
She suffers, which makes me repent the Fact!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Her virtues, do her beauty far excell,
And in my judgement, have no parallel;
What is your thought? will not the man be blest?
Whom Cods with such felicities invest!

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: I doubt not Madam, her perfections may
In hearts of Men; above her Scepter sway.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: She has won me, to a concern so high,
As if my own, were the same Desteny
With hers; my thoughts do labor where to treat
A Marriage with some Prince, worthy so great
A Queen; can you Ormasdes find me one
To recommend? will Greece afford us none?

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Madam, if Citherea can produce
None fit! for Greece, there will need no excuse;—

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: I think so too, unlesse Ormasdes will
Himself, thus my prophetick soul fulfill!
That does such glories, and such joyes foresee,
As may indure unto Eternitie.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Me Madam, does your Majesty think me
A man worthy of so great Felicitie?
Alas I am too old, now to begin
To Love! you may as soon learn me to spin;
—My Sword, and Armor, into Needles turn,
As •… each my Age in Youthful flames to burn.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Tis you Ormasdes, are the man so blest,
Her love to you, she has to me confest;
And me in honour has ingag'd to try,
If I can now perswade you to comply.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Madam, I hope you do not thus abuse
Your servant, cause my nature does refuse,
Such correspondence with your Sex, as might
Ingage a braver Man; Oh do not fight
Against my weakness! that must now confess,
I never unto Lady made Address;
And onely chose this solitary place,
That I might here some quiet thoughts imbrace.
—Sure Madam, you mistake; how can it be?
That she should covet such A •… tipothy!
—Can the good Gods to her be so unkind?
To let such excellence, become so blind?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Think you her self knows? what her self desires?
Or that she has no sence, of those quick fires,
That do consume her! can you doubt such Love?
Which through dispair, did then so mortal prove!
That but to name Ormasdes, she did Dye,
Till you appear'd, to change that destiny;
—And when you all retir'd, she did confess,
Her life depended on her good success;
Your Glorious Acts had raised so loud a Fame,
That she was first in Love with your great Name!
Which brought her hither, with a full intent,
To Judge, and Justifie, that Argument.

sp.speaker: Crm •… s
sp.l: Madam, I must believe what you avow,
And do so far your Argument allow,
That it has rais'd in me, a greater war,
Then I was ever in; and am so far
From slighting this affair, that I descry,
My certain Ruine, by this Victory.
The Gods cannot afford lesse punishment,
If I refuse to hear! and if consent!
I'm lost, to all my joyes on Earth; for Fate
Has not in store, nor can the Gods Create
An evill, I fear more, then to deny,
What you command; though a sad Desteny;
—Can nothing less then my destruction? save
This Excellence? from an untimely Grave!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: If I could see this danger you foretell?
Ormasdes harms, should make no other well!
Though Valeriana do my pitty move,
Ormasdes friendship, is before her Love
In my esteem; but if this match unite
Your hearts? it will our Children then invite,
To imitate our friendship, and so tye
Fast knots, for everlasting Ametie.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: My mind can move my body any way,
But my hard heart, will not my will obey;
My utmost power, my soul to mourn shall teach,
Cause my Affection, is beyond my reach!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: If you oppose not, but your ear will lend,
I doubt not, but the Gods your heart will bend
This way, and your good nature in short time,
Will make you wish for, what you judge my crime.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Although I cannot, wish, and must not chuse,
I would not Madam, willingly refuse
What you advise; but boldly meet my Fate,
That no one thought, may a vain fear Create,
Lest you should judge my slackness, for neglect,
Because I graspe not, what I cann't affect.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Can you such pleasure tak, in this disguise?
Be thus retir'd? and all that's good despise,
When offer'd! do you fear? or scorn to meet
This Excellence, now fallen at your feet!
—Is your great heart Ormasdes, onely made
For dangerous attempts? shall it be said?
This Parragon of all our Sex! now dyes,
Because Ormasdes, does her Love despise!

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: No Madam, I do suffer more, then she
Does for her self! hers, is my miserie;
I dare not virtue, with vain hopes abuse,
I cannot love; and therefore do refuse
To dally with so bright a Saint, whose Shrine,
Compells all hearts to bow before't, but mine;
I am not capable of Love; not blest
That way! my heart's with other flames possest.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: All flames you feel, would vanish, did you see
Valeriana in such misery
As she endure! now fetching her last breath,
Enquiring your health, neglecting her own death.
Thus my compassion has her sorrows learn'd,
I weep her tears, while you stand unconcern'd!

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Madam, your passion does my pitty move,
Though my dull heart cannot consent to Love;
My resolution is now fixt; I'le try
My self to vanquish, or her Martyr Dye!
—I swear, I did not hear that she was ill,
And now it does my soul with horrour fill,
For her concern; no danger is so great,
But I will rather dye in't, then retreat.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Tis bravely said, but dare you try the effect,
Of one short visit? after such neglect!

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Thus provok'd! if your Majesty stands by!
I will not such a visit now deny.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: You speak, and look, as if you meant to fright,
Much rather, then revive her by your sight!

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Madam, to Complement, I have no skill,
Nor can be pleas'd, if lov'd against my will!
Yet sensible, and civil, I can be,
Though it do prove unfortunate, to me.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: When shall I bring this comfort? to revive
Her fainting soul; if she be still alive.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Is she really so weak; so soon grown
Thus ill? I have no skill, in this unknown
Mystery of love! but will boldly try,
What I can do, for her recovery.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: High passions do weak bodies sooner bring
To the Graves mouth, then any other thing;
Her despairs, are of a much longer date,
Though suddain sickness do break out thus late;
—When I your humour, did at first reherse,
And shew'd, how your whole life had been averse
To Love; she sigh'd, and presently grew pale,
Despair that minute, made her spirits fail;
And so transported by her fancy, fell
As if my doubts, had rung her passing bell.

sp.speaker: Orm.
sp.l: Though I cannot speak, nor do yet know how
To look; I'm ready to attend you now!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: I fear, so suddain, and so great a joy!
As your approach; may equally destroy!
Let me her heart prepare, that by degrees,
She may but hope retain, before she sees
The comfort, that your visit brings; and then
Ormasdes may ere long, prove best of Men.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Madam, I do my self to you submit,
Pray order me in all, as you think fit.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: You shall then stand unseen, while I do tell
This welcome story, which will make her well.
And then by what you'l see you may observe,
How my true friendship will from both deserve!
Who have no wish beyond Ormasdes good,
When time shall make me rightly understand.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Madam, I have now no more to say,
But that I will your Majesty obey.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: You shall not stir Ormasdes till I send.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Did you not meet Cleandra going out?

sp.speaker: Near.
sp.l: Yes, but I have business of importance,
Pray let us withdraw, and be more private.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Come this way then:—

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Why have you drawn me to this inner room?
Is the secret, of so piercing quality?
That fewer walls then these, cannot contain't!

sp.speaker: Near.
sp.l: It is my Lord of a high nature grown,
I must impart it to your self alone;
—You and I, must kill one another now;

sp.speaker: Orma.
sp.l: May not I live? though you are pleas'd to die?

sp.speaker: Near.
sp.l: No Sir, since tis decreed that I must die!
I am resolv'd to have your Company.
—There's a sword, the same wth mine, defend you.

sp.speaker: Ormasdes.
sp.l: Hold a while:—
—May not I know the cause of this hatred?

sp.speaker: Near.
sp.l: I have no hatred, yet endeavor, must
That we together may revert to dust.
Though you by chance have rob'd me of my right
—I'de not out-live Ormasdes, if I might!

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: From whēce dos this strange kindnes to me grow?
Say, for I will not fight, untill I know!

sp.speaker: Near.
sp.l: This then, will teach you to defend your self:
sp.stage: Runs at him; he put his Sword by, and holds him.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: I shall call my Servants, unless you now show
The cause of this distracted fury?

sp.speaker: Near.
sp.l: I will:—
—Valeriana's my Quarrel;
She throws neglects on me, and dotes on you.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: You are mistaken sure, and much abus'd!
It is not possible!—She dotes on me!
Who never Courted Lady in my life!

sp.speaker: Near.
sp.l: By all that's good, she told me so her self.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: This must be some design, beyond my reach!
But if true? from whence does my guilt arise?
Who never heard of your pretence, till now!
Nor have a serious thought for hers, to me;
If such a folly, do her heart possess;
Am I to answer for her guiltiness?

sp.speaker: Near.
sp.l: I do accuse you, of no guilt at all;
But joy to think, if by my hand you fall;
It will Create in her such miserie,
As will adorn my death with Victorie.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: If such revenge, and malice you intend?
Where is the Love, that you so much pretend?

sp.speaker: Near.
sp.l: We'l talk of that, as our two souls expire;
She flatter'd me with hopes, that blew my fire,
She threw out vowes to marry me, and now
In hope of you, disowns that holy vow.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Made vows to marry you! and yet love me!
Pray shew me how, this story does agree?
I swear, I never had a thought of Love
To Lady in my life; and will now quit
The intrest you pretend, rather then fight—
For such imaginary Dreams, as this.

sp.speaker: Nearcus.
sp.l: You must Fight.
sp.stage: Nearcus offers at him, he rings a Bell: Enter Servants.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: No; disarm him,—so, now leave us alone,—
—Nearcus, I have lov'd you, and shall still,
If you'l permit!—what does this story mean?

sp.speaker: Near.
sp.l: By Hea—Valeriana did ingage
To marry me; if my birth equal'd hers!
But now repents, in hope to marry you.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: This story grows stranger, and stranger still
Does your birth equal hers? on which you ground
Your Title, and on which her vow was made.

sp.speaker: Near.
sp.l: It does Ormasdes, and did hers exceed,
When I first urg'd that sacred vow she made;
She but a Subject, unto me appear'd.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: And are you other now?

sp.speaker: Near.
sp.l: Yes, have you not heard that Prince Orontes,
Brother to our late King, had a young Son
Call'd Leonatus, who by sad mishap,
Fencing with the Prince, hurt him in the Eye,
Of which hurt he dyed; and the King, inrag'd,
Made vowes to Sacrifice the Murtherer;
As if the mischief, purposely were done!
In order to his own Succession;—
—(After Cleandra;) who was then married
To a young Prince in Greece, and setl'd there.

sp.speaker: Orm.
sp.l: I'ave often heard the Queen, with sighs lament
Her Brothers loss, by that sad accident:
And say, she pittied Leonatus death,
As innocent! for that unhappy youth,
She heard, was drown'd, endeavouring to escape
Her Fathers Vengeance, he unjustly vow'd.

sp.speaker: Near.
sp.l: She was mis-inform'd my Lord, he yet lives;
'Twas by this fatall hand, her brother fell;
And I accurs'd, that have thus long surviv'd!
To fall a mis-becoming Sacrifice,
To Love; by a disdainful Ladies Eyes.
After so long concealment, and so safe!
By Old Nearcus, put in this disguise,
Bred as his Son; but now▪ I Life despise;
And call to have that Justice on me done,
Which I have us'd much industry to shun.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: You tell me wonders, of a different kind,
Of which I shall enquire; and if I find
Valeriana stands ingag'd to you?
And all this story of your self, prove True!
I will my best endeavors soon imploy,
This gross mistake of me, to rectifie.

sp.speaker: Near.
sp.l: If my address, do find no good success!
The business of my life, shall be to dye,
And whether by your hand, or by command
From our great Queen? it is the same to me,
The Princess must my Life, or Death decree.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: I shall conceal your Name, untill I see,
I may reveal it, with securitie;
And in few hours, if my desires succeed!
You shall from all your doubts, and fears be freed.

sp.speaker: Near.
sp.l: You will oblige me ever, if you do!

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: My hour is come, to wait upon the Queen,
Unto Valeriana, where this Newes,
I hope will bring me off, from the first Rock:—
—By Valeriana to be thus lov'd!
And by Cleandra, for another woo'd!
And by Nearcus kill'd, I know not why!
To me is a new kind of Misterie.
sp.stage: Enter Valeriana, brought in very weak, lying in a Couch, with Physitians, and Servants; She speaks very faintly.

sp.speaker: Valeri.
sp.l: Is not the Queen return'd to Court yet?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: No Madam.

sp.speaker: Valeri.
sp.l: I wish she were; my heart dessolves so fast!
That I do find, I shall few minutes last.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Your fancy, does your weakness much increase,
This passion, is the worst of your disease.
sp.stage: Enter Queen, and Ormasdes, she sets him to stand unseen.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.l: Oh Madam! you are much wish'd for here;

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Let all withdraw, I must be private now,
Onely do you Ormasdes stand unseen;—
—How is it with my friend?

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: I'm glad that you are come to close my Eyes,
My spirits wast so fast, that I must dye!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: I hope not yet Valeriana.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: Alass Madam, I had not liv'd till now,
But for the joy my broken heart conceives
In hopes to hear Ormasdes is grown well.
Before I leave this world.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Twas the distemper of an Ague fit,
And he is now so far from being sick,
That he without, begs leave to visit you.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: Me, did you say? to visit me Madam!
Will Ormasdes visit me? is it so?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Yes, He's without, and does by me desire
You will admit him;—Why are you silent?
Now my endeavours prosper to your wish!

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: Does wise Cleandra think it will be fit?
That I in such a passion leave this World!
As I shall do, if I see Ormasdes!—
—I shame to think that he should see me dye,
Yet cannot chuse, but wish it heartily!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Shall I call him in then? why do you doubt?

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: Oh Madam, I dare not see him, must not!
You have said something, to bring him hither!
Makes me fear to see him; it must not be!

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.l: Pray see him, and let this great crime, be mine;
His presence, may your troubl'd heartrevive.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: He cannot Madam, for tis now too late!
I do feel here, the heavy hand of Death
Is crushing me to Ayre.
sp.stage: She faints in the Queens Armes.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Ormasdes your help! she dies, she dies!
sp.stage: He draws, and proffers to kill himself.

sp.speaker: Ormas
sp.l: By all our Gods, I will dye with her then!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: She lives again! Ormasdes your help now;—
sp.stage: He flings away his Sword, and helps.
sp.l: —So let her head lye a little from us.
sp.stage: He kneels, and holds her hand.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: For Heav'n sake Madam, tell what I must say?
Or what now must do? is she not dead still?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Does not her hand inform you, that she lives?
Is it not warm?

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Oh yes! tis warm, but I, who never dar'd
Thus boldly touch a Ladies hand till now;
Understand not how to use it, as I ought!

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.l: There needs no other kindness, then you shew,
—How is it now Valeriana?

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: Well Madam to well, I fear, to last so:
I dare not look that way, because I blush
To think how I have scandaliz'd my Sex!
And how Ormasdes now is justified!
In his contempt of Women, for my sake!
I have no power to take away my hand,
Yet dare not own, to leave it with him longer.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Oh why? what has Ormasdes ever done?
Justly to merrit this dissertion?

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: Pray Madam, say something in my behalf;
Either to hide, or to excuse my shame.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Turn this way then, and let your Eyes excuse
