That guilt, which will Ormasdes disabuse.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: She looks desperately ill!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Tis only weakness, and no danger in't;
Pray call her Servants, and let us retire.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Retire! you have engag'd me now so far,
That I must see the Battle won, or lost!
Before I can consent, to a Retreat.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Tis late▪ and she must sleep.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Why Madam, so she may, though I be by!
I'le sit as silent, as the God of sleep,
And here attend, while her tir'd servants rest.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: You will not watch all night Ormasdes?

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Oh but I will Madam; watch night, by night,
Till she recover! This is my fixt Post,
Appointed by the Gods; not your command,
Nor any force, has power to take me hence;
While this good sword will hold for my defence.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Why so fierce, and violent Ormasdes?
I am much joy'd▪ to see you thus concern'd!
And on this quarrel, am not like to fight▪
With such a man at Armes, by candle light!

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: For Heav'n sake Madam, pardon my rash words,
And disrespect unto your Majesty;
For I do scaree know what I say, or do;
I am become a stranger to my self,
So suddainly transform'd, that I would hide
Me from your •… ight, if I durst stir from hence!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: I will forgive, so you'l let me direct
Your future actions, I'le your Love protect!

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: If you'l command?—I gladly will obey.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: You must submit, to what she does appoint.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Most willingly.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Does our discourse, these sighs, & tears produce?

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: You have said nothing that will need excuse.
These tears flow from joy, and gratitude,
To you great Queen, who by this act, include
More pious pitty, then past stories tell;——
To make Ormasdes counterfeit so well!
-This thought raisd those unruly sighs you heard.
And Madam, now it makes my soul affraid,
To see so great a courage thus submit,
To flatter me, because you think it fit;
—At your command, to put on this disguise,
In kindness unto one, he does despise.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Do you then think his kindness counterfeit?
Can his great soul consent, to such deceit?

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: I can yet find no argument, for ground,
To change so great contempt, as I have found,
Into so high esteem! as he does now,
By your advice, in charity allow;
That my last minutes, may some pleasure have,
He yields to send me smiling to my grave.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: You cannot judge so ill, of him you love;
Nor can so brave a man, so worthless prove!

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: I do confess, I should be glad to find
All real that I see; and his great mind
The same brave Character he had, maintain
Through his whole life; and not that glory stain
But if't be real, this comes now too late,
His kindness cannot change the course of Fate!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Think not of Death, for if you will endure
The Tryall? I will undertake the cure;
I see your sufferings do compassion move,
Which in most genrous hearts, does turn to Love.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Madam, I know not what, you do call love,
Nor how in that fantastick Sphear to move!
I cannot talk the language Lovers use,
When they design fair Ladies to abuse;
Nor can I yet, by this experience guess,
If Love, or a distraction, does possess
My heart? give me but leave to watch this night,
That while you sleep, I may my heart invite,
To tell me what it a •… ls! if it be •… ove?
What all the World allows! I shall approve:
And then, I'le rather dye, then e're forsake
What I avow, or what I undertake.

sp.speaker: Q
sp.l: Pray Madam, give him leave to watch this night,
Some serious thoughts may set his fancy right.
He has lyen often on the frozen ground,
On less occasion, and more danger found.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: I shall not rest then, though you think it fit,
I shall condemn my self, if I submit.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Tis somewhat more then custome does allow,
I must confess; but how to help it now,
Who knows? you see he is resolv'd to beat
Us all, if we but mention his Retreat.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Pray let not this my first sute be deny'd,
But give me leave to •… it on yonder side,
As silent as •… leep self; my body shall
Be fixt, as is that figure on the wall.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Let him Valeriana, pray consent,
'Twill prove his honor, or his punishment!

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Who can have more care? who so fit as I
To watch? who am resolv'd with her to Dye.
—Good rest unto your Majesty.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: He'l turn me out, if I refuse to go!
—But why Ormasdes do you tremble so?

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: This shaking fit may to a Feavor turn,
And I, e're day, in Loves bright flames may burn.

div.head: THE FIFTH ACT.
div.stage: Valeriana is discover'd asleep on a Couch, with Doctors, and Ladies all asleep about her Ormasdes rises from the ground, at the Couch side.

sp.speaker: ORMASDES.
sp.l: ALl eyes are shut, all hearts can rest, but mine,
I've somthing here, that will not let me sleep:
—Tis Love, I am bewitch'd, or it is Love!
That thus disturbs my body, and distracts
My mind; no other passion works like this!
Well then, if it be Love! where's the wonder?
The wifest, bravest, and the greatest men,
Have been in Love as much, or more then I;
—But why then was I, thus long without it?
Why did not bright Cleandras beauty burn?
Why was not this fire kindl'd untill now?
How comes Valeriana by this power?
To wound me deeper, then Cleandra did!
My Kind, Loving Heart, how comes this to pass?

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Ha! Her spirit by that sigh informs me,
That doubl'd groan, struck through my wavring soul,
Oh thou Divinest power! what ere thou art!
I do submit, Valerianas groans
Are all sufficient arguments for Love!
It seems, my stony heart, was proof against
All charms, but deep fetch'd sighs, & dying grons;
By which, tis now made supple, and so soft,
That it is ready to take any form;
That sick Valeriana shall direct;—
—Great God of Love, forgive my past neglects,
And now restore this Lady to her health,
Then I with Insense will thy Altars load,
Thy Temple with those Trophies, now adorn,
Which my whole life prepar'd, for Mars and Jove.
Since they allow me to submit to love!

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: Drusilla.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Madam, your Servants do all sleep, but I.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: I would not have wak'd you, Ormasdes.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: You have not Madam, I have not slept yet;
Pray let your Servant know what tis you want!

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: I want assurance of a thing I doubt.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Can I give you that assurance?

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: And will you not lay that command on me?

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: Do they all sleep?

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: They do.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: Ormasdes I would know, what I do fear,
You are pre-ingag'd never to tell me;

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: By your fair self, I swear, I'm not ingag'd
In any kind, but may, and will impart,
What ever in my knowledge, you inquire.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: My first doubts does still remain, that the Queen
Upon assurance of my suddain death,
Has won you, thus to flatter my last hours,
Like glittering Sun-shine upon dying Flowers.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Madam, by all thats holy, she has not:
What shall I say? what do? to gain your faith?

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: You have done it now; I am satisfied.
And do believe all's truth, Ormasdes speaks,
But I do sear this truth appears too late.

sp.speaker: Orm.
sp.l: Why Madam? have you made yows against me?
Will no repentance? nor no pennance serve,
To wash away my Sins against your Sex
Will you, that Universal quarrel wed?
And bring distruction, on your Servants head?

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: Vows Ormasdes, and those against you made!
Oh do not take away the Joy you gave,
By such a thought; I never wish'd, nor pray'd,
For blessing upon Earth, beyond your Love,
Which you in charity, so amply shew,
That I do doubt I dream, what I injoy.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Madam, you do now misjudge my passion,
To call that charity, which may be love
For ought I know; this so late acquaintance
With my new heart is short, and my transports
So great, it must be madness, if not love:
For, give me leave to swear, that I will know
No other Joys then yours, nor thoughts admit,
But with design to serve, and honour you.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: I do now wish the Gods my life would spare,
And make me worthy of Ormasdes care.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Madam, you speak a Language of respect
To me, who merrit nothing but neglect;
Your favours flow so fast, they over-whelm
My heart with joys, and raise my soul so high,
It turns amazement into extacy.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: I should not talk thus, if I did not see't;
Tis harder for you now to hide, then shew't:
I do not fear your passion will go less,
But doubt by death to lose, what I possess.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: You cannot dye Madam, I have no fear
To find so great a curse, from Heav'n sent,
I onely doubt I sleep! and fear to wake
Least this abundant bliss should vanquish quite,
And so involve me in Eternal Night;
May I'presume to beg a favour yet?
Which will my fancy fix, and so confirm
My doubtfull soul tis real, and no dream.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: You may.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: I beg that Ring you wear; but if of price
Too great for me? pardon my Avarice.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: Tis a trifle, ask something of more worth.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Sure nothing can of greater value be
If you repent, what you now promis'd me.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: You ask, what is not in my power to give!
My dying Mother with this Ring bequeath'd
Her curse, if ever I did part with it!
But to the man I meant to make my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Tis a charm not to be dissolv'd by me;
Who dare not touch it, on the terms, you name;
I was ambitious to wear it Madam
But onely as your servant, not your Lord.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: It never can be had, on easier termes;
Ormasdes you must have this, and me together,
Alive or dead, you must have both, or neither.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: All my Limbs do tremble, at what I hear,
I dare not understand the words you speak,
Least my mistakes do give you an offence,
Beyond a pardon, for such impudence.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: You do not mistake me, nor can you err!
If you'l avow, this kindness that you shew.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: By all our Gods, I think my flame is Love,
I know no other name for what I feel,
But if you doubt? propose a way to try,
And as it proves, declare my destiny.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: I will consider on some way to try,
But must submit unto this drowsinesse,
For a minutes time, twill take me from you!
Pray Sir, command the musick now to play.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: She has talk'd her self into a Repose,
Now I will try to get alittle Rest.
That my tir'd fancy, may at last be fixt.
sp.stage: Valeriana Counterfeits to sleep, Ormasdes lyes on the ground by her Couch, and while he sleeps, she puts the Ring on his finger; then the Musick ends.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: So—when he calls to mind, what I have said;
He can expect no more, then I now give;
—Great goddess of pure hearts, protect my fame,
And this rash act, forgive; which frights me now;
To such repentance, with such suddain pain,
I am resolv'd to take it off again,—
sp.stage: She offers to take it off, and cannot.
sp.l: —His hand is so fast clos'd, I cannot do't;
And to wake him in the attempt, is worse;
Such boldness may a double censure get;
I blush to think how rashly I begun,
And now repent the folly I have done:—
—His hand opens:—
And now tis mine again,
Oh blest accident!
sp.stage: She takes off the Ring, Musick playes; she sleeps in earnest, while the Musick is.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Wake them not; has Ormasdes walk'd to night?
From that corner, hither, in his sleep?
Did any of you hear them talk ith' night?

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.l: Not I Madam.

sp.speaker: First Lady.
sp.l: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Second Lady.
sp.l: I heard none stir Madam.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: The Queen; is it so late?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: You have had a hard Lodging my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: I have had the happiest night Madam;
And am Richer far then both the Indies;—
sp.stage: Ormasdes starts, and looks distractedly for something lost.
sp.l: —Ha! I am undone, undone for ever!

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: What look you for my Lord? what have you lost?

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: I had it now, just now, on this finger!
I look for Treasure Madam, worth the World;
—'Twas no dream, it must be here abouts!
—I beg your pardon Madam, for this search,
Which does concern my life, and honour too.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: This is the strangest passion, I ere saw,
Has your great loss, no name to know it by?

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Yes, I have lost Valerianas Ring.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: You did but dream, see, tis on her finger:

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: How! tis so indeed, do I not dream now?
Or do the Gods us men with shadows mock?
When we do seek such great felicities,
As they allow us not to have below!
—What a strange height of bliss? am I fall'n from?

sp.speaker: Q
sp.l: Has this one night, such mutual friendship gain'd?
That the prophetick Ring, could be obtain'd!

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: I know not what to say, nor what to think!
I know not when I sleep, or when I wake!
Yet must believe that Ring, was mine this night;
And I have lost that Treasure Childishly:
Some kind friend strike me hard, that I may feel
I now am waking; your pardon Madam
For my disaster makes me almost mad.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: How have you slept Valeriana?

sp.speaker: Vale
sp.l: Very well Madam, for one so weak!

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Did you not wake about mid-night Madam?

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: Not that I remember.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Was ever man so much abus'd in's sleep?

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: Ormasdes, what means your disorder'd looks?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: He finds his waking fancies are much less
Delightfull, then his sleeping happiness.

sp.speaker: Orm.
sp.l: I dream't Madam, that Ring you prize so much,
Was this night, by you, put on my finger;
When a thousand, thousand joyes fell on me,
Which now waking, I have no name for.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: My Ring Ormasdes! and on your finger!
And by me put on! twas a dream indeed!
I hope, you do not waking, think it fit,
That I, should waking do so bold an act.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Madam, it does not become me to say
I wish, what you do not allow; nor dare
I tell so great a lye, as to deny
The joy I dream'd of when I thought I saw,
And did believe I felt, it once was mine.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: Tis far from my serious thoughts Ormasdes,
After such high passion, as I have shew'd,
Now to raise any discontent in you,
But do not lessen your esteem of me,
By the acquisition of such favours,
As you your self in others would condemn!
Have we not both, at first sight, done enough?
To justifie, what we professe; I fear
Too much on my part, did not Cleandra
Own all that she has done, on my behalf.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: I submit, and will wish, and think, and do
What the wise Queen, and you advise me to.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Ormasdes has not lost his time I see,
Nor my design for your recovery
Fall'n short! the gods in their good time will bring
You to give, and him to accept the Ring.
May your new friendship never know decay,
But freely both command, and both obey:
—I must now leave you for an hour, or two.
sp.stage: Ormasdes leads the Queen to the Door, and returns.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Madam, is this a fit time to enquire
Nearcus Story? may I now desire
You, to unriddle the bold claim, he makes?

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: You shall hereafter have it all at large,
Only know now, he us'd a violence,
In shew, with such unparallel'd deceits!
Such insolent demands, so cunning couch'd!
His threats, with humble looks, so plain disguis'd;
That at first fight, I found, I was surpriz'd;
Then, to avoid his purpose, I was forc'd,
To use such doubtfull word •… , to bring me off,
His madness did interpret his own way;
While I was safe, by what I wisely said,
To farther my escape, when so afraid!
Thus was Cleandras trust, and mine abus'd;
A baser treachery, was never us'd.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: You have inform'd me fully of his fact.
I suddainly will find Nearcus out,
And hurle such vengeance, on his curs'd head,
That all the World shall say, tis well he's dead.

sp.speaker: Near.
sp.l: Tis strange, I hear not of Ormasdes yet!
If he oblige me really! I'm his,
If not! I shall resume my first resolves,
This his delay, begets more jealousies
Then my impatient burning heart, can bear.—

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: —Now Sir, how have I prosper'd in your hands?

sp.speaker: Ormasdes.
sp.l: As you deserve.

sp.speaker: Nearcus.
sp.l: How is that?

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: With much scorn rejected.

sp.speaker: Near.
sp.l: Is that my me •… rit, in your opinion?

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: In mine, as in Cleandras, and in all!
Who have heard the ground of your false claim,
Which the fair Princess, and her Servants tell;
—A Treachery so base, an act so foul!
That all do think Nearcus has no soul.

sp.speaker: Near.
sp.l: This you dare justifie?

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: I had not dar'd to tell it else! me thinks
My looks might shew, my business was to find
You out, and now to let you know, I must
Defend the Princess, in a cause so just.
—Before I knew Valerianas heart,
Or was at all acquainted with my own;
I Judg'd your cause, against her innocence.
But now inform'd the right from all, I find
No argument, in Justice to compell,
Such a forc'd promise to Nearcus made,
Should now to Leonatus be perform'd.
Your juggling Arts, and your disguised Name,
With your unworthy force, ore-throws your claim

sp.speaker: Near.
sp.l: You are become a subtle Orator,
Since you convers'd with Ladies; but I shall
Your great Eloquence, with this steele convince;
I am not to be frighted by big words,
We now must try the temper of our swords.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: We must indeed, though I lament, my hand
Should harm a man, unto the Queen aly'd.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: Shall that scruple, & this good sword once more
Teach you to call for help? as heretofore!

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: I may change your opinion, with my own.

sp.speaker: Near.
sp.l: Come then.
sp.stage: They Fight, Ormasdes runs him through, Disarmes him.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Get Surgeons for Nearcus presently;
My hurt is slight.
sp.stage: Enter Surgeons, or Servants, who carry off Nearcus.
Enter the Queen, in Valerianas Chamber, with her, and attended by Old Titus, Old Nearcus, Lords and Ladies, a full Train.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Tis by your good nature, Valeriana,
That this mans evil spirit threatens us,
Had you reveal'd Nearcus treach •… ry!
His punishment had suted with his crime.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: Madam, I do confess my le •… ity▪
May have imbolden'd him to higher ills,
Which my just complaint, might have prevented;
But then, how hard a censure should I again?
By ruining so Eminent a man.
Who from his principles of honour fell,
Through love to me; though I cōtemn'd his hopes,
His passion made me pitty his distress,
So far, as his first errour to forgive,
In hope he might in better order live.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: You argue well, and ought to justifie
Your gentle disposition, to forgive.
Mercy, does 〈◊〉 young Princess, much adorn,
But I am bound to vindicate my self,
My Nation suffers, if I be not just,
He is the first, that ever dar'd asperse
The Citherean Name, by such a fact,
As no past Chronicle, can parallel!
I shake to think, how great your danger was!
And how much greater might have been my shame
To trust a man, who values not his fame.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: Let not his faults your anger higher raise,
The punishment he feels, by ill success,
Is a just doom, for his unworthiness.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: His sentence must, to after times appear,
Least my story be blemish'd with a thought,
That I, did wink at such a crime as this!
My people will exclaim, the Gods will frown,
If such a wickedness unpunisht pass!

He must dy •…
Valeriana, his house
Be burnt, the ashes scatter'd in the Ayre,
With prayerst' appease our Cit •… erian Gods,
We cannot offer a less Sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: For my sa •… e, let his doom, be banishment.
If I have any favour in your Eyes?
Make not me guilty by that Sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Rise M •… dam, you shall govern as you please.
sp.stage: Enter to them Ormasdes, and Young Titus.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Ormasdes, are you hu •… t▪ by that vil'd m •…

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: It is too littl •… , to be call'd a wound!
I come now, to beg Nearcus pardon;
Twas I that did inforce him to this fight.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: And I, most wrong'd, who freely do forgive;

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: The wrong was done to me Valeriana,
I put you in his power, my trust, he broke;
My honour, for your safety, was ingag'd!
The Citherean honour calls for Justice,
Against so barbarous a breach of Faith;
Nor was it you provok'd, but were compell'd
By him to fight, for innocence aspers'd!

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Madam, though I shall never justifie
Nearcus actions; his misfortune may
Admit excuse; Because humane nature
Is subject to passions, which the best men
Can never mannage, as they ought! how then;
May Valeriana's beauty guilty be?
That did excite Nearcus love; and led
Him into this distraction, past his power!
To manage his own heart, (as we think best;)
If so! tis she has turn'd him to a Beast;
But when your Majesty shall call to mind,
The gallant service by this Mad-man done;
You will then pitty his Distraction.
sp.stage: Enter to them Nearcus, brought in a Chair.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: What means this boldness?

sp.speaker: Near.
sp.l: Madam, I come not to beg your pardon,
But to justifie my actions, and my self;
Against Ormasdes, who does now with-hold
Valeriana, my betroathed Wife,
Co •… rm'd by vows, in presence of the Gods.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Now Ormasdes! is he fit for pardon?

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Yes Madam, as a distracted person!

sp.speaker: Near.
sp.l: Why do you wrong my person, and my cause?
To call my just Title, a distraction;
Do me Justice Cleandra, or give me death!

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: You may have both your wishes in good time:
Cleobulus guard him to the Castle.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: Pray Madam, let his doom be banishment,
Because his Crime, went not beyond intent.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Madam, he must thank you, for his life then;
—Cleobulus see him a close prisoner,
Untill his wounds, permit his banishment.

sp.speaker: Near.
sp.l: I do your proffer'd mercies, all refuse,
And either Death, or Valeriana chuse

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Lead him to banishment: make him obey.

sp.speaker: Near.
sp.l: Hold alittle:—Cleandra looke, this way,
Tis Leonatus calls; he who at foyles,
The young Prince your Brother, slew;
And fled your Fathers rage, (untill his death!)
Then shelter'd by this borrow'd Name, return'd,
And in Nearcus Family secur'd,
By this disguise; liv'd as his onely Son,
Who dyed, as I return'd;—is it death yet?

sp.speaker: Qu
sp.l: No, this insolence, shall not change your doom,
Nor your confe •… t disguise, (long known to me,)
Force a punishment beyond the merrit
Of that sad mishap! which I believe
Was fatall accident! no purpos'd crime!
Though my Father look'd on his onely Son,
By your hand slain, with such revenging rage!
As might his loss become, and him ingage
To throw out yows, that Justice should persue
So great a Traytor, as he then thought you;
For your succession after me, became
His fancies object, which encreas'd your blame.
—But I, who have exactly been inform'd,
Of my dead Brothers love, and yours, now must
For that sad accident, to you be just.

sp.speaker: Near.
sp.l: I'le rather quit my innocence, then own
Your mercy, when you Justice do deny;
Give me the fair Princess, or give me death.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: I cannot with Justice, give you either;
How can I, a free Princes will compell?
Or how Ormasdes true pretence de •… y,
Or how afford you death, for that offence,
Which your unluckie hand, did act by chance.

sp.speaker: Near.
sp.l: Wou'd I had dyed, the day of my return,
Since great Cleandra dares not do me Right;
But suffers false Ormasdes to possess,
What is my due; Tall your mercy scorn,
And will the worst of Tyranny endu •… e.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: I have imploy'd you as my Brothers friend,
Thus long not at his Murtherer conniv'd!
And untill now, by force compell'd my face
To frequent smiles, in favor of your worth,
While my heart ak'd, to think what you had done!
But you of late, unworthy our great Name,
Have scandaliz'd the Citherean Fame
Boldly to own a Crime so great! as may insence,
The world to question your first innocense.
Which clearly shews, you are for mischief built,
That dar'd to entertain so base aguilt!
—My mercy may prove sin, unless betimes,
My Justice do prevent your farther crimes.

sp.speaker: Near.
sp.l: Must I be held? and baited thus to death!
Be torn, and tortur'd by a womans breath?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: See my Command obey'd Cleobulus.
—I shall take order for an Equipage
Fit for your great birth, and shall now confine
You to an Island near, from whence you may
Return, if you out-live me, and mine!
—Remove him hence.

sp.speaker: Ne.
sp.l: Hold a while!—curse on, curse light on you all,
Tyrants, cruel Tyrants, your juggling▪ Art
Lay by, and strike a Dagger through my heart;
—If Ormasdes any honour have in store?
He'l fight another bout upon the Shore,
As I take ship; and if I chance to Dye!
My soul shall then applaud thy Victory,
And sing thy praise to the infernal Ghosts,
That they may chuse thee Captain of their Hosts,▪
When thou com'st down!—Let not a Ladies word
D •… stroy▪ by piercing deeper then thy sword!—
—Will you not answer? cruel, and unjust!
Ye gods! why put you Scepters into womens trust?
Who crushes me to raise a Cowards Name!
Whom I will in the Elizium fields Defame,
No honor'd Ghost of Troy, shall there own thee,
The Grecian, and the Roman Souls, with me
Will trample on thy Cowards neck with scorn,
—Poor shadow of a gallant man, only born
To lye in Ladies laps, perfum'd, and curl'd!
—I'le Post thee •… oward, in the other World.
sp.stage: They force him away, on the Queen beck with he •… hand.

sp.speaker: Admi.
sp.l: Tis strange, that none of us should know him!

sp.speaker: Young Titus.
sp.l: The general opinion he was drown'd,
Made us not see through his disguise;

sp.speaker: Admir.
sp.l: But his strange passion does amaze me most.
Ormasdes wedding, will his frenzy cure;
When love does see no possibility,
Desires, and hopes, will vanish by degrees.

sp.speaker: You. Titus.
sp.l: We see dispairs, work often other wayes.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: He has disturb'd me, but I'le forget him;
—Valeriana come, let us consult
The Ceremony of your Wedding day,
Ormasdes joys, and yours, will blow away
The farther thought, of Leonatus crimes.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: Our Wedding Madam! I see no reason
For so great a hast! now we are secure.

sp.speaker: Or.
sp.l: Madam, since you have rais'd my hopes so high!
It were a sin, to doubt my destiny.
Yet say, when shall my thoughts so fixt remain?
That I may never think I dream again.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: Ormasdes, not too fast, we must proceed
With much discretion, to so great a deed!
The eyes of all this Nation, do behold
Our actions, and may think my part too bold,
If I again shall do; what I repent!
It would deserve a double punishment;
My over-hasty Love, was once my crime,
I must redeem that fault, by taking time
To finish, what so violent begun,
Least into greater errours, I do run;—
—A year or two's delay, will add much grace
To our young Love, which Time cannot deface.

sp.speaker: Orma.
sp.l: Why have you led me forth, with gentle gales?
Into this dangerous deep? why fill'd my sailes,
With such propitious winds? as would convey
Me safe to my wish'd Port, the nearest way.
Why do you now abstruct this happy course?
As if you wish'd for storms! or somthing worse!
Why thus fo •… sake the Light? to sail ith' dark,
As if you sought out hazzards, for this Bark,
In which, you are the onely fraight, that I,
Can fear to lose; by my mortality.
Oh! do not then my Joyes to time betray,
Least you do ruine all, by your delay!

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: How Valeriana! must this Scene of Love,
Fall from its height? and now no farther move!
Does your quick conquest of Ormasdes? make
Him less worthy? when we such pris'ners take,
As might our selves command! if they will serve!
We cannot give them more, then they deserve;
Consider well, least you, your self destroy,
If thus, you do defer Ormasdes joy!

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: Madam, you, and the world too well do know,
My Love to him, can now no higher grow!
I onely thus stand off, least he despise,
A conquest gain'd, without an enterprize.
And that my injur'd Sex, hereafter may
Judge of my innocence, by this delay;
Honour forbids, that we in hast ingage,
Rash actions often, ill events presage.
Though I, (like a tall ship that spreads her sails
When she is carried on, with prosperous gales;
To her wish'd Port!) do sigh, to be delay'd,
And blame the Remora, by which I'm staid.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: Honour, and Fancy, at great distance stand,
You have no argument for this command,
But your own nice, unnecessary thought,
By which your virtue, may become a fault!
Tis true, that my neglects to woman kind,
May urge, that I should now no favour find;
Till my whole life be spent, to gain a bliss,
To crown my latests hours with joyes, like this!
I do confess such judgement were my due
From all the women in the world, but you,—
Who have no argument, nor a pretence,
Why you, should prove the Rod for my offence.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: Ormasdes true, I only now would prove
By some short time, the temper of your Love;
And shew the world, that mine was not in hast,
Though its first motion mov'd so fierce and fast!
It makes me blush to think, that this great Queen,
And her whole Nation, have such weakness seen!
As all commanding Love, forc'd me to show,
Oh! tis a bold attempt, when women wooe!

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: What ere the vulgar think, great Princes may
The dictates of their greater souls obey;
Tis a self-doubting sin, when you alone,
Dare not avow, what gods, and men do own.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: These cautious wayes, are only fit for such
As have suspected virtues; you are much
Above the reach of Censures;—twas I,
That woo'd him first, mine be the infamy,
Who boast the active part, with the successe,
And would not for the world, it had been lesse!
It does become me, now to see your hands
United, as your hearts!—If my commands
Be slighted! and my self not understood!
When I require what's for your mutuall good,
I shall repent the kindness, I have shown.
And wish, you never had Ormasdes known.

sp.speaker: Vale.
sp.l: Madam, when you command, I must submit;
—But will Ormasdes waking think it fit?
Now to accept this Ring? and safer keep
What he desires, then when h' last did sleep;
I had some pleasure, and no little pain,
To put it on, and steal it off again.
But now, since gods and you, do all agree!
Receive this bond of my Captivity.

sp.speaker: Ormas.
sp.l: I kiss the hand, that freely gives it now,
May Thunder strike me dead, when I do bow
To other Earthly Power, or wish a bliss,
That Heaven can give, the Gods allowing this!
Ormasdes heart, shall into insence turn,
And in bright flames, before this Altar burn;
So long as my fair Saint, does not despise,
To look upon so mean a Sacrifice—
—To you great Queen, I know not what to say,
How to express a gratitude, that may
Declare the glory of your life to be
A perfect pattern, for Posterity.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Brave Lord, your Triumphs, & your Trophies still
Increase our wonder! and our Nation fill
With such Esteem, as all my people may,
With Honour, keep your Wedding, Holy-Day.
And in our Story, after Ages show,
Friendship, and Virtue, did together grow.

div.p: LONDON, Printed by T. Mabb, For John Pleyfere, at the White Bear, in the Upper-Walk of the New-Exchange; And Thomas Hors-man, next Door to the Signe of the Three Kings in the Strand, 1664.

list.item: Pandora, a great Lady of the Prince his Family.
Lonzartes, Right Heire to the Principality.
Clearcus, a Lord of the Prince his Kindred.
Silvander, a Young Lord of the Court.

lg.l: LOvers to You I come, without a Bribe,
From one yt boasts himself of your own Tribe,
And therefore hopes, that your good Natures may
On his behalf, above your Judgements sway:
What you'le see here is naturall, all pretence
He disavowes, to Wit, or Eloquence:
With Friendship he presents you, and with love,
Such as are wont in his free breast to move,
Such passions as he feels, our Author writes,
And humours such, as he observes, indites:
From Conversation bringing to the Stage,
What he does think, will please the present Age.
And if you do not grudge your time here spent,
He will accept it for a Complement.

div.head: PANDORA: THE Scene in Syracutia.
FIRST ACT.
div.stage: Enter Lonzartes and Clearchus in long Grey Cloakes over their Rich Cloaths, with Sanga and Geta, two Lacques carrying Lanthorns, the two Lords Enter a private House, the two Servants stay.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: COme Geta, our Lords have no more use of us, we may go sleep!

sp.speaker: Geta.
sp.p: Tis a fair time indeed to sleep, when day begins to break?—this is a lew'd life, that our Lords do lead.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Why man? the Night was made for labourers to rest; and for great Lords to Revel in▪ come away.

sp.speaker: Geta
sp.p: My Lord, is not half so ill as thine.

sp.speaker: Sanga.
sp.p: Whats that to thee, or me, come away; we'l go to Beggars Hall, and be as merry as our Lords.

sp.speaker: Geta.
sp.p: No, no, I will no more sully my credit, in thy company; I converse with our tall Dary-Maid, who affords me Honours, thou canst not guess at Sanga! Oh the great Felicities! that do belong to chast imbraces?

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: I like Imbraces well.

sp.speaker: Geta
sp.p: I mean by Wed-lock man.

sp.speaker: San
sp.p: A Cox-comb thou art, and a Cuckold thou wilt be; adiew Fool.

sp.speaker: Geta.
sp.p: Adiew Rogue.
sp.stage: A noyse within, Re-enter Clearcus, and Lonzartes. in the Dark.

sp.speaker: Clearcus.
sp.p: Botts on thy slippery heeles; we are undone!

sp.speaker: Lonzartes.
sp.p: Let us draw, and stand upon guard, I hear some call within!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: What was that strange noyse, you made?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: At the bottom of the stairs, I fell, which gave the Alarum to the doggs, and they wak'd all the Family!

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: Oh my Lord! what have you done? all the House are up, pray stand close a while,—are you alone?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Yes, yes.

sp.speaker: Lonzartes.
sp.p: Thou art a very Villain Clearcus, thus to betray a poor Wench, that loves thee; and to force me accept a Favour, I abhor to think on.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Be the blame mine, I have no joy in any thing, unless my Friend Participate;—if I have any skill in Woman; you will thank me for this favour, and say, you never had the like of Angelica.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Suppose she will not consent? must I ravish her?—you say she knows not of my coming.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I swear she does not.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Would I were out again, these Romances please not me;—pray how must I proceed?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Thus, she is in Bed, the Room is dark, I'le entertain her with discourse, while you undress; then I'le retyre, and soon return with Light, to let her see my friend and I, must be as one man to her.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I wonder all women do not hate thee, thou dost abuse all them that trust thee.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: You are deceiv'd Lonzartes, such silly girles, do take it for a complement, to recommend them to a Noble Friend!

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Well, I must now be subject to thy will, and do submit to do, what I detest!—me thinks this is a kind of Rape I undertake;—thou art too wild for my Converse Clearcus.

sp.speaker: Clear.
sp.p: Hold your peace.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: Hist, hist, my Lord!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Here, here.

sp.speaker: Wom.
sp.p: Give me your hand, softly, softly, follow me.
sp.stage: Exeunt Woman leading them off, holding hands.
Enter the Old Prince of Syracusa, with Silvander, Aristonicus, Clothero, Ormuseus, and •… rain.

sp.speaker: Prince▪
sp.p: How does Lonzartes bear his Suppression Aristonicus? now he is full-man grown.

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.p: Like a wise man S •… r, that will not seem to see, what he cannot remedy.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: I have better thoughts for him, then he has for himself; if Clearcus spoyle him not!

sp.speaker: Ari.
sp.p: When more years have overcome some evils, incident to youth, I hope he will be worthy your highest favours Sir.

sp.speaker: Pri
sp.p: Some of you should advise him to a little more sobriety, then Clearcus will allow of;—I apprehend Silvander, that the Corinthian will quarrel, for my refusing to treat his Marriage with Theodosia, whom I design another way;——she has a •… ersion to him.

sp.speaker: Sil
sp.p: The Princes may be excus'd for her dislike, unto so fierce a man, the Corinthian Prince, is all fire, and fury, which does fright, not win affection.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: If Theodosia will be advised by me, I shall provide better for her;—you know Lonzartes right Silvander! if he were reclaim'd, I would wish him to my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p:
I have some thoughts Sir, that Lonzartes does Consort with wild Clearcus, and complies in all his Vanities, onely to avoid your Jealousie, of
his higher thoughts of interest in the State! he is no fool Sir.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: I wish it prove not too much his Nature, to be so debauch'd, for he has not higher thoughts of State interest▪ then I have for him; he has been wrong'd Silvander, and I will endeavour to do him right if he'l be worthy of it.
sp.stage: Enter Lonzartes and Clearcus in a Garden.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Why, this grave face to me Lonzartes?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Thou art so wild, that I have lost my credit by conversing with thee, which I must redeem, by keeping better company hereafter.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Wisely resolved, and in good time declared;—I have indeed observ'd, that you of late converse with Ladies, and delight in rich lac'd Sattin, and in Silver Petticoates; as if you meant to turn Apostate, from the freedom we have had, and now seek your game in secret, my Lonzartes.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: If I should, pray which is most Honourable? And most sutable to my Quality? The dayly terrour of getting such diseases, as •… nhabit your dark houses, has frighted me into better purposes.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Your Quality! I wish your 〈◊〉 had all the Ladies you desire, so I might have like freedom with their Maids.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I shall not spoyle your Market, but leave you those cheap Cattel, at your own price.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
See the difference now, between your Pride, and my Humility; you have studied, learn'd discourses to, such as must justifie your conversion (as you call it) but have never weighed the difference of our crimes;—such thoughts Lonzartes, do move, my tender Conscience, to take what I
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
can find, for ready money; which I freely enjoy, without those frights you daily feel.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Thou dost mistake me, and exclaimest against crimes, I never understood.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: You can counterfeit I know, and may cozen all the World but me! I will not give my freedom up, to such follies as you serve, to be Master of all your wishes.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I shall not labour to convert you, but will take leave to dispise your mean waies, while you envy mine.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Envy! by Violinas eyes, I do dispise you, and your wayes, and will wager any thing you dare, that I enjoy this night a beauty more exact, then any cloath of Gold Dame you treat with, I envy you! no, I pitty you Lonzartes, that after such experience, at your years, you should be fool'd so;—confess now seriously, if you have ever met a better shape, a softer, or a whiter skin, or any more sweet, or more bewitching fair, and lovely, then my Angelica.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: If I have not! what then?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Why? she shall be Fine, and rich •… raid, when I so please! I can call her Sultaness too! and by my fancy, raise her above those, the World allows of.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I do believe thee, and thy fancy, alike Extravagant.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: But why so serious on the suddain? and so dull? you shall have good Chear, and good Company to night, at the old place.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I shall get an ill Conscience by it!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
That sauce, agrees not with the Dainties
we must feed on, pray lay by your Conscience, untill morning.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I wish I were well rid of thee, all thy Rhetorick, shall never ingage me, to meet such company again.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Why pray, how can you spend your time better?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I do begin to hate my self, and will love thee no longer.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Very good;—Are not you the most debauch'd man in Syracusa? (except my self!) how come you by this Impudence? to blush for going to a merry meeting? Is not your own Lodging, beyond a Scandal? are not all the Wenches in that Street, your Pentioners?—not love me! I will study to scorn you, and your love for ever; I dispise a man that does forsake his Principles.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I begin to hate thy over-much lewdness, and to see my own Deformities.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Not love me!

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Come, I do love thee, too well I love thee, shall we go home, and put off this meeting?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Lonzartes, though I do love your Friendship, I do hate this Humour in you, that thus would lay a blemish on me.
sp.stage: Enter to them Lindamira and Teretia, not at first seen.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: See Lindamira, the two wild Princes are in our way, how shall we get by 'um?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Put on a confidence beyond theirs, and 'twill amaze them!

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Can that be?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I'le be your Forlorne Hope, do but second me, and I'le secure your pass this time;—You'l see them start, shoot aside, as from a Baza •… iske! the honest woman!

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Barbarous!—I have heard indeed, they shun all virtuous women!

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: They alwaies look over us, as if they saw us not; but where they have an interest, or hope to gain it, they can like subtil Serpents, humbly creep, to flatter and betray.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: A prize, a prize Lonzartes, each of us one; let us reconcile for this booty, and dispute at leasure;—you close walk invites;—which will you assault?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Neither, they are both virtuous?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Who knows that? have they done sucking?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Dost thou think there be none virtuous, beyond their infancy!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Yes, much too many, but I hope better of these; give me the woman, and keep her virtue to your self:—I'le charge 'um both, there may be a Critical minute for me;—fair Ladies.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Hold my Lord, you are out at first, one of us is very brown I assure you.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: You do not think your self so, or if you do, you think brown the be •… t Madam.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I do indeed, think my beauty such, as may prejudice your Lordship, if you dwell on it; which gave me boldness, to interrupt your set Speech; least you engage past retreating;—our business is to find the Princess.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: And ours, to entertain those, who have nothing else to do.

sp.speaker: Lin
sp.p: How would you entertain us my Lord?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: As young Gallants, use to treat fair Ladies; with love, and our best service.

sp.speaker: Lin
sp.p: I have no imployment for so great a Servant as your Lordship, and for love, I understand it not.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: That you may do is my ambition.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Nay, if you be come to ambition already! I guess your love will grow to such a Monster, in a moment, that I dread the thought on't.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: You cut me off so short, you cannot apprehend, what I would say.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Therefore I do it, because I do not care to hear.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: What have I done Madam, to merrit this neglect from you?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: In the behalf of all our sex, I am the chosen Champion, against all men, who do believe, all Women do admire 'um.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: When shall I have leave to speak? that I may inform you better.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: When I have done.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: When will that be?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: When I am gone.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: How can you be inform'd in absence?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: As much as I desire to know, I know already;—my good wishes shall attend your Lordship;—come Teretia; we may finde the Princess in the other walks.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Now Sir, how do you like this Ladies me •… tle?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Why well, I like her, and her humour very well.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: You thought her a sure prize.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I did but hope so at the first, now I am sure of her, she is my own, if ever we do meet alone;—by this severity, she has cozen'd Teretia, and you, and confirm'd me.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I must laugh, to think how thou art mistaken, in this innocent freedom virtuous women use, and would give a good summe, to see thee but converse a moneth or two, with persons of Honour, which I believe would reclaim thee, and fix those virtues, now lost in a Chaos of wild actions.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I marry, if you could shew me a woman, that would not be won; I would fancy some delight, to pass away an hour or two, at ilde times; but all that I do meet with, are mine, before I wish it; so that I am alwayes forc'd to stand upon my guard amongst 'um.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Thats no wonder, amongst those women you converse with;—shall I chuse you a mistris? and if you get her! let the reproach be mine.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Shall she be worth my pains? if so! I will think on't, when I have time to throw away;—come will you go with me yet?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I'le stay here a while.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I'le go besore then, and make ready for you.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: What pitty tis, such parts should be so drown'd!—
sp.l: Though I resolve to quit, I'me guilty still
If longer I do countenance his ill.
sp.stage: Enter to him, as in the Garden, Theodocia, Pandora, Lindamira, Teretia, and Ladies, and Silvander.

sp.speaker: Theodocia.
sp.p: Lonzartes I have been laughing at Lindamiras relation of Clearcus humour; she sayes, she has abus'd him his own way, in the behalf of all honest women, whom he declares against.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: The encounter indeed was pleasant, but the successe is beyond her guess! for she thinks, that her neglects, have dash'd his hopes, by which he is grown confident, that her seeming scornes, were onely to dazle our eyes, while he doubts not to gain an interest.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I wish him joy my Lord, of his quick Victory, the next encounter, will decide this difference of Opinions.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: But how dare you Lindamira, enter the lists of wit? with young Clearcus, who has the sharpest tongue in Syracusa.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: There is no contest so easie, his whole discourse to women, is ever of love, or something like it! and does believe that all our souls, delight in nothing else, which makes me interrupt him still as he begins, and never hear him out.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Is that civil, to a person, of his Quality?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Is he not angry, when you slight him so?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: No Madam, I am his mirth, and he is mine.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: If Pandora would permit! I do fancy his conversion might be wrought by her, and his Eclips'd virtues, made to shine brighter then his vices do.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: 'Twill be a noble undertaking Madam.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I wish he were within my cure.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: We'l joyne our forces Lindamira, for I shall easily consent unto so good a work, as may reclaim so great a person as Clearcus; a man so near alied unto the Duke!—but how must this Charitable work be done?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: If you Madam, will admit his visits? for a Moneth or two, the cure of course will follow; for he who never yet convers'd with civil woman, will surely be concern'd, when he shall see the harmless mirth, that virtue does allow, to persons of your Quality!

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: So, I be obliged no further then to civil visits, his birth does require that for him, which I deny to no man.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Leave the rest to me.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: How happy are you Cousin, that may dispose of your self as you please! I must speak, and look, and move, as my Father, and the State direct, me.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Great Princes indeed, are bound to some strict Rules, most Subjects understand not?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Your Highness complains without a cause, we hear the Duke will leave you to your own choise, only he will recommend.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: When Parents recommend, tis so like command, it frights me to think whom it may be.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Now you are safe from the Corinthian, have no fear untill you see occafion for it.

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: I wish my dear Cousin, you would marry too, I should then like it better I now dread to put on that yoak, by all the World so much desired?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Will my being in the pound, get your Highness out off it? why would you have me run the hazzard, to loose that happiness I now am sure of? by a single life;—If men did ever appear in their own likeness! we might chuse some one, amongst many, worth the having, but in our fights, they are alwayes disguis'd in such shapes, and humours, as they believe we like best, and so cozen us, and themselves too; for if they make us unhappy, it seldome failes, but we make them so.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: No Oracle ever spoke truer; I am of your Sect Madam, (as to matters of Faith!) yet I would gladly have a Husband, though it be dangerous to put my heart into anothers keeping (And as my learn'd Author sayes,) to give my freedom up, unto I know not whom! (nor ever can do, till I have him)—this were a sadd condition Madam, if we had not the same Arts to cozen them, that think to cozen us.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Would I could get a merry heart, like yours I indamira.

sp.speaker: Lin
sp.p: I'le present your Highness with a piece of mine, I have enough for both.

sp.speaker: Messenger.
sp.p: Madam, The Prince calls for you;

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: I attend him, pray Cousin go with me to my Father.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: A few such Excellent women would make this World a Paradice!—how have I walk'd in the dark, till now? how strangely been missed, by my affection to Clearcus? that have approv'd, and acted in all his ills; begun upon design, and led on, till custome has almost chang'd my nature, but will no more.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: How now Lonzartes? walking alone? take •… eed the Devil find thee not at leasure.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: A greater then thy self, can hardly find me.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Very gravely replyed, if I mistake not, you are whimpering after some great Lady, and now practizing to play the fool wisely, to spend your time, adoring you know not who, nor why.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Thou art still ith' wrong.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Let us meet then, at the old place to night.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: That's a freedom, I shall never take more, you have converted me, beyond all the Homilies I ever read, you have made me ashamed of my self for being so long like you.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
Oh Hypocrite! what new piece have you
got? that I must not be trusted with; come tell me, and I'le cry up your Austere purpose, and rail at your conversion, as if I did believe it.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: VVhen you see me next in ill company, I am then that Hypocrite you mention.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Out upon these tender Consciences, they spoyle more mirth, then they are worth; let old folks hear Homilies, while we enjoy the time we have, and not whine away our youth, on dreams of virtue, which signifie we know not what.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Peace Clearcus, thou art not half so ill as thou appearest; but dost glory in talking worse, then thou canst be.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: VVhat should we talk of more then what we most delight in?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Of nothing less, because we often do delight in what we ought not own;—Is't not enough to offend the Gods through frailty, which perverse nature does invite us to; but we must provoke Heaven, beyond sence, and appetite, by our discourse, as if we studied to defie those Powers, we ought to tremble at.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I hate Hypocrisie.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: And I abhor to aggravate my crimes, by such unnecessary boastings, as thy wild brain delights in; when I offend I am sorry for it, dost thou all honesty dispise, all virtue slight?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
How Lonzartes, will you confine honesty, and virtue, to the fruition of one woman only? Fie, what a scandal is this to man-kind, as if there were no honesty, nor virtue but in such chast breasts as yours? what an affront to this good company, pray speak Gentlemen, is any here
of his opinion? can you Lonzartes shew me one young man, that looks as he were guilty? or any so old, who would be thought so weak?—Is this a fit design, to set up your Title to the Dukedom?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I see this is not the hour for your Conversion.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Nor shall ever live to see that hour, I hope.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Nor you I fear, ever live to tast, and relish the true felicity obtain'd, by such a conquest on thy self; but I will pray for thee, and thy conversion.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I had rather your Lordship were at Jerusalem, then see that day of my conversion; what have I done Lonzartes? to deserve such ill from you, do not provoke me to a revenge.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Revenge, for what?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Can you aske for what? suppose the gods should hear your prayers, and turn my heart, how miserable a man were I, how should I spend my time, for forty years to come; Is it not enough to forsake your cause, but you must seduce me too? Lonzartes, if you pray for me, I shall curse you heartily; I dare stay no longer with him.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: If this brave man this humour could expell,
His virtues would his vices far excell.
sp.p:
I have put on this Cloak of wantonness onely to avoid being thought a serious man, least the Duke grow jealous of my pretentions to his Crown;—while the Duke is civil and I am safe;—he shall be so too?—But if I finde
designes against me; I have Friends, and force enough, to gain my right by this;—Oh but Theodocia does unman me quite;—when I look on her, all these high thoughts do vanish, and I become the humblest creature in the Court:—
sp.l: I have no Title, that I ere shall owne,
Unless she daine to raise me to the Throne.

div.head: THE SECOND ACT.
div.stage: Enter Lonzartes alone, Clearcus hearkning at the Door.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: OH Cloris, Cloris! what stange unwonted pains I feel? what fears? what new disease conceales my blood?—if it be love, twill not offend the gods, because my soul does now rejoyce to find, Beauty and Virtue so divine, that both may be well worshipp'd at one Shrine.
sp.stage: Clearcus chaps him hard on the Shoulder.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Are you talking in your sleep Lonzartes? or is it some divine meditation, thus transports you?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: You are too rude Clearcus.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I cry you mercy Sir, you can be angry then I see; I thought your conversion, had set you above such passions, as we wicked men are subject too.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I do confess thou didst make me start, and speak hastily, but I am not angry, nor can be with thee.

sp.speaker: Cle▪
sp.p: I'le try your temper presently,—Oh! Beauty and Virtue so Divine, both may be worshipped in one shrine; Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: What of this, you heard me repeat an old Song.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: An old Song to a new Tune Lonzartes: dost thou pray for my Conversion this way? must I get a Cloris to sigh after?—as thou dost;—I have heard all, and have observ'd thee too, I and do guess who Cloris is,—come, tell me quickly, that way to oblige me to silence; for if by my own skill, I do discover her, I'le lay thee open to the World, tell me who Cloris is, least I tell thee; Adiew.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: How can he discovee that I love, when I know it not yet my self?—Yet I may admire her, and by my adoration of her virtues.—
sp.l: Be by them, from all meaner passions freed,
When this new virtue, shall my vice exceed.

sp.speaker: Geta.
sp.p:
What the Devil ailes my Lord? his wonted mirth is changed into
〈◊〉 , and twenty times a day, he sends me on sleeveless Errants, that he may be alone; I think Lord Clearcus will prove the wisest man at last;—I have been five times this morning to enquire, if the Princess be in health! if she be stirring, or if near ready! if she go to the Temple!—And after dinner I must enquire, if she have dyned! if she comes forth in publick! if she ride abroad; and thus twenty times a day, he tires me, with these silly Errants, when I might aske them all at once, and save much labour; I'le try if I can find some way to contract these Embassies;—tis well for my Lord, that his man is wiser then himself.
sp.stage: Enter Silvander with Lindamira, and her Maid.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Do not my looks Lindamira enough express what I would say?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Yes, to me, who do discern your passion thus suppressed, more clear, then by those loud noyses, which some Lovers most delight in.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: But how shall I be assured, this is not Raliery?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Cannot you judge by my looks, as well as I by yours? what kind of security do you require? I have no Citizens that will be bound for my good behaviour!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: A serious word or two, with a kind look confirm'd, will secure me against the World.

sp.speaker: Lin
sp.p: Will this look serve? and I am yours, suffice for words? with this hand given from my heart! ingage beyond your wish.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: It does, may I be—

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Nay, no strange lines I beseech you, make me not jealous by professing more then I expect.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I am confirmed.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I shall try your temper, if my merry humour hold!

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: 'Tis that free Innocence, I most adore.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: And that I can afford enough off, at an easie rate.
sp.stage: Enter Clearcus to them, Silvander goes off.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Your Lordship was going another way, pray let not me divert you, my lodging is far off.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Madam, I have long sought an opportunity to kiss your hands there.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: You may do it here, and save the labour of going so far for nothing.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Do you call that honour nothing, which I do prize above the World? and would give all my interest on Earth, to purchase one kiss of your fair hand, by a free consent.

sp.speaker: Lin
sp.p: The World is little beholding to your Lordship, for so low a value, that will give all your interest on Earth, for a kiss of my hand, and this I must in civility, look, as if I did believe.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I'le swear it Madam.

sp.speaker: Lin
sp.p: Thats as easily done, as said, but I am hard of Faith.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: How shall I obtain more credit?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I'le shew you a short way; bring me a conveyance of half your Land, and you shall have two kisses of my hand, three if you please; and as you like your Market, you may have more, for the other half of your Estate! and this is much cheaper then to give all the World for such an honour.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Why do you mock me? who truly love, and honour you above all women! by those fair eyes I do.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: How can I believe it? when I know you talk thus to every woman that you meet.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: May my hopes nere prosper, if you are not the only object of my heart.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: No touching good my Lord, my Affairs calls me away, I must be gone.
sp.stage: He proffers to kiss her hand.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: And I must wait on you home Madam.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Ile rather stay here this Twelve-month, then give your Lordship that trouble.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Am I such a Monster, in the opinion of all Women, as you make me?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I must take care you make not me one;—Oh happy deliverance!
sp.stage: Enter to them, Theodocia, and Pandora, and Silvander.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: This is such a piece of nicety, as I nere met before;—these are no company for me.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Stay Clearcus, I would speak with you;—my Cousin Pandora tells me, you Court Lindamira, which her self does not much deny.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I am practizing I must confess, how to talk to Ladies, and have learnt some Speeches to that purpose, whereof Lindamira has had her share.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: You have mocked her then! and intend her onely for your mirth!

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Methinks his silence, and that legg, shewes more love to me, then I know what to do with.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Excellent Girle! how she playes with his wanton humour!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Nay, if Lonzartes fall on me too? I shall be over-whelmed with wisdome.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Now there is some hope of him, his look is Civillized already.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Are you not pleased Clearcus? to see the whole Court concerned for you? to see your self so valued, methinks it should stir up the Noble Blood of your great Ancestors, to set you on to such actions, as may out-shine their stories, and not loose one day more, in your wild waies.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Madam, Your Language, and your Looks, agree with your great soul; I can be proud to be so taught, when the Princess Theodocia, and you direct, twere great stupidity to shew neglect;—but in my Opinion Madam, one of a Family is enough to be a Saint;—twould take from great Lonzartes credit, and render his conversion no rarity; if I should become virtuous too.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Pandora, and I, are much obliged to you, for your good opinion of us, I wish all our •… ex were so too.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: My opinion and my practise, differ very much Madam; I do honour virtue in your Sex, as much as any man; but my Tallent lies the other way, Lonzartes does enough Illustrate the Platonnick Name, and Eminently maintain, that high Seraffick flame, which is above my reach.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p:
Tell me now Clearcus, is there not more
relish in this Conversation? then with your Getinas, and your Angelinas!—that blush shewes well, there is some hopes of grace in that blush.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Hold your pratling, my conversion does not belong to you.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I hope I may direct you to a Lady, that will work that wonder.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Hold your peace then, till we be alone.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: We'l be gone Pandora, and not hinder so good a work;—you shall neither of you go with us,—but if you please Clearcus, Lindamira may walk with you a little longer.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: No Madam, I have enough of her already, she out-wits me; we shall nere agree.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I have got credit enough for a young Souldier, by my honourable Retreat, from so hot a charge.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Let us now persue our Argument, for thy Conversion.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: It comes on a pace;—what a fine Gentleman are you grown, since the Spirit of Chastity has possest you? and I must live chast, that I may have the Honour, and Felicity to be in love!—to be a fool! to intangle my self in •… etts, that I shall nere get out of! I'le none of it.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p:
Let my old Friend-ship so far prevail, that on my request you will sometimes converse with Pandora, if thy visits do ingage her to undertake thy cure! and she do work that Miracle! she must value what her self has made worthy of her
self; for so wilt thou be, if thy wandring fancy, were once fixt?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: So then all this bussle, is to make me in love; though you know, I have been a thousand times in love already.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I Clearcus, I know thy thousands, but I would have thee once in love.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I never will be mad, as you are; yet to give you, and the World satisfaction in this point; I will condemn my self to one Months pennance, and make experiment to look, and talk as idlely with Pandora, as you do with your Divinest Cloris!—If I were sure Pandora were not to be won; I could fancy a pretty kind of pastime, by raising my desires to hopes of what I cannot have! but I could never meet a woman yet, that was impregnable; and my nature is not capable of being converted, by any that I can conquer;—Pray Su •… at my Chamber this night.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I will not fayle, if you will go with me unto Pandora?—
sp.l: And visit her, while this good motion's warm,
'Gainst all your feares, I'le fit you with a charm.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I go.
sp.stage: Enter Pandora with Lindamira and Ladies in her Chamber, and Silvander.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Lindamira you must be my second, they will be two, to one else.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Gladly Madam, I cannot wish a gentler Enemy, then him that thinks he has me at his mercy.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: But if you be over-sharp upon him, you may hinder the great work, we undertake! and make him hate all honest Women for our sakes.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I shall use him with more Art, and lead him on with hopes, that all our Sex do scramble for him;—if I can fit his Fancy, and his Wit, I'le ingage him in a concern for you, and then mannage my young Gallant to my will, till I confute his common places, so often urged to the prejudice of Ladies, I cannot fancy better sport, then to see him mad in love with you Madam.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: The gods forbid, I would not cure him at that rate, for my own sake, and his; least that prove a greater evil, then he now has; I shall be very careful, to give him no incouragement, for thoughts of that nature, my undertaking is not beyond a common civillity, as to all others of his Rank.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: That will do it, if I mistake not;—and catch you both I hope,—here he comes?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Madam, I have brought my Friend to kiss your hand.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Thus far Madam, in order to my ingagement, I have given you the trouble of the first visit, I ever made against my will.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Your Lordship, does me honour; came you now from Court?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Yes Madam, and left the Princess Theodocia in great complements with her kind Father, who has now declared against the proud Corinthian, and given Theodocia her free choice where she please.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: You tell me News, beyond my hopes, this will raise the Princess drooping Spirits again; I wonder she is not here by this time.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: The Duke and she, are not yet parted Madam;—how now Lindamira, are you tonguetyed? no welcome for my Friend, to encourage him to like of civil company;—You look as if you feared to loose your Gallant.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: No, no, she knows she has too fast hold of my heart, to part so easily.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Tis Honour enough for me, to be in the number of your Martyrs Sir.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: How long have you two been acquainted?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Ever since last night Madam.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: And dost thou sigh already?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: 'Tis onely to give you warning, by my harmes

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I thank your care, but I am arm'd against the World.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: That's good News Lonzartes, there is some hope, she has made firm resolves against Wedlock; that I may assault her with security.—

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: You may, you may.

sp.speaker: Cle
sp.p: Madam, You speak, as if you held mankind at a defiance.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: By way of Marriage, I do, but I can value all men that I see worthy.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: He must be a bold man, who does designe beyond the favours you allow, but have you made vowes against marriage Madam?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: No vowes, but such resolves, as are unchangable.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: You are severe to men.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: If all Women were of your opinion Madam? how should the World be Peopled?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I marry Madam, that was well urg'd.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I thought Lindamira you would have been on my side

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: So I am, when you are in the right, this is our common cause; Suppose you bring these two Lords, and they bring twenty more, to be of your judgement, and this Heresie should spread; what will become of us, who think of nothing else but Marriage?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: She tells you true Madam, when her own concern is at stake, you may excuse her.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I do, and will make good my argument alone.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Never to Marry Madam?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Never my Lord, is my full resolve.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: You are the happiest, and the wisest Lady living! and I the joyfullest man, if you'l permit me to adore you at this distance, for I am of your own opinion Madam.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Two Fannaticks well met.

sp.speaker: Pan
sp.p: So long as your respects be free from love, my house is open to you.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: You are all witnesses, that this Lady does adopt me her avow'd Gallant, on the conditions before mentioned:—you give me leave Madam to talk of love, and to carry up this jest, as high, as he who really does love.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I do, so it be ever in Publick; all private visits, and all whisperings are excepted.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: 'Tis enough Madam;—This is a pretty kind of Entertainment, I never thought of: Lonzartes thou art in the right, this will be sport beyond my hope.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: But how does Lindamira like, to see her new Gallant, thus taken from her?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: 'Tis her own fault, she might have fix'd me another way, if she had been wise.

sp.speaker: Pan
sp.p: Indeed Lindamira, I thought not of your concern, and did conclude too rashly, but I will use my interest on your behalf.

sp.speaker: Lin
sp.p: 'Twill not be needfull Madam, I know all his professions to you, are meant to me.

sp.speaker: Cle
sp.p: Very prettily contrived,—This is a new kind of wit I never heard of; so then you are to love me, in spite of your teeth, and I you, in spite of mine; what will this come to at last?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Mirth man, all the year a constant mirth:—Is not this better then spending your time in a smoaky house, with your old Acquaintance?
sp.stage: Silvander, and Lindamira do converse while the others talk.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I cannot tell you that, till I have tryed this, as long as I have the other.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Pray my Lord, do not perswade your Friend, all this earnest is a jest, I allow you as much mirth as you please, so the conclusion be serious.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: We leave the success unto the Fates;—Clearcus may in time have pitty on you Lindamira, he does not yet believe, you are in earnest.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Nor ever shall do Madam, till I see her heart break, and then 'twill be too late.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: He dissembles well, for so young a Schollar Madam.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: We have done all well me thinks, and now tis time that we retire.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: How soon may I make my next visit to you Madam?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: As often as you please my Lord, at publique hours.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: How did I perform my part Madam?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: You fell too soon into your humour, he sees you mock him.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: That's all I ayme at, he has too much wit to be abused; my onely business is to let him see, that he cannot cozen me;—I believe you will see this Scene changed, at his next visit, if I have any skill, you will be troubled with him.

sp.speaker: Pan
sp.p: I am arm'd at all points, against all men, and him most.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Oh Cousin! I am freed from all my fears, and come to rejoyce with you.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I have rejoyced already Madam, and have begun a Scene of mirth, will hold us long;—Had your Highness come a little sooner, you had found the late Convert Lonzartes, and his Friend Clearcus here, who is become my avowed Gallant, and looks as if he liked our company already.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Then you have hopes to cure him;—Pray order it so, as I may come to your next meeting, my heart is now so light, that I could play with any thing;—Can I have no part in your Comedy?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: For two reasons, your Highness can onely be a looker on, tis petty Treason to make love to you, though in jest; and then your beauty is too dangerous to be dallied with; these be edge-tools, too sharp for us to play with.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Why may not Princes participate in such innocent mirth? we make stricter Rules then need; true virtue will shine through such thin clouds without a prejudice, and be above the reach of vile tongues.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I Madam, if you could shew a rule, to distinguish between Innocence and Guilt;—But we often see that Angelical virtues are aspersed, by malicious tongues, and no quality exempt, from rude censures.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I differ in opinion; Princes may enjoy harmless mirth, as freely as we; to be too much reserved, does look like disguise.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: I would be so merry Lindamira, as should defie all scandall, and with an open face justifie it to the world; to wear alwayes a stiff-state face, is intollerable.

sp.speaker: Pan
sp.p: Private persons may be bold that way, when few eyes observe,—But Princes are set on Pirameds, for all to see, and immitate.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: You shall not fright me from your mirth, with this grave Lecture, are they not, both my near Relations, whom you endeavour to reclaim? why may not I share in so worthy a designe?—I fear Lindamira she doubts least I may gain her Gallant from her.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: She may well be jealous, if your Highness undertake him, I shall have small hopes, if you two quarrel for him.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: VVhy Lindamira? is Silvander vanished?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: No Madam, the more Trophies I can fairly get by Victories on others, will raife his Conquest higher, who gaines me from the rest.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Thou art safe, and mayest say any thing▪ Silvander is thy security against all scandal, though you carry it thus unconcern'd, the secret spread.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.l: 'Tis time it should do so, now we do own
Our love, tis fit the secret should be known.
Your Highness may assist, while you look on,
Though onely we, the active part do own.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Let us retire to council then.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: What is thy business honest Geta? How does Lonzartes thy brave Lord?

sp.speaker: Geta.
sp.p: My Lord is in good health of body Madam, his brains are only out of order.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: How meanest thou Geta, has he got a blow on his head?

sp.speaker: Geta.
sp.p: Only some fumes from his heart Madam, •… nakes his head addle, tis call'd the Spleen of •… te, and much in fashion; his Lordship does desire •… o know the Princess mind this morning▪ what •… e meanes to do all day?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: This will be a hard question to the Princess fasting, why would he know all this now?

sp.speaker: Geta.
sp.p: Because he has some great affairs for me •… o mannage, and cannot spare me to ask, so often •… s I use to do.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Of what nature, be thy particular queries Geta?

sp.speaker: Geta.
sp.p:
He would know how she slept last night? 〈◊〉 what health now? by what hour she will be •… rest? when to her devotions? and then, where •… he walks this morning? and if she dine in pub
•… que? then how she intends to pass her time till •… ight? else I must come twenty times; for
what you may at once dispatch me.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: And does Lonzartes send thee, to enquire all this at once?

sp.speaker: Geta.
sp.p: These women are so silly, they Aside. cannot reach a deep design;—No but he does every day make me trou •… le my self, and every body that I meet, to ask these questions severally, which I would do at once, to sh •… w him I am a man of quick dispatch.

sp.speaker: Ter
sp.p: Oh! is that the matter? I can fit thee with one answer to all these;—Tell thy Lord, the Princess did take cold last night, and will keep her bed all day.

sp.speaker: Geta
sp.p: I like it well, and wish her Highness would do so this moneth.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Out Traytor, I'le make thy Lord braine thee for that wish.

sp.speaker: Geta
sp.p: Why Madam? I meant no harm, 'twas but to save you the trouble, and me the same questions to morrow, and so on till Doonis-day, I think.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.p: Well Sirra, for this time, 'le not complain of you, this Jest shall excu •… e your knavery.

sp.speaker: Geta.
sp.p: This will be a play day for me, I like this lying a Bed well.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: TEll me then who Cloris is?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I dare not trust thee yet.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I will know now, or break all Friendship with you.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I swear I must not yet.
sp.stage: Enter to them Theodocia, Pandora, Lindamira, Teretia, and Ladies, and Silvander.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Then look to your self, least I discover Cloris.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Where did you leave my Father Lonzartes?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I have not seen the Prince to day Madam.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: I was told, that you were walking with him just now.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: That may well be Madam, for his braines do crow of late;—do ye see how he stands;—Lonzartes the Princess speaks to ye.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: To me, does your Highness command me any thing?
sp.stage: Silvander, and Lindamira entertain themselves in whisper.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Did not I tell you Madam, that his brains are turn'd, he neither hears, nor sees of late;—The Idea of his Seraffique love, takes him wholly up, from all converse with us mortals.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Hold your prateing, or I shall be angry.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: What has made you so grave of late Lonzartes? all your wonted mirth is gone.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: No man is alwaies in good humour Madam.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: He's in love Madam, on my knowledge, o're head and eares in love.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: In love, Lonzartes, I thought you had not been at leasure, to be in love;—Tis your fault Clearcus, that have not councell'd your Friend better.

sp.speaker: Cle.
