sp.p: Thus am I chid for your follie •… , who reject all my councels, and refuse all my approv'd Antidotes, which do preserve me against that Serpent (you call Love) while he convers'd with me, he was safe Madam.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Thou hast fool'd enough Clearcus, the Princess and all the company are weary of it:—If your Highness allow him this freedom, he will grow troublesome.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Is it Love Lonzartes? or is Clearcus onely merry with you?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Your Highness knows him too well, to credit all he sayes this way, he is at this time, very angry that I have chid him for his lewd life, and have with-drawn my self from his ill company, which he imputes to my being in love.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I say he is in love, most seriously in love; shall I unmask this grave Reformado, and shew you the Lady now?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: If Lonzartes be content, I would gladly see her, whom he thinks worthy of his heart.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: No matter for his consent Madam, He holds them all to Lonzartes, one by one. so you like it;—And thus I begin my tryal;—By your good leave Lady—Tis not here;—nor is it this;—nor is it you Lady?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I lament the losse of such an honour.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Thou art become a pretty fool Clearcus, dost thou not observe how all the Court do laugh at thee?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Yes, and shall make them laugh at you, e're I have done; if Pandora will make the next tryall.

sp.speaker: Pan
sp.p: I am content to try, what this will come to.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Now Sir, have at you;—Tis not your good fortune neither Madam.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: How can you make Lonzartes an amends, for all this abuse.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I will give him present satisfaction, if your Highness will permit me to bring him to you?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: To me! think you Lonzartes is in love with me?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Tis a Cloris in the clouds, one much above his reach, which you onely are Madam.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: With all my heart, I shall be proud to own his conversion, as a Trophie of my honour.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: See if his guilt do not make him avoid the tryal;—stop him there;—Lonzartes the Princess calls you.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I'le cut thy throat.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
He threatens me,—guilty I'le warran •… ;—now Madam, do you see no alteration in his
face?—no change yet?—speak all,—you are all assistants in this Judgement.
sp.stage: Lonzartes throws him off in anger.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: It will disturb a Saint, to be thus subject to the fancies of a fool.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Be not disturb'd Lonzartes, you take this in earnest, which we look on as a jest, only to pass the time; Clearcus has more wit, then to be in earnest.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I hope your Highness will not prefer his follies, before my professions, who disclaim such a presumption.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: I •… you turn this jest to earnest Lonzartes, I shall believe Clearcus;—I take it now as Ralliery;—I wonder Lindamira you get not hold of some young lovers heart?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I have twenty in store Madam, more then I know what to do with.

sp.speaker: Pan
sp.p: Then you allow as many lovers, as you can get, and mean to chuse the best.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I think tis credit for women to be admir'd and honour'd by worthy men; it shews a value, to move so many to a general Esteem, and must be the womans fault, if she deserve a censure.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: You are in the right Lindamira, men may designe, but women may destroy, faster then they can built; my thanks unto Clearcus for our mirth.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Mirth ought to be our business Madam.—
sp.l: The angry gods affords cross Fates to give
Us griefes enough, and troubles while we live.
sp.stage: Enter the Prince and Lords, who meet the Ladies going off.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: We were now discoursing of your Gallant Pandora, have you hopes to work this miracle?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: This Lady and I, have ventred our credits on this conversion Sir.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: To reclaim him, were a good work; but suppose he fall in love with either of you.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: At his peril that, let Lindamira look to her self, I am safe.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I have a sure retreat Sir, tis but seeming to comply, and he'l give ore; for he can love none that he can conquer, and I am resolv'd rather to be vanquish'd, then not to be rid of him when I see my time.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Could all her Beauty with my love expire
Her flowing Wit, would still create new fire
sp.stage: Enter to them Clearcus and Lonzartes.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: You two I know, come now from exercizing of your Troopes.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: No Sir, we went hence just now; I wish my Troop here to guard me.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Have you an Enemy in view Clearcus?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
I have many Sir, that have rob'd me of
my peace, I cannot sleep of late, but have a thousand fancies, which do set my brains on fire.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Take heed it prove not love.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: That is the danger Sir, for if Pandora do keep her resolve for single life; I may be in love; for I do feel strange alterations that I know not what to make of.

sp.speaker: Lin
sp.p: Have you no affection left for me my Lord? can you so soon forget your last nights professions?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Now Sir, you see how I am assaulted, I shall be pull'd in pieces presently.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Silvander and I, will secure you from Lindamira.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: If I were assured you could Sir, I should like her wit, and humour well,—but I fear,—if I should be in earnest, she would be so too.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: You see his inclination is for me Madam, so that what ever he shall say to you hereafter, is meant to me.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Nor so, nor so, sweet Lady, I do respect Pandora, above all her Sex; you throw out hoocks to catch young Gallants, she neglects those are laid for her, thats my danger.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: What riddle is this Clearcus? dost thou desire, that thy desires may not be answered?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Yes Sir, from some persons, for if my love be return'd, all ends in the fruition, (as most Examples shew,) But if Pandora keep her resolve for single life, then I can raise my fancy while I live▪ to Adoration of her beauty, and that virtue, with a continual delight, which will last while I last.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p:
You are then my Lord, the happiest lover
living, for you will find my Cousin, just as you wish.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Pray Madam, answer not too fast for me, for if I find Clearcus a person of such NobleNature, beyond what I did ever hope to meet in man; I may change my Opinion of men for his sake; and therefore 'tis best to find some other sport, least we destroy each other.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Look you now? I am Treypand.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Start not Clearcus, she but mocks you, you are both ingaged for this month to Entertain us, and your selves, no going off now.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I shall not break Covenants.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Nor I Madam, though I do sometimes reminde you of your resolve against Marriage, whereon depends my bliss, secure me but of that, and I am ever yours.

sp.speaker: Pan
sp.p: I shall endeavour what I can, to give you that satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I kiss your fair hand on that word, which has given new life to my doubtfull heart, and now I do defie Lonzartes gravity, to put his heart in a more loving dress, then mine shall be hereafter.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: If Lonzartes can love too, my wonder ceases.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: He is my servant Sir, and has a chief part in the Comedy.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: I like your pastime well, but me thinks Lonzartes looks as if he were compell'd unto his part, and will do it scurvily.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: That's the sport Sir, and will afford the more variety.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I shall be glad Sir, if I might be excus'd.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: By no means Servant, what an affront is this, that I must beg your favour, in the face of the whole •… ourt to own me?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: You must not be so grave Lonzartes, all is for our mirth.

sp.speaker: Cle
sp.p: Now Sir, have not I done your work for you?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Would thou wert hang'd, hold thy peace.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Give me better words, or I'le talk aloud.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Was ever man thus hamper'd, between jest and earnest?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: They are comparing notes in private; there's Treachery in their faces; I'le play no more.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: When begins the love Clearcus? this is only talking of it.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: It is begun already Sir; if I had not valued this Excellent Lady above the World; I had not taine this care to secure my interest to a perpetuity.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Madam, you are not to believe a word of this, for he has with the same grave face, sworn the same to me but Yesterday.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: That was in jest Madam, but now every action of my life, shall justifie each syllable I utter unto you.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I shall endeavour to believe it my Lord, and yet allow you the same Christian liberty with Lindamira, and the rest, as you had before.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
Madam, you speak, as though you did not
value my respects, now my whole soul is set to serve, and honour you alone.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I must confess, I cannot change my faith, so fast as you do your discourse;—And then •… s I remember my lesson, is to keep my distance, least I loose my lover.

sp.speaker: Cle
sp.p: True Madam, as to comply, but you are to see, and credit my ambitious love, and to admit it with the same Esteem, I serve you.

sp.speaker: Pan
sp.p: How can I do that, and not return you love for love? and then you will dispise me; pray my Lord, at your next visit, bring my part in wr •… ng, th •… t I may not erre in it.

sp.speaker: Prince
sp.p: he is in the right Clearcus, you now seem to seek such contradictions, as all the Court will laugh at; consult with Lonzartes against your next visit.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: If he will follow my advise, he may do well Sir;—now we are alone, tell me what crotchets next? prethee make me understand what thou wouldest have Pandora do?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I think you were best release me the residue of my mon •… h, that I may go seek my wits, where I last left them;—must I see none of my old Friends, untill this month be over?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: If you consider your promise, not see one of them.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Then shall I be lost, if those preservatives be all forbid me; I do find already love will be Predominant.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: The better for you if it be;—let us now talk seriously;—suppose Pandora may be won, can you fancy a happiness on Earth, beyond having her?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Yes, I do fancy that having twenty, is better then any one in Christendom.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Thou dost not love then, else, that one belov'd, has more variety then a thousand.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Make but that good, I'le marry her to morrow.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: You think then she is already at your dispose.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: When she once sees that I am in earnest, she will be, what I will have her; and the truth is Lonzartes, I do like her best of all I ever talk'd with, and have great fear that I shall be like other men, who never value what they have, which makes me covet what I cannot get.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Suppose some other do obtain her, while you are thus long resolving?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Nay, I am resolv'd no other shall ever have her.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: And you resolve for her too.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Yes, she cannot in Honour ingage to any, while I pretend.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Art thou turn'd fool, to think thus? be more serious, or thou wilt be dispis'd.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Why do you not allow me some relief then? to live a whole month honest, will put my blood into a flame; I have tempted all I meet, and all within these Walls prove honest.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p:
By your own Experience then, you will find that Courts are Nurseries of virtue, and are
onely scandaliz'd by such vilde persons, as would have the clearest innocence aspers'd, that their own guilts might be no wonder;—you find few virtuous persons, amongst Censurers.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: That's true, but take heed Lonzartes, you do not lead me into snares that will destroy me, for I already find some inclinations towards Pandora, which I am asham'd to own, least I be laugh'd it.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: You have reason, for there can none of us believe thee.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: You have made me a fine Gentleman in a few dayes;—if Pandora be of your mind, adiew to your Philosophical love.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I hope thou art too fast to free thy self.—
sp.l: Thou playest with flames which undiscover'd burn,
Untill they do thy heart to Ashes turn.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Did ever man betray himself as I have done? by putting fetters on in jest, which already are become so fixt, I cannot shake 'um off, but must humbly beg to be allow'd to worship that Divine Nature I so much dispis'd in virtuous women, and must now confess:—
sp.l: If I do neither Faith, nor Favour find,
The god of Love is Just, though he be blind.
sp.stage: Note, that all the Play through, when Silvander and Lindamira speaks not, they are to whisper as in private discourse.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: If your Highness do consider Lonzartes's Worth, and his great Birth, as it deserves; whose Ancestor was not many Ages since, by yours put by this Dukedom, on a nice point, (as I have heard;) so that to me Lonzartes's love, looks like a Divine direction, to his Restauration.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: I am of Pandora's mind for single lise, and have as small a value for that idle passion you call love, as she.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Your Highness may as well judge what they do in China, as guess at our Felicities that love?—I can •… iss the ground that my Silvander treads on, with more re •… ish, then all other joyes can bring me.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: You have high fancies that lead you on to hopes, which you may never find.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: These hopes are more delightfull then an Age of dull life without them; if your Highness did converse as much with me, as with Pandora, I should convert you.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Why do you not then change her severity against men?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I had not the Honour to be known to her, before her heart was set another way; but yet I'le try what I can do.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: I wish Silvander may answer your expectation Lindamira; but if such honour, and such bliss accompany your loves, why thus long carried on ith' dark? and why not yet avow'd?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Tis now avow'd unto the Duke, though I took time to know my Gallant, before I did admit his love, and on long tryal found his silent looks, did speak more truth, then such loud noyses as most passions make

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: You praise Silvander as if you meant to sell him.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: He is no Prince Madam, and is therefore safe from you.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: The less safe, if I so pleas'd;—do you believe his virtue, and his love so great, that I could not win him from you for a Friend of mine?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I do, and shall not think him a loss, who can be won from me, by the greatest Princess of the World?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: If I could once see such a man, I might change my opinion.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Why don't you try Lonzartes?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: He is too much concern'd to be play'd with;—you dare not venture your fine man then?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I dare, and do desire it withall my heart, and do voluntarily ingage, not to work against your Highness.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: And I am resolv'd to try his faith to you, it may cure Lonzartes to see himself neglected, when anothers chosen, though but in jest, for I can pitty, though I do not love him.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: And tis my desire to have Silvanders faithfull love, made Eminent by this temptation.
sp.stage: Enter Lonzartes, and Silvander to them.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: In what humour left you Clearcus my Lords?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: In such as does become his greatnesse Madam.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Most brave men are often puffed up with vain glory, that does Eclipse those virtues, which themselves do over-value.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Your Highness is severe to men, but all are not so vain.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Most are, when we do value them too much;—yet I confess I am well pleased, when I find men worthy my Esteem.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: How does that appear? when your Highness does dispise mankind by your resolves against them.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: To shew how much you are mistaken; unpin this Jewel;—wear this Silvander for my sake; I'le own it to the World, that I do value men of Worth.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Madam, I understand not what this kind of favour meanes; I hope your Highness does not chuse me for mirth.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Do you Silvander raise mirth from my Favour?—come with me Lindamira;—I do command you to stand near us within hearing;—I will not run the hazzard of any Censure, by this tryal to satisfie my curiosity concerning lovers, such high Romantick lovers, who soar above the reach of all temptations.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I shall obey you Madam, though I desire it not.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Can you guess Lonzartes, what this tends to?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: 'Tis a Riddle far beyond my understanding.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Wake; wake Silvander, the Sun shines bright upon thee; Theodocia dotes on thy virtues, and will advance thy youth, much faster then thy own wishes can propose.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: How Lindamira, have you so mean thoughts of me?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: So high thoughts, why may not the Princess neglect the Corinthian for you? such things have been in story.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: You speak, as if you wish'd it.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Can I wish you well, and not applaud it?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: You cannot fancy me a greater curse, unless your own heart be turn'd against me.

sp.speaker: Lin
sp.p: The Princess desires your Company in the next Room; I can stay no longer.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p:
I have so much to think on, that I know not what to say;—the Princess unexpected
favours, with Lindamira's no concern, begets such wonder, as does amaze me—I will not go;—and yet I must or make my self Ridiculous, by judging what I cannot guess at.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Have I thus long ador'd the Princess? and still approach'd her with the same trembling, I draw near the Altar, for this scorn at last,—before my face, to court a man, she knows ingaged unto another, a man of so much lower quality then I; this I confess does make my Faith stagger;—Silvander was as much surpriz'd as I,—Lindamira too was out of Tune;—If Theodocia can go less, this change will be more my admiration, then her virtue was.
sp.stage: Enter Lindamira, passing in as by him.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Now Madam, whither so fast?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: To see which way the wind blows;—pray my Lord, where is your heart now?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: In the Princess lodgings, with yours;—or can you tell me better, where your own is?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I change my mind so often, that I know not where I left my heart last.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Are you no more concerned? Suppose Silvander change his opinion? Princess have mighty power to overcome mens hearts.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p:
Why then his opinion will be chang'd?—I cannot value him, that leaves to value me;—
methinks my Lord, the Princess favour to Silvan
•… r, should a bate your passion for her.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: My desires go no higher, then to look, and •… onder at her perfections! my Esteem cannot be •… ll'd love, beyond what Duty, and Obedience •… oes allow;—but how does Silvander receive •… his great Honour?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: They are now in private; you may judge •… y his exalted looks when you see him next;— •… am glad your Lordship is no more concern'd.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: This is a forc'd discourse Lindamira, pray do not mock me, who have a true value of your •… orth.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p:
The truth is, the Princess often angred at •… y confidence in Silvanders love; onely now 〈◊〉 if she can shake his faith, by higher proposi
•… ions;—and my hope is, that his virtue may •… eget in her, some better thoughts for men, •… hich will do your business, and confirm mine, •… or Silvander is above temptation; and I think Lonzartes does deserve what he desires.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: You oblige me to say, your confidence •… oes merrit the greatest faith from man; but is Silvander of your Plot?

sp.speaker: Lin
sp.p: No, 'twould then be none, nor I no tryall have of his sincerity.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: These are dangerous sports, and we too •… ate may find them so;—the Princess and you •… re both too bold, and do too much rely on your own beauties.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: If Silvander can be won, I can smile at such a loss.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p:
'Tis easie to say so, when you fear it not;
but I have seen stout hearts fall to pieces by such a blow;—you have setled my heart again, and I advise you from these dangerous sports, least they blow up your joyes, when you are most secure: we know our present minds, but cannot fore-see what we shall like tomorrow:—

l.hi: Our Nature with such frailty is indow'd,
'Tis well if present moments be allow'd.

sp.stage: Enter Theodocia, and Silvander, two Ladies at a distance; Lindamira is seen near observing them.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Is your heart my Lord so fixt on Lindamira, that no Person, nor any Argument, can e're prevail with you to change?

sp.speaker: Sil
sp.p: Our Souls Madam, are so united, that I hope death can onely make that separation.

sp.speaker: The
sp.p: Can no Fortune, nor any Quality invite you to Honours, and Happiness, beyond what you can ever hope from Lindamira? Nor a greater beauty dis-i •… gage your heart from her?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: None can ever move me to a thought of change Madam.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: What if she have chosen higher, and gives way for your preferment also.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I can smile at all this, when your Highness is so merry;—Lindamira and I Madam, do understand a happiness, can never be dissolv'd; we are above temptation.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Suppose my Father be her choice, will you pretend to love, and hinder her advancement, by your claim?—Suppose my Dear Cousin Pandora, have like affection unto you; and puts on this severity to others, in design onely to gaine you? will you let such a beauty, of so high virtue and extraction dye for you?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Your Highness sure does fancy what is impossible?—but if all this were so, I could dye in gratitude to serve Pandora, but do prefer Lindamira's love, and virtue, above the brightest beauty, or greatest Empire this World has.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Can there be such worth in men? how have I been mis-informed?—Princes who do not converse, know not the World they live in, but take all on trust from Aside. others;—You believe that I am now in jest Silvander, and do not deal so freely, as I expect.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: By all thats——I am fixt, past •… ltering;—if your Highness knew the joyes, which do accompany united hearts, you would sooner undertake to pull down Stars from Heaven, then hope a separation, where true love Triumphs.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: I am fully satisfyed, that Lindamira has what she deserves, a worthy Lover;—appear now Lindamira, and call in Lonzartes with the •… st:—I am converted.
sp.stage: Enter Lindamira with Lonzartes and Ladies

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p:
Here Madam, you are coupled by the gods, Silvander does deserve your confidence;—
Now wear that Jewel, I before gave you in jest Sir, as a mark of my Favour, for your approv'd virtue.

sp.speaker: Lin
sp.p: Has your Highness any better thoughts for Marriage, then you had?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: I have found an honest worthy man, beyond my Expectation;—Lonzartes you look sad.

sp.speaker: Lon
sp.p: My heart is not so full of feathers as it was, but is of late become a lump of lead.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: We have indeed been all too serious of late; come Lindamira, let us find some Entertainment to refresh us on the Sea this Evening; Lonzartes, you, and Clearcus may go with us, if you please?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Your Highness does honour us;—what these various fancies tend to, is above my understanding;—As Nature has fram'd Women of a more refined matter, then us men, so she has given to some, Souls so much above ours Excellent, that their Intrincique purity, dazles our Judgements more then their brightest beauty does our eyes;—Theodocia is cetainly without blemish;—yet may have some notions of my love, which she thinks not fit to cherish, because she likes not me:—And yet may have a virtuous concern for my birth, and sufferings, such as her good Nature is unwilling to destroy;—'Tis Theodocia's Excellencies makes me thus humbly seek my Right, as her Gift; Else my Sword should make my way to ascend this Throne, which is my own;—but no more of that yet:—
sp.l: —For if I can be rightly understood,
My love may save the expence of so much blood.

div.head: FOURTH ACT.
div.stage: Pandora with Lindamira are seen sitting on a Couch; Enter Clearcus to them, they rise.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: MAdam Tis a felicity to love you, though neglected; by what Name then, shall I call my Joy? Now you allow my Love, to what height raise my thoughts?—Shall I dare to enter upon such a state of bliss?—To be thus snatch'd into so much Light, from the long Chaos I have liv'd in, may prove more ruinous to me, then that Hell I came from.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: My Lord, you speak a new Language I understand not.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Alas Madam, I have this night seen Visions, and do find my passion, growing much above my own command;—For when I look on your eyes, I forget that there are gods, and shall do such Idolatry to you, as will provoke them, to make me more miserable, then you can wish me happy;—But when I consider how vast a Chasme, your resolves have made between us; I sink into such an abyss of misery, that I can ne're get out of.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I understand you less, and less;—The more you say, the more you do confound my Judgement.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: All this Madam, is onely to let us see how he could talk; if any Woman were worthy of his real love;—pray my Lord proceed,—I shall take Notes and Edifie.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Your mirth Madam, is now out of season, when every word I utter flowes from my wounded heart.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Why do you not speak to me then? who can change my mind as often as your self? I was made for you; this Lady is impregnable.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I yield Lindamira, let not your wit destroy a man that does submit to mercy; I beg quarter.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Oh! do you so?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: 'Tis enough Lindamira, that he does confesse himself o're-come, let it be Registred amongst our Victories;—And now my Lord, what is your next desire?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: My next Madam; I have scarce begun with this, you do mistake all I say for mirth; Does not my looks and Language shew an Alteration?—All those Chymeras, that did possess my idle head are vanished, and I become a serious man:—Your Miracle is already wrought, and I now see the onely way to my Felicitie, is to gain what I so much contemn'd.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Excellently well Acted, this might cozen twenty that did not know him.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: You shall do well my Lord to persue this new path, untill you do obtain a general opinion of your virtue; But I hope you would not have us credit it at first sight.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Though my love cannot yet gain credit in your Esteem, do not deny me the joy to think that you see how much I love, and honour you.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: This is too serious for our Comedy my Lord.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Nothing can be too serious Madam, to expresse my love, by which the gods are pleas'd to bring me to them; thus by forbidding what might intice me to slight Paradice, by having had you here:—'Tis fit then that I submit, and raise a joy from what I am now too apt to repine at, for 'tis a blessing to be so fixt, as Antidates my Elizium here on Earth; this Souls joy will endure like its own nature, unto Eternity.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: You are cured then Clearcus, and will unto the Prince confess your conversion, if we call you to it?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Propose away for my acknowledgement, and try.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Let us take time Madam to consider of it, least we loose half the Entertainment by our hast, and so spoile the jest.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Madam, let not this Ladies mirth prevaile with your good nature, to afflict a man, who can live onely by your smiles.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I must confess I have some pain to hold in my smiles thus long, for this serious way of fooling I expected not from you my Lord.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Why Madam, do you take all this for jest still?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Yes indeed do I.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: By all the powers above, I do Adore you, next to them I Worship.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: That's no Oath Madam, for he Worships none.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I have the same thoughts Lindamira, and am safe.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: What a Monster am I grown, give me credit Madam, or give me death?—If I do not love you, let Jove strike me with suddain Thunder; or I will gladly seal what I have said with my best blood, if nothing less will satisfie.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Hold Clearcus.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Oh! let him alone, he'l not hurt himself, he onely hopes to fright us.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: My Lord you fright me now, and since you think fit to turn our Commick Scene into a Tragedy; I shall quit my part in it; and from this time, admit no farther visits from you:—Let us retire Lindamira, his converse grows dangerous.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: This had been my fate, had I ingaged a little farther, and this the fruit of chast, virtuous love; What a folly 'tis, to give our freedoms up, unto the will of Women, so humbly to obey, those we are Created to command:—But I am safe yet, and will now play with 'um, at their own game; and through a seeming sorrow for my rejection, laugh at them, who think to laugh at me.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: A good day unto my Friend.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
You speak too late Lonzartes, this is a fatal day, and I am studying how I may make it more
Eminent by death, then by my sufferings.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Why what's the matter man? have you visited the Ladies before they are drest, and made 'um froward.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Thy love Lonzartes has ruin'd me;—yet I thank thee for my conversion, I shall now dye a sober man.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Thy looks speak some disaster, tell me the worst, that I may joyn to find a Remedy.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: In a word then, I do love Pandora, as she deserves, and did so to the life express my love; that in spight of Lindamiras mirth, she did believe it, and has forbid my farther visits.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: 'Tis not possible that she can be so fool'd, she forbad thee in jest, come let us go to her now.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I'le swear she did forbid me, and in great anger turn'd from me, I dare not go.

sp.speaker: Lon
sp.p: This is pretty, would'st thou have me believe thou lovest?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Lonzartes, I am not in humour to be play'd with.

sp.speaker: Lon
sp.p: Nor I in humour to be fool'd; what would'st thou have me say, when thou talk'st thus to me? thou in love! Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: What shall I say? what do, to beget faith in thee?—Pandora's resolution against Marriage, which I so much rejoyc'd at, is fatally become my scourge, and I must dye, or have her.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: That's the only way to obtain belief; do but hang thy self, and then a Printed Ballad (The Dary Maids greatest Faith;) will make them swear thou dyedst for love.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
Do my looks agree with so much jest?
does not my face declare, my heart does love?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: No, nor ever can do to me, would'st thou have me belye my self, that thou mayest laugh at me? these shallow Plots are lost on me.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: This is right, had I been fool'd into the Platonick pound; I might have knock'd my head against the walls, and never been believed;—Thus I blow away those bubles, those ayrie Lectures of chast love, which lead silly mortals into slavery;—Ha Sanga.

sp.speaker: Sanga.
sp.p: Your pleasure Sir.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Go presently, and sum mon all that merry Crew, (who danc'd the other day,) to Sup with me this Night; and bid the Musick come.

sp.speaker: Sanga.
sp.p: I go Sir.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I will retreat while I am safe, and be Arm'd against my Wise, Virtuous, Chast Friends, with their Cob-web Netts, so subtilly laid to catch me;—Thus I throw all their Inchantments off;—And now like the Grand Seignor, after some great Victory atcheiv'd;—I will retire to my Seraglio.
sp.stage: Enter the Duke, with Theodocia, Pandora, Lindamira, Teretia, and Train:—and Silvander.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: You tell me a story beyond belief Theodocia, Clearcus playes with you all this while; he love?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: If Pandora be mistaken, he will triumph over Women kind for ever.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I wish it were no worse Sir, tis I who now am to be pittied, who for the common sport, and for his good, have brought an evil on my self, I cannot bear.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Why Pandora, he is descended of our own blood, and his Estate proportionable to his Birth? so that if you can raise his virtues above his vices, you'l have no cause to murmur at his love.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: True Sir, if I were not ingag'd to a single life, much might be said, to set Clearcu's merrits above mine.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Is there no dispensation for such resolves Madam? when it may be disputed, whether the gods approve them?—They give us Lawes enough, we need none of our own making.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: My heart will ne're consent to alter my resolves.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: We shall have enough to do then.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Let us all agree to laugh him out of it.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: You will find little cause for mirth, when you see Clearcus next Madam.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Can so few hours alter a man of his temper, so much?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p:
He is asham'd of his first Principles, and is angry at that shame; He hates himself for loving, and loves so much, he dares not wish it less; This
mixture of passions, does beget such a confusion of thoughts, that makes him look as if he had fed on nought but sighes, and tears this twelve Month; and I fear we shall have cause to turn our 〈◊〉
〈◊〉 sorrow for him.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I'le give him Commands that shall divert him;—come with me Theodocia.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Tis great pitty so brave a man should be so lost

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Tis so Lindamira, but how can it be help'd? must I become mad, because he is so;—'Twas not a rash word, by chance let fall, but on debate and mature judgement, because I saw none so happy after Marriage as before;—Why may not I then live and dye as free as I was born?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: You see why, because the gods do not allow so great felicity on Earth, as might keep us from ever wishing to be with them; pray whoever heard of a pair of true Lovers, that desir'd to be in Heaven, if they might stay here till Doomsday? Tis therefore for our good, that such united hearts are so rarely to be found on Earth; take heed Pandora, that you bring not more evils on your head, then you fore see.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I must now bear my Fortune as I may.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p:
Though you have not met with many happy Marriages, I have heard of some, who all their lives have had a constant spring of love; their passions so high, and joyes so great, each
striving to raise the others happiness above their own; this I believe and hope for;—Methinks till I am married, I am a thing laid by, as if forgotten by the gods.

sp.speaker: Pan
sp.p: Tis not high passions, nor great joyes, I doubt to find, but their continuance;—suppose the Gallant Lovers to the Wars be sent, what terrours will possess their frighted Ladies, till their return? and if miscarry, what will their whole lives have to joy at after?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Those who stay at home, may have equall dangers, these are anticipated dreams of evils, that may never happen; then you conceive not the joy those dangers bring when they are over; this world affords us nothing to relish our delights by, but such accidents as love, with some fears and dangers bring; Tis sharps make sweet the sweeter.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: But if I am satisfied with less joyes, without those pains you find so useful, why must I try to gain more happiness, then I do wish for, when I have joyes enough already?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Joyes enough Madam; there is no such thing in Nature, as enough of what we love.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I am weary of this idle talk.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: And I know no better Entertainment.
sp.stage: Enter to them Lonzartes, and Silvander.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: How think you Silvander, is Clearcus what he seems?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Lonzartes knows him best Madam.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I do believe he loves, though I seem not to credit him, and am now resolv'd to play with his passion, as he has done with mine; 'twill entertain the Princess rarely, to see how I shall anger him.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Is he enough fix't? to be so abus'd, for if neither Men, nor Women have any faith in his budding love, he may fly off for ever.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I am now going to see what humour he is in.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I'le wait on you.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Pray do, and let me know how I must behave my self, that would not hurt him.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I can direct you best, if you'l trust your self to me.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I shall trust you as far as any in this affair; let us consult within.
sp.stage: Enter Clearcus and Sanga, with Men, and Women dancers.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Welcome my dear Friends, I will be no more seduc'd by grave Lonzartes fooleries; this night shall reunite us while we live:—Is the Musique come.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: Not yet Sir.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I have broke through their Nets, and now the day and night are ours to Revel in; we will be so merry, that our hearts shall seem much lighter then our heeles.

sp.speaker: Sanga.
sp.p: Lonzartes, and Silvander are without.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: They are come as I could wish, I'le entertain 'um as they deserve; they are my kind, chast, virtuous, well-wishing spies;—pray retire all Exeunt Dancers. into that Gallery, while I dispatch my Court-Friends:—Sanga shut the windows close, then call 'um in, and say, that I am grown sad of late, Exit Sanga. monstrous sad;—Now for a grave face to suite with my disguise; I have some fear my sides will burst, with holding in my laughter.
sp.stage: He sits in a sad posture.
Enter Sanga with Lonzartes, and Silvander.

sp.speaker: Sanga.
sp.p: Softly pray;—for a strange Melantholy has seiz'd him on the suddain;—He is now talking to Pandora.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: She is not here.

sp.speaker: San.
sp.p: He entertains her Idea in her absence with the same passion, he would her;—the only sure way for a lovers happiness;—hark.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Blessed Angel, turn not away;—these tears must be my daily Incence, offer'd at your feet; if you refuse this Tribute from my captiv'd heart, you'l turn the Elizium I enjoy, to Hell: Oh stay! and take my Soul with thee;—that gentle look! that:—

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Why so sad fond lover? let not one repulse dismay so great a Conquerour; thy next charge may prove more prosperous;—we come to councel thee Clearcus, and to raise thy drooping Spirits by new hopes.

sp.speaker: Cle
sp.p: Or to laugh at my affliction, whose Soul is sunke so low by my dispair, that all my Spirits are vanished; I must submit to my Captivity Lonzartes.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: That sigh had almost blown me over, yet I am glad to see this, and am now fully satisfied thou art in love, in love Clearcus;—let me Imbrace my fellow-Prisoner, we will now shake our shackles, to the same sad tune.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I know you came to mock me;—but I must bear it.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Oh no! who can have so hard a heart? we pitty you, and have some fears Pandoras heart will break, when we relate your mighty sufferings;—but if I should sit thus in the dark, would it create the like Angelical Idea in my brain Clearcus?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: This is barbarous, to catch a Lion in your Toyles, and bait him like an Asse;—thus to render my passion Rediculous, will beget Pandoras scorn, and may prove my destruction.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: If she discern not your passion, how can she proportion her favours to your merrit?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Do I deserve this mirth from you, thus to highten my affliction?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p:
Do you not?—all that I can do this Twelvemonth, will not bring me on equal terms
for thy abuses:—remember how you held me to the Ladies, and made me your mirth, by which scandal you destroy'd my credit with the Princess, this is my revenge.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: 'Twas a great scandal indeed to procure you the Princess leave to love her; by my means you have obtain'd a happiness beyond your hopes, which all your whining Poetry, or your Eternall sighes could ever reach;—for which speciall service;—prethee good sweet Lonzartes spare Hangs on him. me;—by our old Friendship I do beg;—by thy own virtue, and unparalel'd chast heart, I do conjure thee not to raise a publique mirth out of my souls sorrow, which you have brought me to.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Well then, if I find you do continue thus humbly penitent, and truly thus afflicted, I will shew more mercy then I found from you;—come chear up;—we will sigh, and condole together, Embraces Clearcus. and if possible, so order our sad hearts, that both may the same moment break, and infect the world with such a sorrow, as may fright the female Sex from like rigour unto men; so shall we become a Noble Sacrifice to love, for the good of a whole Nation;—or if you please, we'l send for some of our old Gang to dance, and drink these Melancholly vapours from our hearts, to let the Ladies see, their beauties are not so destructive, as we make them believe.
sp.stage: Clearcus Imbraces Lonzartes with great joy.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I marry Lonzartes, now thou talkest like a Phylosopher, now thou prescribest the onely remedy for our disease;—Sanga,—bid the Musick strike a chearfull Ayre, and then call in those Friends in the next room;—Nay, if you allow this way of cure, I shall soon expell loves venome from my heart into my heeles.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: What is all this Clearcus, art thou mad still?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I am wise, and do not mean to quit my cool, pleasant, flowry paths, for your consuming flames of restless love, who walke on tops of Steeples, and at that height, plead that your chast desires are pleasing to the gods;—But I, who know the end of such fair flashes, as at first appear with such folded Armes, and down cast looks, are but steps to approach the Ladies fingers ends;—
sp.l: —Then by degrees grown bolder, you aspire,
Till nought but ruine, quench the subtle fire.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: What doest thou mean by this misterious language?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
I mean to follow thy advise,—to sigh only when I make love to Ladies, (their backs turn'd) I mean to dance, and sing as often as I can, that their neglects may pierce no deeper then their
eyes discern;—here Lonzartes, this Girle will cure the bite of a Tarantula, and drive the poyson from thy heart.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Out Hypocrite;—is this thy love unto Pandora? was all thy passion counterfeit the other day?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: No, 'twas fairly growing up to equal thine in all sincerity of Noble thoughts; But the nice Lady would not permit it to take so deep root as yours, before she blasted all my hopes, and in a moment let me see, that love is like a bitter potion, which many tast, and flying away, rather chusing their disease, then so ill a relish'd remedy; This made me return to my old Antidotes Lonzartes;—what think you of a heat or two before you go?—call in the Musique.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Pandora was to blame, to throw him off so rashly.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Let us retyre Silvander, this Ayre is infected.

p.hi: Go whine fond lover, go whine, I say, go whine, While we chear our hearts with Wenches and Wine, I say go whine.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I do not wonder that he is fallen off, twas what I feared, when his passion went so high, I saw Pandora was concern'd, but we will bring it on again.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: You are mistaken Madam, all he said then was jest, for he is now as mad as ever;—I left him Incirculed with six wild men, and as many wanton Girles, prepar'd to dance and Revel all the night.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: There is no harm in dancing my Lord, unless they do catch cold; you judge Clearcus by what is past; but when I see him with Pandora next, I'le give my opinion of his concern.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: By what means may their meeting be procured?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: We'l think on't.
sp.stage: Enter Theodocia, and Ladies to them.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: I am sorry Lonzartes that Pandora has cast off Clearcus, which has occasioned his relapse, when a little patience would have setled him in the way of virtue.

sp.speaker: Lon
sp.p:
Tis every way what I expected not; his love was as strange as his rejection, and his relapse in the old humour, beyond all the rest;—I
know not what to think of him.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Let us bring them once more together, and I'le undertake to guess at both their hearts;—it may be govern 'um.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I Madam, but how shall they be brought together? when both would rather see a Basaliske, then one another.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: You may be mistaken my Lord, who judge by what you see, when tis our business, and our virtue, not to shew our hearts till a full tryal, that men are worthy of them;—then you forget that Clearcus conversion, must be by one he cannot conquer.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: But if he will neither conquer, nor be subdued, how can his conversion follow?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: If your Highness can contrive an interview, I have a fancy in my head, that may reconcile them, and effect what we all wish

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: I will send presently for Pandora, and intreat my Father to pretend some business to call Clearcus hither.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: He will suspect.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Let him come, no matter what he suspects.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Do you Lonzartes, once more see what humour he is in.—
sp.l: —We must endeavour, and not fear to try,
But trust the Event, unto their destiny.
sp.stage: Enter Duke with Silvander and Lords.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I ever thought Clearcus did but mock, and laugh at their designs; his brains is not yet ripe for serious love:—But how does Theodocia look on Lonzartes?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: With much neglect Sir.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: That is not well, have you Silvander instructed Lindamira, that she may inform Theodocia of Lonzartes Title to this Dukedom? and how much better then a Forraign Prince, her Marrying him, will be applauded by our people, who are not ignorant of his pretence.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I have Sir, and the Princess gives a serious ear to it, though she yet makes no reply; a little of your Councel and Authority, I believe may incline her to a better value of him.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: That shall not be wanting; Lonzartes is all that I can wish in a successor;—and his love looks so without design, that I will cherish it, and try to win my Daughter to comply.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Your Highness will gain a double interest in all your Subjects hearts by this honour to Lonzartes, who has merrits proportionable to your favour, and his birth, all which his love gives Lustre to.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I see it Silvander, and will recompence his Faith, and his Humility, with my advice to Theodocia, who yet knows not his story.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: The Princess must needs hear what every body talks, and all do wish.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I shall now inform her fully of Lonzartes Right, too long held from him: bid him meet me at my Daughters Chamber; I will no longer hide my purpose for him:—
sp.l: —His Birth and Virtue, with his constant love,
Declares he never can unworthy prove.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: NO, I'le never see her more.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Do you not love at all?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Nor ever will; methinks love is like a smooth water, that Invites men to Bath, and tumble in it with delight, untill they be destroyed by Serpents, which in the bottom undiscover'd lye.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: What means this similie?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: This Serpents bite, has Metamorphized you into a whining lover, into the shaddow of a man, of late become a shape without a Soul; why must I busie my head with such Chymeras, when I can please my self to my hearts wish, my own way?—Prethee sweet suppress'd Prince, do not forsake me thus, for specious shewes of happiness, or vainer hopes of better dayes, then you will ever find in Court;—You are now safe, but when you grow wise, and serious, it will in the Dukes head great jealousies create; and to let him see your virtue, may be dangerous, and your pretence appear worthy of his fear.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p:
That hazzard is better, then what I now suffer, in the opinion of my best Friends, who
believe this wildness is my Nature, or such as may beget a habit in me, which I can ne're put off; and thus my security in this disguise, may become my ruine;—I wish I could perswade you Clearcus to shew forth that virtue, all the World would wonder at.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: To what end I pray? if the good Duke would give me imployment fit for his Kins-man▪ and worthy of my Sword, I could soon be my self: But now I have nothing else to do, and therefore play away my time in folly; and tis a hard question which is best, for we know that too much wisdome does undo more men, then it advances, or else begets eternal slavery to State Affairs, where the wisest ever walk on needles points;—I have weighed these things, and do believe 'tis better to maintain the peace, and the security I now live in, unregarded.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: But you will loose the Dukes favour, and become contemptable to the whole Court, if you continue thus Extravagant, what designe can I have, by my desire to see you great and glorious?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Have I not tryed, and been misled? yielded to your wise Maximes, against my own better judgement, and been rejected in the height of my Endeavours, to be (as you call it) great, and glorious, is not this true?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Yes, in part.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I will no more of your advice, till you can cure your self.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I have an Honourable Argument for my love.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Who has not, untill he be dispis'd?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Was it not your own desire to be neglected? did you not declare against all women, that you could conquer? you left Pandora no way for victory, but by rejecting you; so that I can conclude a good success from what you raise dispaire.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Ha! think you Pandora did reject me, in compliance with my humour only?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: What else? can she be angry with you, for loving her too much?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: You do surprize me with a discourse I look'd not for;—but I will be no more abus'd;—I will not see her.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: How can you be reconcil'd then? shall she make love to you?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: No, I abhor that thought beyond her anger, a woman Wooe, that were preposterous.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Will you treat by Embassadours, and wed by Proxie?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Nor so, that's only fit for Princes, who cannot meet to treat.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Will you have her; if she declares she would have you?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I shall never like her change of mind.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Can you tell whether you would have her, or not?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: That's a harder question, then the other.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Will you have her by compulsion?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: That were a Tyranny, would make her hate me ever.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Shall the Duke by his Prerogative Power, in spight of both your teeth, compel you both to compliance?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Let me think on this alittle, at first sight, this looks likely to agree us:—if two impossibilities can make one possible, this might do our business.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Well, what do you resolve?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Nothing, why do you tempt me to farther evils?—I know not what to resolve, nor what to say;—but will no more of love, my heart shakes at the thought of my last tryal;—I blush to think how much less then man I was, and how much more then woman I created her in those few hours I lov'd;—

sp.speaker: Messen.
sp.p: The Duke calls for Lonzartes.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I'le attend his Highness presently.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I take you for my Friend Lonzartes;—do not discourse me into a Ruine, you will share in.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I have no Rule for friendship above my desire to see you happy.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I believe it Sir, and beg your pardon for my distracted language;—I must attend the Duke to.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: And I.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: You tire me Lindamira, and chide me for a fault I cannot own; I had no other way to free my self.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: You might have check'd his approaches, with somewhat less severity, your rigour may beget dispair in him.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Dispair of what? my undertaking was only on the Dukes command, to afford him civil visits, which I have done in hope of his conversion.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: You did give o're, before the work was perfected.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: You speak as if the design to set him free, were to inslave me to the humour of a mad man.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: The wildest young men, do often prove the soberest at the last; and the truth is Madam, we do all desire to see you and Clearcus convert one another; so to beget that unity of hearts, which the World seeks most.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Do you believe that I who have a prejudice against the best of men, can e're esteem the worst?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: If Clearcus were under that notion, I should have other thoughts; but when I consider such men reclaim'd, do often make good Husbands; I have hopes of him.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: If his wildness were his only fault, time, and experience might reclaim him.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: If these be your only Exceptions Madam, I wish you would trust me to mannage this affair.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: You must not talk me into an Intreque which I avoid;—I do not love him.

sp.speaker: Lin
sp.p: You will do, when you have him, I know many have done so after Marriage, who did not before.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: That is too bold a venture for me, who have no faith in men; and those Examples you mention so rarely to be found, my courage dares not undertake it; pray no more of this.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: The Princess desires your company at Court this Evening.
I did intend to wait on her.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I have given you Arguments enough on his behalf, which his dejected looks you see declare;—Your favours Theodocia should not be restrain'd, because his adoration is so great, he dares not beg 'um; come near Lonzartes.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Lonzarte's Worth is understood beyond the weak Rhetorick of flattering words; he cannot wish to be more valued, then he is by me

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Nor will I ever Sue for favours beyond these you now afford me Madam;—may I confirm my hopes, by understanding what you say my own way?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: You may, for since my Father does so much advise for Marriage, I may alter my opinion when I find just cause to value men, above my resolves against them.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: For Heavens sake Madam say no more, my breast cannot contain these spreading joyes you give me, my hopes increase too fast for my dispairing heart, to comprehend these honours you allow, without an Extacy.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Theodocia, I shall ne're revoke the freedom I have given, to make your own choice, though I direct you to Lonzartes, to whom our Ancestors have done wrong.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: This your indulgence Sir makes me more cautious how I proceed;—Marriage is a concern so great, I dare not at once resolve it, and the same day chuse the man:——I can yet only say, that I have alter'd my opinion in favour of Lonzartes.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: My Amazement, and my concern are too great to answer Madam, my felicity is above the reach of a reply.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Theodocia, I have given you my best councel, and my full consent to please your self.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: I thank you Sir, and will endeavour to Regulate my heart to your advise, and to Lonzartes wish;—give me but time to examine and approve what I am willing to submit to.
sp.stage: Enter Pandora, and Lindamira to them, with Silvander.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: How is it Madam, that you quit the field? before your undertaking be perform'd.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I have done my part Sir, which was on your command to allow him civil visits, and to entertain the Princess, I complyed with Lindamira to try how our Raleary would work on him, which did produce so unlook'd for an effect, that I was forc'd to quit my part, to save my self.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Were you in danger to be lost then?—I did not think Clearcus had prevail'd so far; but if he be reclaim'd, he will be worthy your esteem.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Your Highness did mistake me, I was in no danger to be lost through love, nor at all concern'd; for a man who does declare against all worth in women, where he can get an interest: pray Sir, make me understand what you would have me do?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: We would have you marry Clearcus.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Whether he will or no;—If I consent, can you prevail with him?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Do you comply, we'l try what we can do?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I would not be Treypand into a Marriage I am so much a verse to, in confidence of his old humour, think my self secure, and be so lost.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: You may ventute safely Madam, you see he is so great a Coward, that he only dares persue them that fly him, do but charge and he will run away.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: If I were sure of that, I would seem any thing to be freed from farther trouble.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Trust me Madam, he is now worse then ever.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Lonzartes, pray use your interest to bring him to us now.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Do you think Cousin, we have a design to harm you?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: No, but your Highness disputes me into a condition your self does not approve; pray shew me the way to this felicity, that I may credit what you say, by what you do.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Will you then ingage to marry Clearcus, the same day I marry?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Shall I chuse your man, as you would mine?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Suppose I have already chosen.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I thought your Highness had been of my opinion; But if provided, I give you joy.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Now you run too fast the other way, I am onely towards marriage.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: That journey seldome proves long Madam, when we look towards it.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: That was said like a sage Sibell, the quintessence of truth in few words, tis'but a willing mind, and then.

sp.speaker: Pan
sp.p: Prethee Lindamira help me to be rid of this uncertain man.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I know no better councel, then to be in love with him, or to seem so; for if he should take you at your word, and marry, that may do your work; for I once knew a Lady, who chose to marry an importunate Sutor, that she might be rid of him, and was so; for soon after marriage they parted, and never met more.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: You are alwaies in jest, I would have serious councell now.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: You have had my store twice over to no purpose.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: By all my observations, I cannot judge, whether Clearcus, or you Pandora, be most extravagant.

sp.speaker: Lin
sp.p: Your Highness may do well to put them into the Colledge of half mad Folks, where they will either cure one another, or become quite mad together; when their disease is known, some remedy may be found; 'tis now past judgement, what either of them ayle.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p:
Lindamira saies well, 'tis very strange you
will not declare so far, as to let us see how we may serve you.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Do but leave me to my self, and I am well Madam.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Many sick people are of that opinion, when in most danger, and must therefore by their friends be govern'd.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: As many healthy people, think themselves sick when they are not, and by seeking remedies for nothing, do create evils, they never can finde cure for;—such high passions as Lindamira's, do never let us rest in peace, but do create perpetual storms.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: You argue well Madam, if a dull calme, were the onely happiness appointed us on Earth, then one degree from being asleep, would prove our greatest bliss;—sure no age did e're produce two such Icy-hearted Ladies, as the Princess & you.
sp.stage: Enter to them Lonzartes and Clearcus.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Here comes a Homely, and a Jigg hand in hand;—now for the second part to the same tune, Of love me, and love me not.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Clearcus, it troubles me to see you delight in a retired darkness, or else to walk in such clouds as we cannot see through; I would perswade you to regain Pandora's good opinion.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Is the mistery of love to be discuss'd in publique Sir?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
With us, who are so near ali'd unto you both; I think it may, because we all know what you both profess in private, and now desire to
hear, what you will face to face avow; and we intreat you Pandora, first to shew, why you threw off Clearcus.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: You do amaze me Sir, to examine me as a Criminal!

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: You have no cause for this displeasure Pandora, but mis-judge our love and our respects; we know your worth, and would to the World Illustrate that virtue you design to smother by a single life; I allow your purpose did become your younger dayes, and did express an Angelicall Innocense; but I question whether now, on mature judgement, you may not do better for your self, and us, to reclaim Clearcus.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: You demand impossibilites from me, for if I should change my mind, he will change his too; Pray shew me a rule to reclaim him by, before you do condemn me.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: We onely desire you will afford him the same civility, as did first induce him to adore that virtue he dispised before.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I have done this.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: You did begin, but you gave o're too soon.

sp.speaker: Lin
sp.p: And all her kindness but in jest too Madam, which he discern'd.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: How do you answer this? Lindamira was of your councel.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I undertook him but in jest, and was by him injoyn'd to such severity as I perform'd, and 'twas then thought the only way to vindicate our Sex, and to work his conversion, which he at first did counterseit so well, as to deceive, and fright me from his farther visits.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Was his love so terrible?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: To me it was, who thought him uncapable of ever having Noble thoughts for any of our sex.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: But when you found him growing worthy, why did you not cherish that virtue, as your own Creation.

sp.speaker: Lin
sp.p: Because she fear'd her Virgin-vow might be defil'd, by owning such a Man-child of her own begetting; for he began to aske her blessing, till she laugh'd him into so great anger, that one day he proffer'd to kill himself, which gave end unto our Comedy.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: If his cure had lain within the reach of Raleary I had gloried in my part, but never shall consent to inslave my self unto the humours of a man, who cannot be a minute in one mind; his imaginations are beyond the Moon, and would have he knows not what.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Clearcus you have heard your charge;—Guilty or not Guilty?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Guilty Sir.

sp.speaker: Cle
sp.p: I shall never want your good word Madam;—Lindamira tells you true Sir, I am guilty.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Of what?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Of all the crimes, that offended Lady does object; pray Sir pronounce my doom, and put me out of pain.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Will you submit then, and obey it?

sp.speaker: Cle
sp.p: If it can put me out of pain, I will?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I doubt it not;—my Sentence is, that you revive that love you shew'd unto Pandora lately.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
Oh Sir, the very name of love, puts me into a shaking fit; for Heaven sake, give me Halters, Poysons, Daggers, any means to let out life, rather
then renew those torments which I felt that hour I lov'd.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Pray Sir, give me leave, to put him some Interogatories.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Do so.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Your Lordship has confest, that you have lov'd one hour, and must have some reason why you lov'd no longer; shew us that reason, or for ever hold your peace, and submit to judgement.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: How Clearcus, nonplust by a Judge in Petticoates?

sp.speaker: Lin
sp.p: Why Madam? many of our Sex have pussled the wisest men;—give him leave to think a little;—but if what I have said, has struck your Lordship dumb, hold up your finger,—'tis He holds it up enough;—He has nothing to say for himself, but submits unto the mercy of the Court;—I understand him Sir;—and have now found a remedy for both their evils;—If you will trust me with your hand my Lord, I will not harm it:—and Clearcus gives his hand. if I have credit enough Madam to be trusted with your hand too, pray lay it without fear on mine, that I may try a charm I have, to conjure out the evil Spirits that possess you both;—you may at your own pleasure, take back your hands;—only let me hold 'um, while I pronounce my charm within.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Pandora I intreat you to try Lindamira's charm, give her your hand, she deals not with the Devil.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: The Devil I work by Sir, is truth, drest in her rich robe of Innocence;—if truth do not convince both these Delinquents, my charm will have no power on them;—My Lord you have in this great Assembly, often said, that you could never value any woman you could win;—if now you have found this Lady as impregnable as you can wish, she is your fate;—hold Sir, remember He proffers to speak. you are dumb, till I have done;—Now Madam, I must speak serious sence to you, who stand here the expectation, and the wish of all the Court;—yet I know you must not consent to give your hand to him, nor in a look, or word comply, with what I say; for if you yield, Clearcus will forsake the Field;—I shall therefore onely put your hands together, no marriage, nor no contract make, only desire that you will thus hand in hand retire a while with me in private, to apply my charm, who now do pray, that all the evils which ever did befall the most unhappy lovers, may light on him, or you, that shall their hand remove, before my charm does work; now come with me.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
What the issue of this will be, I cannot guess;—Now Theodocia, I must remind you of Lonzartes, who dares not approach you on his own behalf, who is, what you can wish, to make
you happy; and I do again invite you to Crown his unparalell'd humility with a bliss, he presumes not once to mention, least it offend you; I have also a State Argument you understand not Theodocia, your two interests in this Dukedom, thus united, will make it flourish;—Lonzartes has been wrong'd.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: I know his wrong Sir, and have observ'd his sufferings, or I had never dallied with his love; Lonzarte's clear soul is adorn'd with more glories, then this Crown will bring him.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: If then your hearts agree, give me your hands;—here Lonzartes is the best reward I have, to incourage modesty and worth, when they do in one heart combine, as now in thine.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Great Sir, I am so much surprized, so overloaden with my joyes, that I have nought but blushes to express my gratitude;—nor know I how to welcome this unlook'd for honour from the Princess, who dains to raise her humblest Servant from her feet, to set me on a Throne, incirculed with more joyes, then that you now restore me to.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Keep still your Character Lonzartes, as I will mine, high transports in love are not long liv'd I fear.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I shall be Madam, whatever you direct, though this unlook'd for happiness, do raise my heart above my own command, for such an excess of joy, is hard to mannage.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p:
I may now wish your Highness Joy I
hope, now your Fannatick love, conforms to the Law of Nations;—Now you may talk your pleasure against high passions Madam;—and methinks you Sir, do look as if you lik'd this better then that wise Sect of ayrie lovers, whose Phylosophy doth teach not to desire, what they can never reach.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: You are Madam the best Phylosopher I ever met, and do deserve to have a Golden Statue in Loves-Temple set.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: But how have you disposed of your Fantastick couple? 'tis that great work must Crown all your undertakings Lindamira.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: That goes on excellently well Sir, I have left them sitting on a Couch, with their hands still fixt, eagerly gazing on each other eyes, as if through them they could discern the inside of each others hearts; by their no motion, and their stedy looks, I can foresee they will be of one mind suddainly.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Why could not we see this Experiment?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Oh Madam, my charm will not work in company; lovers will seemingly dispise, what they like most, onely to deceive observing eyes; I believe they held off thus long, for shame to owne what they had so publickly declar'd against, and to themselves will hardly dare to let their hearts appear these two dayes;—they must look themselves into an Argument, for no words can ever reconcile their first Principles.

l.hi: If their hands, do not their hearts discover,
I'le no more pretend to charm a lover.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: May we not peep at the hanging, and stand unseen.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Let us not turn this serious work into a jest, unless Lindamira do approve it; none shall stir that way.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I can place you so, as you may see and hear too.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Pray Sir be pleas'd to look on them, our Testimony may be of use.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Come then.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Your Highness must stand silent, or you'l hinder my Projection.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: We will, we will.
sp.stage: They all Re-enter behind the Couch, and stand on each side of the Stage; then is discover'd Pandora, and Clearcus holding hands, and sitting on a Couch, a while silent, looking on each other; then Clearcus proffers to kisse that hand he holds, she puts him back with her other hand, and turns her face from him,—He sighes:—

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
Turn not away those beautious lights have guided me to Heaven, nor look as if you were in pain to see my heart thus chang'd from a rude Destraction, to an Extasie of bliss; from a deformed Satyr, with a confus'd Chaos of dark thoughts, and blacker actions, by your glorious beauties, and brighter virtues, new form'd into the Figure of a man, Emulating those Excellencies I admire in you:—Oh turn this way, and own what is your own Creation, by your perfections rais'd from what was worse then nothing, to something now, too worthy to be cast away; I should this happy hour believe my self were in in Elizium; did not this fair, soft hand, and those bright eyes
assure me I yet live; from whence some divine instinct teaches my rude nature to adore, what I never understood before.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I do not like to be thus long left alone, to be expos'd unto your passion, and the worlds censure; Lindamira has deceiv'd my trust;—I now see your plot, and her design descover, but will no longer suffer the abuse.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Be not so cruel unto your self and me, think on the curse hangs over us, if we remove our hands till she return.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: 'Tis too much foolery, to give faith too.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Remember we complied to what she said; by which her words are Registr'd in heaven, and have ingaged the gods by our consent.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: 'Twas rashly done, and I repent;—when will this subtle Sorcerress return? my innocense will justifie my blind consent, to which I was misled by my fidelity and trust, and will no longer fear to take away my hand.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Oh take not your hand away untill the holy Charm have rectified your heart, and therein created so much charity, as in a moment may remove your scorns, and teach you love; for I, who so long slighted your neglects, and fled all civil favours from your Sex, do now tremble at the thought of parting hands, untill our hearts like them, become united.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Do you believe Lindamira Mistris of such Magick? that her words have power to reconcile dissenting hearts, like ours.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
Yes, I find them work on me, and hope
same effect on you, else why sit we here obeying those commands she left? why fear we to offend those powers she did invoke?—when you consider this, I hope you dare not stir a finger towards such impiety.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Though Lindamira's virtue be approv'd, I was surprized by her inticing words, and by the Duke compell'd to do, I know not what;—and therefore will no longer now obey.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Stay, oh stay, and let the fatal curse strike me alone; my guilts have merrited what e're can fall on me;—Do but command me to remove my hand, and I'le obey; that you may see how much your power prevails, above my fear of Lindamira's threats; If so, I may divert your harms; I will against my Nature and my Faith destroy all hopes of future bliss, to pull this ruine on myself, which else may light on you;—Say, must it be?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: If I command your hands remove, and her curse should after follow you, my unblemish'd Innocense may suffer more then all your crimes can merrit;—I have no faith in charmes, nor cause to apprehend her curses can reach me; and yet;—
sp.l: —My doubts and fears, my reason does dismay,
I know not what to do, nor what to say;
The Wonder is so great, I am afraid,
Some god this Serpent, has an Angel made,
And now indow'd him with Coelestial Art,
To force obedience from my stubborn heart.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: 'Tis worthy your consult, before you do destroy a body and soul; here a ready Sacrifice to set you free, for now I find that Lindamira's charm does higher work.
sp.l: And now again, that dazling light display,
Which did my heart inflame the other day:
Ye gods, I do implore your power to move,
The bright Pandora, to allow my love;
'Twill be the same, if now Clearcus dyes,
By Thunder struck, or by Pandora's eyes.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Lindamira's virtue, and her wit, are much more powerful, then her charms;—(which I contemn,) but you my Lord, have now by chance thrown out such words, I shake to think on;—Your body and your Soul are now at stake you say;—and by your looks I read, you think our Fortunes and our Fates, depend on my reply;—and so do I;—this is then too great a work, for so few minutes to dispatch; we must look up Clearcus, and from above seek ayde:—
sp.l: 'Tis piety, when we our hearts submit,
To undergo, what e're the gods think fit.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: 'Tis so, let us hasten to the Temple then, there Celebrate:—
sp.l: This happy issue of so strange contest,
Wrought by the gods, must by the gods be blest.
sp.stage: He Kisses her hand, three or four times in Joy.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
Where is this powerful Sibell gone? whose
Sacred Charms do dis-inchant fantastick hearts.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I am here Sir, with witness enough, to hold Pandora to her word.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Let me adore thy Divine virtue Lindamira? who hath shew'd such skill, to raise dead folks to life; for we were dead in follies, and are now become true converts Sir.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: This is great News, you are both well come to your wits again, which does declare Lindamira a great Artist.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: What sayes Pandora for her self?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: I have both waies done too much, either to excuse or justifie my self; silence becomes me Madam.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Let the clock strike twice, before we credit what they say, or else make all sure, by I Clearcus take thee Pandora, &c.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Lindamira is my Oracle;—give me your hand Pandora, and yours Clearcus.

l.hi: May they most wretched live, and cursed dye,
Who shall this knot endeavour to untye.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: My prayers concur with yours Sir, and now dear Cousin, what I wish'd is come to pass, that you and I might on the same day be Married.

l.hi: Thus for our good, we see the Gods fullfill
What they designe, though much against our will.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p:
Your great Example Madam, is sufficient to lead me from all my own resolves to follow you, and if now Clearcus be reclaim'd, we must own all our happiness to Lindamira's wit, who has conquer'd both, when neither of us could subdue
the other; And now Clearcus I hope will seek occasions to shew the World by his own actions the Noble Stock he is Descended from.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: By your permission Madam, I shall set my heart towards my Prince his, and my Countries Service;—I beg imployment Sir, on the next Gallies you send out, least idleness corrupt my busie brain.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Mark that Sir, he is already wavering; Madam take heed how you take the spirit of uncertainty, (in the habit of a man.)

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: You speak too late, the uncertain man, is now my certain fate.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Some diversions are necessary Madam, to look on the same objects ever, dulls and tyres the best eyes; but Lindamira can say nothing, I dare contradict.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: You shall command in Chief Clearcus, to shew the world the vigour you have too long hid.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: Joyes on joyes, light on Clearcus head.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: May those joyes be Multiplied on yours Sir; my Redeemer, and now become my Prince.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: We must conclude this happy day Lindamira, by joyning Silvanders hand with yours, if your mirth will give us leave to be so serious?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: That is a serious jest Sir, I have long look'd for.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Come near Silvander;—which of you two is most pleas'd now?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: I Sir.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Who spoke first?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: I Sir.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: This is a good Omen to a joyfull life; may you be both as happy as ever love made any.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: We are happy to our wish Sir.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: He speaks for himself Sir, on hopes of more then he may find.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: We'l Celebrate these weddings suddainly, and see that Lindamira's praise be in loud Hymenealls sung through all the City, to incourage the like Virtuous, and Noble undertakings.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I thank your Highness for your good opinion, but shall love you for this gift of my Silvander, above all your other favours; Now Silvander.

l.hi: Let us dwell Arme in Arme, and dayly show
Our loves increase, that all the World may know
Our hearts; Now the fair Princess does confess,
That Wedlock may afford True Happiness.

lg.l: LADIES, our Author has so great Respect
To Your Fair Sex, he fears some gross Defect
In his best Characters, may prove so short,
Of Your perfections, he needs pardon for't.
If such sad fate, do now attend his Play,
In's Cloak, thus muffl'd, he will sneak away;
But You like't, he will on tip-toe go,
That all the World, may the proud Author know.
